    "pages": }\n\n'''Elizabeth Katharine \"Betsy\" Johnson''' (born January 12, 1951) is an American aviator, entrepreneur, and politician who served in the  from the  and  House districts from 2001 to 2005, and in the  from the  from 2005 to 2021, as a member of the . Prior to her tenure in the state legislature she served on the  board and worked in the .\n\nJohnson was born in , as the daughter of , who served in the state house. She was raised in , and educated at , , and . She operated a helicopter business and participated in international helicopter competitions. She was active in local politics in , where she served on the boards of multiple groups and she was elected to the  board in a 1993 special election. She was the manager of aeronautics in the Oregon Department of Transportation from 1993 to 1998.\n\nShe was elected to the state house in the 2000 election and reelected in the 2002 and 2004 elections. Johnson was appointed to replace  in the state senate in 2005, and was reelected in the 2006, 2010, 2014, and 2018 elections. She was a moderate and  and held a controlling swing vote. She resigned from the state senate in 2021, to run in the  as an  candidate, losing to .\n\n\n\nElizabeth Katharine Johnson was born on January 12, 1951, in , to Elizabeth Hill Johnson and , who served in the  for fourteen years. She was raised in , and graduated from  in 1969. She campaigned for her father during her youth. She graduated from  with a  in history in 1974, and from  with a  in 1977.\n\nJohnson married John Helm. She represented the United States at a helicopter competition in , , in 1978. Johnson created Trans-Western Helicopters in 1978, and it merged into Hillsboro Helicopters in 1993. She served as president of the Columbia County Economic Development Council, and was on the boards of the Columbia County Health District,  , and  of Columbia County. She was appointed to the board of the Oregon Tourism Alliance in 1989. She replaced  as the chair of the  lectureship committee at  in 1992. She was the director of the  for six years.\n\n\n\n\nTony Federici, a member of the  board from the fourth position resigned in January 1993, in order to take office in the state house from the . Johnson defeated four other candidates in the 1993 special election and won without opposition in the 1997 election. She replaced Eric Dahlgren as chair of the board in 1999. She was appointed as the Manager of Aeronautics in the  in 1993, and served until her resignation on September 7, 1998.\n\n\n\n, a member of the state house from the 1st district, was term-limited during the 2000 election. Johnson faced no opposition in the  primary and won the  primary as a  and defeated  nominee Bob Ekstrom, the chair of the party, and  nominee Don McDaniel. She won the Democratic and Republican nominations and was elected from the  in the 2002 election against Constitution nominee Ekstrom and  candidate Mervin Arnold. She won the Democratic and Republican nominations and defeated Constitution nominee Ron Ross in the 2004 election.\n\nIn the state house Johnson used the same desk that her father had used during his tenure. During her tenure in the state house she served on the Ways and Means committee. Johnson was appointed to a shared seat on the  with Representative  in 2001. Following the  the House Special Task Force on State Emergency Preparedness was formed with Johnson being one of its members. She worked as 's campaign chair during the .\n\n\n\n, a member of the , was appointed to the  by Governor  in 2004. Johnson announced on November 24, 2004, that she was interested in replacing Dukes in the state senate. Johnson, Bill Blank, and Emil Nyberg were nominated by the Columbia County Democratic Committee as possible options to replace Dukes. County commissioners from Columbia, Clatsop, Multnomah, Tillamook, and Washington counties voted unanimously on January 19, 2005, to appoint Johnson and she was sworn in on January 20.  was selected to replace her in the state house.\n\nShe defeated Republican nominee Don Fell and Constitution nominee Robert J. Simmering in the 2006 election. She defeated Republican nominee Bob Horning in the 2010 election. , the former chair of the , called for Johnson to be replaced after she voted with the Republicans against voter registration legislation in 2013. She defeated independent candidate Andrew Kaza, Constitution nominee Ekstrom, and Libertarian nominee Perry Roll in the 2014 election. She won the Democratic, Republican, and  nominations, with write-in votes in the Republican and Independent primaries, and defeated Constitution nominee Ray Biggs in the 2018 election.\n\nDuring her tenure in the state senate she served on the Rules committee and co-chaired the Ways and Means committee. An ethics investigation was launched against her on June 22, 2007, as she did not report profits of $119,000 from selling property connected to legislation she sponsored and she later paid a $600 fine. She was later investigated by the . Due to the Democrats' narrow control of the state senate she had a controlling swing vote and blocked legislation.\n\nShe endorsed , the Republican nominee for , in the 2016 election. She and Witt were removed from the executive committee of the  due to their support of Richardson. , Johnson, and  called for United States Senators Wyden and  to support President 's appointment of  to the .\n\nJohnson hit a driver with her car in 2013, resulting in Betsy Johnson spending six months in a wheelchair and not fully recovering until 2019. She was sued by the driver in 2015, but Johnson's lawyers argued the lawsuit was frivolous, and a violation of the Oregon Constitution due to her being in transit to her complete her duties as an elected official. The lawsuit was subsequently dismissed.\n\n\n\nJohnson was considered as a possible gubernatorial or  candidate in the 2000s. She announced on October 14, 2021, in an email that she was going to run as an independent in the  stating \"[H]aving to choose between another left-wing liberal promising more of the same or a right-wing Trump apologist – is no choice at all\". The Democratic caucus subsequently removed her from all of her committee assignments. She announced on December 14, that she was going to resign from the state senate to focus on her gubernatorial campaign and it took effect on December 16. Emmet Duffy is her campaign manager.\n\n was criticized for, and subsequently apologized for, inviting Betsy Johnson to a May 2022 conference in violation of the 's regulations for 501(c)3 nonprofits, which require that if any political candidates are invited to speak at an event, all other candidates are given an equal opportunity. She received endorsements that included former Governor Kulongoski and former United States Senator . As of early June, her campaign has raised $5,611,714.37, with $1 million coming from , and spent $3,292,831.82. Knight increased his stake in the race in late August, contributing another $750,000 to Johnson's campaign. In July,  reported that \"shirts bearing the ...dott[ed] the crowd\" at a June rally in , a flag which Johnson later condemned as \"a symbol of treason against the United States\". She stated to OPB in September that as governor she would lift the  and enforce the death penalty.\n\nJohnson's campaign spent $897,000 to collect 48,214 signatures, with 23,744 being required to appear on the ballot, and 37,679  were validated by the secretary of state.\n\nIn the general election, Johnson conceded to Tina Kotek after garnering less than 10% of the total vote.\n\n\n\nJohnson was considered as a moderate and conservative member of the state legislature. She received a lifetime rating of 34.34% from the . The  gave her a score of 43% in 2005, 50% in 2007, 0% in 2008, 60% in 2009, 20% in 2013, 83% in 2015, and 50% in 2017.\n\n\nJohnson supported the construction of a $230 million ethanol plant in . She voted in committee in favor of legislation to  in restaurants, but stated that she did so only to send it to a vote in the state house. In 2002, Johnson voted in favor of the unsuccessful effort to overturn legislation to borrow $50 million for education against revenue made from a cigarette tax.\n\nJohnson voted against  legislation in 2007. In 2009, she voted against legislation supported by the  that prohibited workers from being required to attend company meetings about politics. She voted against increasing the  gradually from 2016 to 2022, to between $12.50 and $14.75 per hour. Johnson received a D rating from the  in 2018. She received a score of 50% from the  in 2020.\n\n\nJohnson opposed four pieces of gun control legislation in 2013, stating \"I would do something meaningful rather than symbolic\" and wanted more mental health access instead. She voted against background checks for private gun sales and  legislation. She is a member of the  and received an \"A\" rating and endorsement from the  during the 2014 and 2018 elections.\n\nShe voted against legislation in 2019 to redefine  and limit its scope, the only crime in Oregon which is eligible for the death penalty. She also is in favor of lifting the state moratorium on the death penalty.\n\n\nJohnson opposes a  approach to homelessness, and would enforce laws against illegal camping in Oregon. She blames recent drug legalization, such as through , for driving the crisis and would attempt to repeal it, while also focusing on deregulating housing development.\n\n\nJohnson supports . She stated that \" now is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Democrat Party\" after failing to gain its endorsement during the 2022 gubernatorial election. She opposes allowing  to participate in girls' sporting events.\n\n\nJohnson has not shown support for adopting political campaign contribution limits in Oregon, and said she would oppose limits she felt \"result in an uneven playing field for anyone participating in elections\". She voted against legislation to make  automatic for people with driver's licenses.\n\n\nShe received a lifetime score of 64% from the , and has a record of voting against legislation to combat climate change, such as .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* , former official senatorial website\n* , gubernatorial campaign website\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Beatrice Perin Barker Hall''' (March 18, 1921 – April 26, 2018) was an American politician from the state of . Hall served in the  for a total of 28 years, serving non-consecutively from 1970 until 2008.\n\nHall grew up in , where she attended . In 1948, she and her husband moved to the town of , where they started a  firm. Beginning in the 1950s and early 1960s, Hall began participating in local politics, serving on several boards and commissions in Brookline. Hall was elected to the Brookline school board in 1963, and in 1972, she was elected to the town .\n\nHall's career in statewide politics began in 1970 when she was elected to the New Hampshire House of Representatives as a member of the . In 1986, Hall switched her party affiliation to the , citing the Republican Party's shift towards  during the . During her political career, Hall was described as a firebrand who frequently bucked her party. While a Republican, Hall was seen as a  member of that party, and was considered to be a political enemy by conservative leaders. In the Democratic Party, Hall was a member of the  base, challenging the party's establishment in a 2007 campaign for chairman of the .\n\nIn the 2000s, Hall became nationally known for her activism. In 2004, she was arrested for  for her participation in a protest against President ; she was later acquitted of the charge. In 2008, Hall introduced , which would have petitioned the  to introduce  to  President Bush and Vice President  for their actions leading to and during the . While the bill ultimately failed, it generated a large amount of media coverage.\n\n\n\n\nBeatrice Perin Barker was born on March 18, 1921, in , , where her father , a  officer, served as the administrator of a  following . After leaving the military, Barker's father completed his education in engineering from the , receiving an academic position at the institution. He later became the  at , and she primarily grew up in . This led to Barker's entry into academia, as her father's position at Columbia University brought prominent scientists such as  and  to their home for dinner where Barker would serve as a hostess. In 1937, her mother Mary died when Barker was 16.\n\nBarker attended the  and later studied engineering at . She would later do graduate work at the , , and the .\n\n\nAfter graduating from Barnard College in 1943, Barker worked as an engineer at . During , she helped manufacture  for  equipment, and her father served as a special assistant to , the .\"Joseph Barker, 84, Dean at Columbia\" New York Times, Dec. 12, 1975\n\nOn May 27, 1944, she married Sidney Leavitt Hall, an engineer from , leaving her job at Western Electric to join her husband in , where he was undergoing training with the  in order to fight in World War II. However, the war ended before he was sent overseas, and in 1948, the couple moved to , a town of 800 people in . Hall's grandmother, Florence Hobart Perin, was a resident of Brookline, and Hall had frequently visited and spent several summers in the town during her youth. Sidney Hall initially worked at , and in 1951, the couple started a  firm called Hall Manufacturing Company, which was informally known as Hall Tote Bags. The company produced stitching for , as well as steam air covers for dry-cleaning machines. Later, the company became locally famous for the  they produced, as well as other stitched products. Hall and her husband were members of the local , and she was credited with uniting the Brookline  and  churches into one single church.\n\nIn 1957, Hall received a  from the . Hall served as the assistant manager for Hall Manufacturing Co. until 1962, whereupon she became a science and mathematics teacher in . Hall transferred to Fairgrounds Junior High School in , in 1964, and taught mathematics there until 1972. In 1968, Hall was awarded a grant by the  in order to start an experimental \"Mathematics Learning Laboratory\" at her school. She had also been invited to academic conferences, such as the Advanced Modern Math Institute, which was sponsored by .\n\nSidney Hall died in 1987 at the age of 66. Hall and her husband had four sons and one daughter. One of their sons, Sidney Hall Jr., is a locally-known author.  Following her husband's death, Hall solely ran Hall Manufacturing Co., and the company was featured in a  symposium on small businesses in 1994. Hall Manufacturing Co. closed in 2001.\n\n\n\n\nDuring the 1950s and 1960s, Hall became very active in local politics, serving on numerous boards and committees in Brookline, including the board of assessors and the town finance committee. In 1961, Hall was defeated in an election for Brookline library trustee. In 1963, Hall was elected unopposed to the Brookline school board. She was re-elected in 1966, defeating future state representative  and another candidate. In 1969, Hall was re-elected for her third and final term on the school board. She served as the chairman of the school board from 1964 until 1968 and again in 1971. She served a total of 9 years on the school board.\n\nIn 1967, Hall ran for the Brookline ; however, she was defeated by Walter W. Frost, receiving 138 votes to Frost's 152. In 1972, Hall served as the chairman of the Brookline Republican Town Committee. Later that year, Hall again ran for the Brookline board of selectmen to succeed the retiring , defeating two candidates to win a three-year term as selectman. Following her election to the board of selectmen, Hall did not seek another term for the school board and resigned as a teacher. In 1974, Hall served as the chairman of the board of selectmen.\n\n\nIn 1970, Hall ran for the  in Hillsborough County's 13th district as a member of the . Hall had decided to run for state office because she \"realized she was not accomplishing what she wanted to\" in local office. She was recruited to run by Governor  Hall and fellow Republican  were elected with 43% and 41% of the vote, respectively. In 1972, Hall ran for re-election in Hillsborough County's 12th district, and was elected unopposed alongside fellow Republican . During the 1970s, Hall held multiple positions in the local Republican Party, serving as a member of the Republican state committee the Hillsborough County Republican Party Executive Committee.\n\n\nIn 1974, Hall ran for the  of the , running to replace retiring Republican incumbent . In the Republican primary, Hall faced fellow state representative , as well as  town selectman , a former state senator and former member of the . During the primary, Hall campaigned via bicycle, cycling a total of 1,000 miles through the 26 towns in the district. Hall won the primary election, narrowly defeating Rock. Despite Hall placing second in her hometown of Brookline and only winning two towns,  and , both towns gave her large margins. Additionally, she placed second in nearly every other town in the district, offsetting the large margin by which Rock won in Nashua. Official sources conflict on the final vote tally: the  officially reported that Hall received 1,544 votes, Rock received 1,485 votes, and Fletcher received 1,198 votes, giving Hall a winning margin of just 59 votes. However, a recount found that the margin was actually 114 votes in favor of Hall, with the town of Amherst alone overcounting 50 ballots in favor of Rock; however, the results of the recount are not officially recorded. Hall's campaign expenditure for the primary was $1,470.\n\nWhile there was no official  candidate running in the heavily Republican district, both Hall and Rock also contested the Democratic primary as . Rock won the Democratic write-in nomination, with official sources again conflicting on the tally: the New Hampshire General Court reported that Rock received 72 votes to Hall's 71, a margin of just one vote, while a recount reportedly increased Rock's margin to 3 votes.\n\nDuring the general election campaign, Rock was heavily supported by , the publisher of the '''', an influential conservative newspaper. Rock frequently used the newspaper's front page to promote his campaign. While Hall was endorsed by the '''', her campaign did not have the media capabilities that Rock's did, and Rock ultimately won the general election, defeating Hall by a margin of 53% to 47%. , then the chairman of the Nashua Republican Party, alleged that the party's campaign literature had been tampered with; specifically, Gregg alleged that an individual had switched out Hall's campaign literature from several envelopes and replaced it with Rock's campaign literature before they were sent out to voters in Nashua. However, Hall stated that she did not believe the incident had influenced the end result of the election. Hall was succeeded in the state house by Republican .\n\n\nIn 1975, Hall became the chairman of the New Hampshire branch of , a lobbying group that opposes corruption and promotes . In this role, Hall advocated for . In the , Hall criticized Republican candidate  and independent candidate  for being the only two major candidates who had not agreed to the campaign standards proposed by Common Cause. She later criticized all the presidential candidates for not discussing the costs of the programs they propose. Hall left the position in September 1977.\n\nIn 1978, Hall was elected back to the New Hampshire House of Representatives for Hillsborough County's 12th district. Hall and fellow Republican  won with 36% and 31% of the vote. Hall and Ware were re-elected unopposed in 1980.\n\nIn November 1980, Rock, who had still serving as the state senator for the 12th district, died of cancer just three days after winning re-election. Hall was one of four candidates vying for the Republican nomination for the February 1981 ; instead of being elected in a primary election, the party nominee was instead to be selected by delegates of the Hillsborough County Republican Party. Hall's campaign for the nomination was heavily opposed by , the influential Republican , who viewed Hall as a political opponent. Monier instead supported , a Nashua businessman and the New Hampshire campaign chair for 's . The other Republican candidates were state representatives , , and . Despite an initial convention ending in , with 9 delegates voting for Hall and the other 9 for Stabile, the party reconvened and ultimately selected Stabile to be the Republican nominee. Stabile would go on to defeat Democratic state representative  and independent candidate Mark Knox, a Nashua alderman, in the special election.\n\nIn 1982, Hall ran for the  of the New Hampshire Senate to replace retiring Republican incumbent . Hall placed third in the Republican primary, losing to fellow state representative ; Hall received 29% of the vote, while White received 40%. The second-place candidate, state representative , received 31% of the vote. However, Hall won the Democratic nomination as a write-in candidate, receiving 199 votes compared to White's 81 and Amidon's 55. Hall was defeated by White in the general election, receiving 4,668 votes to White's 6,632.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1986, Hall switched to the Democratic Party, citing the Republican Party's shift towards . That year, Hall ran as a Democrat for the state house in Hillsborough County's 16th district. Hall defeated incumbent Republican state representative , who had been facing charges of  after it was revealed she used her position as  town clerk to embezzle $10,000 in fees. Hall received 642 votes, while Fried received 555. Hall was narrowly re-elected in 1988, defeating Republican candidate Shirley A. Morley by just 54 votes out of 2,274 cast. Hall was re-elected in 1990, defeating former Republican state representative , 56% to 44%.\n\nIn 1992, Hall ran for re-election in Hillsborough County's 20th district. Hall and Republican  were elected, receiving 1,488 votes and 1,384 votes, respectively. Hall and Arnold had previously served together on the Brookline school board in the 1960s, where Arnold was the school board's moderator. The two were re-elected unopposed in 1994. In 1996, they were again re-elected, with Hall receiving 46% of the vote and Arnold receiving 36%. In 1996, Hall served as the chairman of the Hillsborough County Democratic Party. In 1998, Hall and Arnold were again re-elected. Arnold received 1,063 votes, while Hall received 1,001.\n\nHall was an early supporter of  in the , and was a delegate for Clinton at the . Hall also praised  during the , supporting his tax policy and stating that he seemed honest.\n\n\n\nIn 2000, Hall and Arnold were re-elected unopposed. In 2002, Hall ran for re-election in Hillsborough County's 46th district. However, Hall was defeated in the general election, placing fifth with 12% of the vote.\n\nIn 2004, Hall was arrested and charged with  at a protest against President  in Nashua. Hall, who was 83 at the time, was sitting in a chair outside the designated area for protestors, and was close to the presidential motorcade route. Hall was also holding a sign that said, \"Bush is bad for America\". After Hall refused to move, three police officers picked Hall up, \"chair, cane, and all\", carrying her away and arresting her. A photographer captured the arrest, and the incident became national news. Hall was acquitted in September 2004 after Nashua District Court judge Clifford Kinghorn ruled that the evidence provided did not fit the charge of disorderly conduct; Kinghorn stated that \"the police had no authority under state law to make Hall move because she wasn't getting in their way\". Hall also explained that she had originally written the law that was being applied to her case.\n\nLater in 2004, Hall ran again for the state house for Hillsborough County's 5th district. Hall won, placing fourth with 13% of the vote. In the , Hall was a supporter of 's . Hall was re-elected in 2006, placing fourth and receiving 13% of the vote; Hall narrowly defeated fellow incumbent , a Republican, receiving just 25 more votes than him.\n\nIn 2007, Hall announced her candidacy for chairman of the . Her main opponent was , the vice chair of the state party and an executive member of the . During the campaign, Buckley, who was considered to be the frontrunner, was falsely accused of possessing child pornography by former state representative , who had been a former friend of his. Buckley was exonerated following an official state investigation, and Vaillancourt later stated that he had exaggerated in the allegations. Later in the campaign, Joe Kelly Levasseur, the chairman of the  Republican Party, posted an old home video of Buckley to , in which Buckley, who is openly gay, is seen \"cursing and unzipping his pants\", as well as highlighting Buckley's membership in a  group called \"Gays in New Hampshire\". Despite this, Buckley maintained his support amongst statewide Democrats, with the exception of U.S. representative , who withdrew his support for Buckley following the release of the video. Buckley ultimately defeated Hall, receiving 109 votes to Hall's 17. A third candidate, former state house Democratic Leader , withdrew following Buckley's exoneration, but remained on the ballot.\n\n\nIn 2008, Hall again gained national prominence for introducing a bill in the New Hampshire House of Representatives which would petition the  to introduce  to  President Bush and Vice President  for  relating to the . The bill accused Bush and Cheney of electioneering, torture, unlawful surveillance, misleading Congress, and violating the  by engaging in an unlawful aggressive war, as well as other alleged crimes. The bill, , cited section 603 of , which states that \"an impeachment may be set in motion by the  by charges transmitted from the legislature of a state\". In 1973, Hall had opposed a similar bill calling for the impeachment of President .\n\nHall campaigned for impeachment alongside U.S. representative , whose  she supported in the . Hall's bill was supported by '''' leaker , former  , and former director of the  . However, the bill also had several outspoken opponents, such as Republican state representative , who stated he had \"never seen a document more vitriolic and more inflammatory\".\n\nIn February 2008, the House State-Federal Relations and Veterans Affairs Committee voted 10-5 to recommend that the House not vote for the bill. In April 2008, the state house voted 227-95 to  the resolution, effectively killing the legislation. Some Democrats who voted in favor of tabling the bill, such as state representatives  and , both of whom said they supported the bill in principle, stated that the bill would take away time that could be spent fixing everyday issues. , another Democratic state representative, stated that impeachment would be too divisive.\n\n\nLater in 2008, Hall ran for the 12th district of the New Hampshire Senate as an , despite still being a registered Democrat. Hall placed a distant third with just 10% of the vote. Democrat  won with 47% of the vote, while Republican state representative  received 43%. In 2010, Hall officially switched her party registration to independent, stating that she \"wanted to make a statement [that] neither party was doing what they should be\". That year, Hall ran as an independent candidate for the New Hampshire House of Representatives in Hillsborough County's 5th district. However, Hall placed seventh out of eight candidates, receiving just 6% of the vote in the district she formerly represented. In 2012, Hall ran as an independent candidate for the state house in Hillsborough County's 12th district. She placed last out of five candidates, receiving 10% of the vote.\n\n\nHall died on April 26, 2018, of  in . At the time of her death, Hall had 5 children, 12 grandchildren, and 21 great-grandchildren.\n\n\nDuring her tenure with both the Republican and Democratic parties, Hall frequently challenged her party's . While in the Republican Party, Hall was seen as a member of the party's ; she was an objector to the  and opposed an attempt to outlaw , with Hall stating, \"I don't think I should legislate my religious beliefs on someone else\". While a Democrat, Hall was seen as a firebrand emblematic of the party's  base, challenging the Democratic establishment by opposing Buckley in 2007 and leading the attempt to impeach Bush. Hall was described as \"a giant among the moral compass-holders in the community\".\n\nWhile in the state house, Hall's primary issues were the government integrity and campaign finance reform. Hall was also an advocate for mental health issues. She served as the first president of Milford Regional Counseling Services in the 1970s, and later founded Harbor Homes, an organization that provides transitional housing for people with mental illness. In the 1960s, Hall was also the president of the Waban Association for Retarded Children.\n\n\nIn 1989, Hall led opposition towards a bill which would introduce new regulations against  operators. However, the following week, in what was described as \"parliamentary shenanigans\", the bill was revived, amended, and passed in both chambers of the state legislature. Later in 1989, Hall sponsored a  which would have introduced a 5-cent deposit on bottles and cans in order finance recycling centers. The bill also called for bottles and cans to be recycled instead of reused. Hall sponsored a similar bill in 1979, which would have imposed a tax ranging from $25 to $9,000 a year on businesses in order to fund litter control and recycling.\n\nIn 1990, New Hampshire's economy collapsed and the state fell heavily into debt. Hall opposed a bill which would order the state to repay all of its bills within 30 days, stating that it didn't solve the problem and \"would only make us think we're doing something\". Hall also opposed a budget which would marginally cut spending and levy small taxes, such as a 4-cent  and a 5% phone tax, stating that \"cutting 10 percent and 20 percent isn't going to do. Nickel and dime taxes aren't going to do it either\". She was instead supportive of the legislature stepping back and allow the governor to \"reduce spending any way he could\". Hall had previously opposed the state budget in 1979 due to the inclusion of a 1-cent . In 2007, Hall supported legislation pushed by the  which would \"reduce carbon pollution from power plants, lower energy bills and strengthen our economy\".\n\n\nThroughout her career, Hall supported the breaking up of cooperative school districts. Cooperative school districts, known as school administrative units (SAUs), were school districts consisting of multiple towns. Hall said that wealthier, smaller towns would be forced to disproportionately fund an SAU when grouped with poorer, larger towns. She also said the small towns were effectively trapped in the SAU as long as the larger towns were able to out-vote the smaller towns.\n\nIn 1971, Hall sponsored legislation which would establish a volunteer corps to provide assistance and counseling to minors who violated the law. In 1973, she sponsored a bill which would create a scholarship program for college students from New Hampshire. After a first attempt failed in the House, the bill was amended to apply only to students attending in-state colleges. The program would provide matching funds for college students: the state would allocate 25 cents for every dollar given by a private scholarship. During her 2008 state senate campaign, Hall stated that she opposed funding education from property taxes, instead supporting a \"pay-as-you-go\" model.\n\n\nIn 1972, Hall supported an  bill which would restrict candidates from working in polling places in which their name was on the ballot. She was the only representative from a small town to support the bill. Introduced by state representative , the bill had public support, but faced heavy opposition in the House after being \"verbally beaten into the ground by many state representatives from small towns who double as election officials in their home communities\". In her support for the bill, Hall said that it could allow for more people to become involved in the political process.\n\nWhile with Common Cause in 1977, Hall supported a state ethics commission to watch over the state legislature, stating that at the time New Hampshire was the only state that didn't have conflict-of-interest legislation. In 1979, Hall supported a rule change in the state house that would require all members of the House to list their sources of income. In the mid-2000s, Hall stated her concerned with the outsourcing of New Hampshire's  to private companies, citing security and integrity concerns. In 2006, Hall proposed a bill which would make primary and general election days a state holiday. The same year, Hall supported a rules change in the state house which would end segregated party seating, which she said increased partisanship by keeping members of opposing parties separated from each other. During her independent candidacies, Hall also advocated for elections to be publicly funded in order to limit the effects of corporate influence on elections. Due to her work on campaign finance reform, Hall was frequently compared to , who she was friends with, and with whom she collaborated on election reform issues with.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert J. \"Bob\" Leeper''' (born December 8, 1958) is an American  politician and . He was a member of the  from 1991 to 2015 retiring to run for  Judge-Executive. In 2014, he was elected Judge-Executive of McCracken County, but chose not to seek reelection in 2018.\n\n\nLeeper attended  and .\n\n\nPrior to serving in the Kentucky State Senate, Leeper was a city commissioner in Paducah.\n\n\nOriginally a , Leeper joined the  in 2000, and became a political independent later in the decade. Leeper has been described as an \"ultra-conservative independent\", and was known in the legislature for his opposition to expanded gambling. In 2012, he mounted an unsuccessful candidacy to serve as president of the Kentucky State Senate. He decided against re-election in 2014 and ran for McCracken County Judge-Executive.\n\n\nIn 2014, Leeper was elected Judge-Executive of . In 2018, he faced criticism over the termination of Paducah Economic Development president and CEO Scott Darnell, and issued a statement saying he would not answer questions about the matter. He did not seek reelection in 2018.\n\n\nIn 2020, he was honored with the opening of the Bob Leeper Bridge, a 110-foot pedestrian bridge in McCracken County.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  at \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

As of 2024, McPherson is the very last Republican to serve as California Secretary of State to date.\n\n\nMcPherson was born and raised in . He attended , where he played football as a  and baseball as a . He earned a Bachelor of Science degree in journalism from  in 1965.\n\n\nPrior to his political career, he worked as the editor of the '''', a newspaper owned by his family. McPherson served as a member of the  from 1993 to 1996 and  from 1996 to 2004. McPherson was defeated in the 2002 election for  by incumbent .\n\nHe was nominated to replace former Secretary of State , who resigned on March 4. McPherson, a  from , served his term as secretary until January 8, 2007. He was confirmed ly by both -controlled houses of the  after being nominated to replace Shelley, a Democrat, by Governor .     "pages": }\n\n'''Carolyn Goodman''' ( '''Goldmark'''; born March 25, 1939) is an American politician who has served as  of , since 2011. She is the second female mayor of Las Vegas and is married to former mayor and attorney . She is the founder, president and trustee emerita of .\n\n\nBorn in  in 1939 to a  family, Goodman attended the , then earned a bachelor's degree in  from  in 1961. She and Oscar Goodman moved to Las Vegas from  in 1964. She graduated from the  in 1973 with a master's degree in counseling.\n\n\nGoodman is the founder, president and trustee emerita of . She and her husband moved to Las Vegas in 1964 and soon became active in the local Jewish federation. Eventually, she became the leader of the local Jewish federation's women's division, a position she held for several years.  She received the 2009 Commitment to Education award from the  of Southern Nevada.\n\nOn , Goodman was elected mayor of Las Vegas with 60% of the vote in a  against , and she took office on July 6, 2011. She was reelected  against  and several minor opponents, and  was reelected to a third (and, due to term limits, final) term, with 83.5% of the vote against several minor opponents, including local politician .\n\nOn October 24, 2011, Goodman greeted President  at . In regard to negative remarks Obama had made about Las Vegas two years earlier that had angered her husband, the previous mayor, she told Obama that \"the slate is brand new and clean\", and gave him one of her lucky mayor chips as a gift.\n\nOn July 15, 2015, Goodman endorsed  for the  in . Kihuen defeated incumbent U.S. Representative . Days later, she endorsed  for the  in . On August 3, 2016, Goodman declined to endorse  or  in the . She identifies as an .\n\nDuring her tenure as mayor, Goodman promoted Las Vegas as a home for professional sports teams. The  of the  (NHL) began playing professional hockey in the  at  and the  of the  (NFL)  to play at , although neither team is within Las Vegas's city limits: both are in , outside the mayor's jurisdiction. Goodman attempted to lure a soccer team to Las Vegas several times, including bids for a  (MLS) expansion team, and ultimately got a second-division team, the  of the  (USL), which began playing in 2018. Goodman has also shown some  albeit significantly less  support for the  to , which is expected to occur in 2028.\n\nGoodman is no longer eligible to run for reelection due to . In 2019, her final term was extended a year due to a state law that shifted all municipal elections held in off-years to even-numbered years, meaning her term will end in 2024.\n\nOn April 22 and 23, 2020, in interviews with 's  and 's  during the , Goodman said she wanted to reopen Las Vegas's casinos and hotels. When pressed about procedures necessary to ensure patrons' safety, she said that wasn't her responsibility and was up to the businesses. During the interview with Cooper, Goodman questioned the impact of , saying Las Vegas \"offered to be a control group\" to test what would happen if casinos reopened, but was advised against it \"because people from all parts of southern Nevada come in to work in the city.\" She also suggested that social distancing be subjected to a placebo test, adding, \"We would love to be that placebo\". When Cooper asked whether she would be willing to go to one of the casinos if they were soon reopened, she replied: \"First of all, I have a family. I don't gamble.\" Goodman's comments were widely criticized and faced backlash from other elected officials. U.S. Representative  from Nevada's 1st congressional district, which includes the Las Vegas Strip, disagreed with Goodman, saying it was necessary to heed scientists' advice to shelter at home whenever possible to enable the successful recovery of Las Vegas's businesses. Titus added, \"The mayor does not represent the Las Vegas Strip, literally or figuratively.\" Nevada Governor  also pushed back, saying, \"I will not allow the citizens of Nevada, our Nevadans, to be used as a control group, as a placebo, whatever she wants to call it\", and that he would not \"allow our workers to be put in position that they have to decide between their job and their paycheck and their life. That's not a fair position to put them in.\"\n\n\nGoodman's husband is Oscar Goodman, who was Carolyn's predecessor as mayor from 1999 to 2011. They have four children and six grandchildren. Oscar Jr. is a doctor with the Comprehensive Cancer Centers of Nevada,  is a criminal defense attorney, Eric is a Las Vegas justice of the peace, and Cara is a marriage and family therapist who also works with burn victims at University Medical Center. Cara was one of three students in The Meadows School's first graduating class in 1991.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Carolyn Stanford Taylor''' is an American educator who served as the   from 2019 to 2021. Stanford Taylor was the first African American to serve as Wisconsin Superintendent of Public Instruction.\n\nHer appointment was announced by Wisconsin   in December 2018, who served as  prior to his election as Governor. She did not run for the seat in 2021. Prior to assuming the superintendent's office, she served as the Assistant State Superintendent for the Wisconsin Division for Learning Support for 17 years.\n\n\nBorn and raised in , Stanford Taylor and her siblings were one of the first African American families to integrate the schools. She attended the  where she received a bachelor's degree in  in 1978 and a master's degree in educational leadership and policy analysis in 1979.\n\n\nStanford Taylor served as a classroom teacher and principal in the  for twenty years, serving as principal of Marquette and Lincoln elementary schools and Wright Middle School. She was the first African-American president of the local teachers union. Prior to her appointment as State Superintendent, Stanford Taylor was the first female, African-American appointed to serve as an assistant state superintendent. She supervised the Special Education Team, one of the agency's largest teams; the Student Services/Prevention and Wellness Team, which focused on student safety, support, and engagement; and the residential schools for students who are blind and visually impaired in  and students who are deaf and hard of hearing in .\n\n\nStanford Taylor is the 2018 recipient Virginia Hart Special Recognition, an award bestowed by the , Division of Personnel Management, to female state employees \"who are making a difference through their service to Wisconsin.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n* at the \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Charles Kong Djou''' (born August 9, 1970) is an American politician and attorney who is currently Secretary of the . A former member of the , Djou briefly served as  from  from May 2010 to January 2011. , he is the last Republican to represent Hawaii in Congress. \n\nDjou was elected to Congress in a  with 39.68% of the vote against two Democratic opponents. He was defeated in the November 2010  by . His election made him the first , as well as the first Republican of  descent, to serve in the House of Representatives. Prior to his election to Congress, he was a member of the  and the .\n\nFollowing his defeat in 2010, he unsuccessfully ran to represent the district in the  and  elections. In , he was a candidate for , ultimately losing to  by a 52% to 48% margin. In 2018, Djou left the Republican Party due to his opposition to then-President . Djou supported Democratic nominee 's  in the . Following Biden's victory, Djou was appointed Secretary of the .\n\n\nDjou was born on August 9, 1970 in  to a Chinese father from  and a  mother from . His paternal grandfather fled Shanghai following the , settling in .\n\nDjou grew up in  after his father's employer transferred him there when Djou was three. He graduated from high school at , and earned a  in  and a  in  from the , graduating ''''. He earned his  degree at the  at the . Djou earned his  graduate degree in strategic studies at the  where he was a resident student and Carlisle Scholar.\n\nDjou is a  in the . He has taught as an adjunct professor of law at the  and as an adjunct professor of political science at .\n\n\nDjou was Vice Chairman of the  from 1998 to 1999 and was later named legislator of the year by Small Business Hawaii in 2002, 2004, and 2006. In 2006 he was selected as one of the 40 most promising leaders in Hawaii under age 40 by '''', and in 2005 was named by '''' as the \"Best Politician\" in the state.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1998, Djou ran as a Republican for the  District 47 seat. He was unopposed in the primary election, but lost to Iris Ikeda Catalani in the general election by 190 votes.\n\nIn 2000, he again ran for the Hawaii State House of Representatives District 47 seat. Unopposed in the primary, he faced Catalani in the general election. Catalani faced controversy in the campaign, with allegations that she broke a promise to , a community  organization, by posting yard signs. Djou won the race with 52.5 percent of the vote to Catalani's 44.2 percent.\n\n\nAs a member of the State House of Representatives, Djou had one term in the  from 2000 to 2002 and was the Minority Floor Leader. Djou launched a successful campaign to open the State Budget worksheets to the public after being told he could look at the budget worksheets in the committee room but was not allowed to take any notes or make copies of them. The documents detail the budget for various state departments and agencies. He opposed the state \"van cam\" program launched in 2002 to catch speeders using automated cameras instead of police officers, and successfully campaigned for its elimination.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2002, Djou announced he would run for the Honolulu City Council. He also announced he would move to  (City Council District IV) from Kaneohe (City Council District III) to avoid running against fellow Republican Stan Koki. Honolulu City and County elections are officially nonpartisan, and any candidate who wins a majority of the votes in the primary election can win outright. No candidate received a majority of the votes in the primary election, so Djou and Robert Fishman, a former city managing director and chief of staff to the governor, faced each other in a runoff in the general election. Djou won with 51.3 percent of the vote to Fishman's 39.2 percent.\n\nDjou ran for reelection to the Honolulu City Council. He was unopposed and won the seat by default.\n\n\nIn 2002, Djou was elected to the , representing District IV ( to ). He was reelected in 2006 and was on the council until his election to Congress. On the City Council he was the Chairman of the Zoning Committee, Vice Chair of the Planning Committee and as a member of the Transportation and Public Safety & Services committees.\n\n\n\n.]]\n\n\n\n\n\nIn March 2008, Djou announced well ahead of time that he would run for  in the 2010 cycle, seeking  seat. The seat became vacant on February 28, 2010, when incumbent  resigned to run for . Abercrombie's resignation precipitated a special election on May 22, 2010, which Djou entered. Djou was endorsed by former Massachusetts Governor and Presidential candidate . Djou subsequently endorsed Romney for president in the summer of 2011. Former Hawaii Congresswoman , a Republican for whom Djou had once volunteered as a teenager, was Djou's campaign chair.\n\nIn the special election, Djou received 39.4 percent of the vote. He defeated five Democrats, four Republicans, and four independent candidates. Among the candidates Djou defeated were former Congressman  and State Senator , two Democrats who together polled over 58% of the vote. Djou was sworn in three days later and was in office for the remainder of Abercrombie's 2008 term. He was the first Republican to represent the district in 20 years. He followed Abercrombie and  as the third person to have been in the Honolulu City Council, Hawaii State Legislature and U.S. Congress, and was the first to be elected to all three chambers before age 40.\n\n\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* ''''''\n\n\nDjou had opposed  in 2009, a bill to legalize s for same-sex and opposite-sex couples, and supported the federal . He stated that lawmakers \"ignored the will of the people\" who enacted  in 1998.\n\nDjou was one of a handful of Congressional Republicans who voted in favor of an amendment to the 2011 Department of Defense Authorization Bill that would repeal the \"\" law and allow gay people to serve in the U.S. military.\n\n\nDjou supported comprehensive immigration reform and was one of eight Republicans who voted for the  to allow immigrants brought to the U.S. as children earn citizenship through service in the military or obtaining a college education and a job.\n\n\nOn May 28, 2010, Djou spoke on the floor of the House in support of approving the , which was signed by former president  on June 30, 2007. Congress approved the agreement on October 11, 2011.\n\n\n\nDjou ran for a full term in November 2010. There was some controversy over the use of ing by the Congressman's official U.S. House office, both before the election and afterward, but as with all official mass communication between members of the House and their constituents, the phone survey conducted on behalf of Djou's office was approved by the bipartisan Franking Commission as an appropriate use of official resources for the purpose of communicating with constituents.\n\nDjou was defeated by the Democratic nominee, State Senate President , 53% to 47%. Djou was one of only two Republican incumbents to lose a general election in 2010, along with  in Louisiana.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDjou announced on August 17, 2011, that he would challenge Hanabusa in the 1st district in 2012. A major in the U.S. Army Reserve, Djou suspended his campaign for six months while deployed to  with the 3rd Brigade Combat Team, , from September 2011 to March 2012. Djou lost to Hanabusa in the general election, with 45.4% of the vote.\n\n\n\nDjou ran for the 1st district again in 2014. Although he garnered a greater percentage of the vote in a general election than any other Republican running for Congress in Hawaii since 1988, he still narrowly lost to Democratic state representative , who received 51.2% of the vote.\n\n\n\nDjou announced on June 7, 2016 that he was running for the nonpartisan office of  against incumbent Mayor , former Mayor , and at least ten others. In the nonpartisan race, Djou had already received the endorsement of former governor , an anti-rail Democrat. On June 15, Djou announced that retired Federal Judge and former Chair of the Democratic Party of Hawaii, , would chair Djou's campaign, and City Council member , also a Democrat, supported Djou for mayor. With no candidate receiving more than 50% of the vote on August 13, 2016, a decision between the top two candidates, Djou and Caldwell, would be made in the November 8, 2016 election.\n\nCaldwell defeated Djou, 52% to 48%. Though both candidates supported the municipal rail project, its cost overruns were an issue, as well as Caldwell's alleged interference with the Ethics Commission. Labor group support was split between the pair.\n\n\n\nDjou served as the Hawaii state campaign chair of 's 2016 presidential campaign and urged voters before the 2016 Hawaii caucuses to reject . In 2018, Djou left the Republican Party, citing concerns with its policies and President Trump's character. In October 2019, Djou said, \"It would be fair to say that I'm an independent Democratic\". On July 9, 2020,  released a video in which Djou urged voters to vote against Trump.\n\n\nDjou is a member of the ReFormers Caucus of .\n\nOn March 9, 2020, Djou published an op-ed article in ''Honolulu Civil Beat'' announcing that he would not enter the , though he has accused Honolulu politicians of incompetence in handling important issues. Djou wrote, \"while it is clear to all that Honolulu is in desperate need of dramatic change and real leadership, I have come to the difficult decision that I am not the best person to lead this charge in the 2020 election.\" He said he might endorse a candidate but had not yet made a decision.\n\nIn addition to his decision not to run for mayor of Honolulu, Djou announced he was selected to serve in the  to complete a graduate degree in Strategic Studies. With his decision to set politics aside, Djou wrote, \"completing War College will better position me to assume more significant future roles and duties in service to our country. And unfortunately, running for public office this fall would conflict with this military assignment.\"\n\nIn 2020, Djou endorsed Democrat  for President alongside 26 other former Republican members of Congress. In May 2022, President Biden appointed Djou to be secretary of the . In August 2024, Djou wrote an op-ed for  praising  Democratic vice-presidential nominee .\n\n\n\nDjou is married to Stacey Kawasaki Djou, a . They have three children. His surname is a  transliteration of the Chinese surname . This originates from his grandfather's work at a French engineering company in Shanghai in the 1920s, where he was referred to as \"Dijou\", a name he later wrote on his immigration papers.\n\nDjou was on the board of directors of the  and a member of the Neighborhood Board. He is a member of the Young Business Roundtable, the , and the Hawaii Telecommunications Association.\n\nSince 2010, Djou has contributed op-ed articles as a writer for , a local nonprofit journalism website. \n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Charles Edwin Collins'''  (16 January 1929 &ndash; 16 September 2012) was an  politician and activist. He was an  candidate for  in the  and sought unsuccessfully to run again in .\n\n\nIn 1986, Collins, who was a former  school board official, challenged the use of '''' and other books at the Mowat Junior High School his granddaughter attended.  He wrote letters to the parents of all the students, and placed an advertisement in the ''''.  At a school board meeting Collins submitted what he claimed was about 9,000 signatures petitioning the use of the book, though a television reporter later found the number to be 3,549.\n\nThe case's first national coverage came from '''', which in the cover story of the Sunday magazine section reported on the case and the death threats that had been received by the teachers and parents defending the book and by the television reporter, Hill.  Hill's apartment was attacked by arson and a bomb threat placed on her car required the summoning of a police bomb squad, though the device proved to be a fake one.  Commenting on the attacks, Collins dismissed the dummy bomb as a \"joke\" and the fire as \"a good way to get your apartment painted by the landlord.\"\n\n\n'''' magazine called Collins the \"consummate  candidate,\" and opined that he appealed to an online population of \"isolationists, alarmists, and conspiracy theorists.\"  His campaign advocated abolishing the  and the  and other pledges noted to be similar to that of the U.S. Taxpayers Party ticket of  and .\n\nHe initially sought the  nomination, qualifying for and receiving some votes in the Republican .  He received a mere forty-two votes in the  primary and still fell far behind the other candidates in other states where he did better; e.g. 628 votes in  and 451 in   Collins withdrew from the  primary after the ballots were printed.  The  barred him from debates.\n\nCollins also sought, and failed to receive, the nomination of the .  Collins then decided to run as an independent, receiving the endorsement of a group called C.U.R.E. led by the former Republican governor of Arizona .  C.U.R.E. endorsed Collins over other potential choices including former  State Assemblyman and State Senator , who would later be the presidential candidate of the  in the  and John Yiamouyiannas, formerly a candidate of Take Back America who had received 2,199 votes in the .\n\nOn August 21, 1996, Collins attempted to have the  declare all  to be .  They declined his motion.\n\nContinuing to run as an independent candidate, Collins chose as his  running mate Rosemary Giumarra of .  Collins and Giumarra received 8,952 votes in the election.\n\n\n\nIn 2000, Collins attempted to win the nomination of the .  He fell far behind the frontrunner  in the party's important  primary with 295 votes versus 2,214, though he beat . In California, Collins fell in last place with 1,681 votes.  He thereafter attempted to win the party's nomination for vice president.  The convention split into two factions: Buchanan and Hagelin. In the Buchanan convention, Collins received 23 votes versus the winner of the nomination .\n\n\nCollins died in , on September 16, 2012, at the age of 83.\n\n\n\n\n\n* https://web.archive.org/web/20101028101426/http://www.politics1.com/reform.htm\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n*  citing .\n* : \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n* \"Charles E. Collins for President,\" The Gordon Hall and Grace Hoag Collection of Dissenting and Extremist Printed Propaganda, . OCLC 46319142.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Chase Iron Eyes''' (born March 6, 1978) is a  activist, attorney, politician, and a member of the . He is a member of the Lakota People's Law Project and a co-founder of the Native American news website ''Last Real Indians''. In April 2016 he announced his candidacy for the  for . He lost to incumbent .\n\n\nIron Eyes graduated from the  with a bachelor's degree in political science and Native American studies. In 2007, he graduated from the , with a  in law (with an emphasis in Federal Indian law). Iron Eyes was also the president of the Native American Law Student Association during his academic career in law school. Iron Eyes is licensed to practice law within the state of  as well as in the federal courts of both  and South Dakota in addition to several .\n\nIn July 2012, Iron Eyes filed a  in federal court on behalf of Vern Traversie, a  69-year-old  man, against a South Dakota hospital. The lawsuit alleged a violation of Traversie's , citing scars that Traversie said were from doctors carving the initials of the  into his abdomen during heart surgery. The hospital stated the marks were a reaction to surgical tape, and in 2015, a jury ruled against Traversie.\n\n\n, pictured here, that is sacred to the Lakota.]]\n\nIron Eyes has used his career as an attorney to advocate for . He has served as a staff attorney for the Lakota People's Law Project (LPLP), an initiative founded in 2005 with the purpose of ending the unlawful practice of removing Lakota children from their families and placing them in foster care outside their communities. In the summer of 2016, Iron Eyes and other representatives of LPLP joined with other anti-pipeline protestors near Standing Rock to resist the Dakota Access pipeline.\n\nIron Eyes has actively engaged in the  protection of sacred sites. He was instrumental in raising awareness of Pe' Sla, a high mountain prairie situated within the heart of the Black Hills, a sacred site related to Lakota creation beliefs where annual ceremonies, village gatherings, and other traditional activities took place, located north of Deerfield Lake and west of . This is the area where renowned  visionary  sought his vision. Another of the sacred sites Iron Eyes has drawn attention to is .\n\nHe is also a member of the Bush Foundation's Native Nation Rebuilders program, a leadership development program designed to foster innovative tribal governance practices to effect positive change. He has continued to voice opposition against the drilling of  within the area.\n\nIn 2016, Iron Eyes announced his candidacy as a member of the  for the election to represent  in the . Speaking to '''' in April, he said, \"I'm running for Congress out of necessity [...] I see that our government is broken, and I  feel responsible to do my part to try and fix this on behalf of North Dakota\", as reported by ''''.\n\n\nIron Eyes was raised on the , and since then has lived in a multitude of places.\n\nChase is an enrolled member of the Oglala Sioux Tribe.\n\nOn June 8, 2022, Iron Eyes and his wife, Dr. Sara Jumping Eagle, filed legal documents asking a judge to issue court protection against  on behalf of their 18-year-old daughter, , due to Miller allegedly using \"violence, intimidation, threat of violence, fear, paranoia, delusions, and drugs [including  and ]\" to hold sway over her. Their \"friendship\", which began in 2016 when Miller was 23 and Tokata Iron Eyes was 12, also included Tokata Iron Eyes flying to  the following year to visit Miller on the set of  and dropping out of school in 2021 to follow Miller. Iron Eyes and Dr. Jumping Eagle also alleged in their documents that their daughter had taken bruises from Miller and that Miller had misgendered her. Tokata Iron Eyes responded by denying her parents' allegations and saying that she was mentally stable and was in contact with a mental health professional.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Christina Tobin''' (born June 17, 1981) is an   and leader in the election reform and voters' rights movements. She is the founder and chair of The , and president and chief executive officer of Free and Equal, Inc.\n\n\nTobin was born in , in 1981. She grew up in  and  and graduated from  in . She attended  in  where she served as varsity tennis captain and volunteered for . In 2004, she earned a bachelor's degree in graphic design with a minor in .\n\n\nTobin started her career as a   coordinator. An expert in defending signatures and coordinating petition drives, Tobin has helped gather and defend over one&nbsp;million signatures for s, the , Foes try to knock Green Party off ballot in 14th Congressional District|newspaper=Daily Herald|date=21 November 2009|publisher=dailyherald.com|accessdate=18 January 2014}} the , the , the , the  and the .\n\n\n\nIn 2008, Tobin founded the Free & Equal Elections Foundation, More Voices, More Choices|publisher=freeandequal.org|accessdate=18 January 2014|archive-date=28 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171128022552/http://www.freeandequal.org/|url-status=dead}} a  , non-partisan  organization, whose mission is to empower American voters through education.\n\nFree & Equal hosts open gubernatorial, Presidential and senatorial debates, including the 2008, 2012, 2016, 2020 and 2024 Presidential debates moderated by  winning journalist , broadcast legend ,  of , and  winning actor .\n\n\nIn the 1998 election for governor of Illinois, Tobin helped defend over 60,000 signatures for her father, Libertarian candidate . In 2002, she personally gathered over 5,000 signatures and successfully defended 55,000 signatures for Cal Skinner, who was running for governor, and her father, who was running for lieutenant governor representing the Libertarian Party.\n\nIn the 2004 presidential election, Tobin defended 29,000 signatures in Illinois for  when he ran as an independent. She also sued Democratic State Chair Michael Madigan alleging that he used his full-time state employees to have Nader removed from the Illinois ballot.\n\nFor the November 2006 election, she successfully defended 39,000 signatures for Rich Whitney, the Green Party candidate for Illinois governor.\n\n\nIn 2008, Tobin served as Ralph Nader's national ballot access coordinator. She helped collect more than 500,000 signatures to put  on the District of Columbia ballot and 45 state presidential ballots, more than any other  or independent candidate. While coordinating the national ballot drive in 50 states, Tobin organized a successful petition drive in Illinois, ,  and .\n\n\nIn 2008, Tobin filed a lawsuit against , alleging harassment of jewelry designers in  and improper copyrighting of a Balinese folk motif.\n\n\nIn March 2009, Tobin founded Free and Equal, Inc., a non-partisan, full-service ballot access consulting and petitioning firm that specializes in independent and third-party candidates. Tobin has helped gather and defend over one&nbsp;million signatures for s, the , the , the , the , the  and the . Free and Equal, Inc. does not endorse any candidates for office. She serves as president and chief executive officer.\n\n\nIn 2011, Tobin served as Vice President of , founded by her father . Her work exposed big pension payouts in Illinois and other states. On Air Videos  Fox News|date=May 2013 |publisher=video.foxnews.com|accessdate=18 January 2014}}\n\n\nTobin is a passionate activist against the top two primary systems. In 2012, she founded Stop Top Two, a movement designed to educate voters of the machinations behind the relatively new electoral trend. Louisiana, Washington and California elections are now controlled via top two primary systems. Arizona's version of a top two primary system, Proposition 121, was defeated by Arizona voters November 2012. The main objective of Tobin's Stop Top Two movement was to defeat the proposition through education, media outreach and panel discussions, including the \"Problems with Arizona's Top Two Primary System – Proposition 121\" panel presented by the Free & Equal Elections Foundation at the Goldwater Institute on October 9, 2012.\n\n\nIn 2010, Tobin ran as a  candidate for the . She formally announced her candidacy for Secretary of State on February 23, 2010. She was the only candidate seeking the Libertarian Party nomination. , editor and publisher of '''' was her campaign manager.\n\nIn the general election, Tobin came in fourth with 214,347 votes, 2.3 percent of the total votes cast.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Christopher S. Porrino''' (born October 20, 1967) is an American trial lawyer who served as the  from 2016 to 2018. Porrino is currently a partner of Lowenstein Sandler, and chair of the firm's Litigation Department.\n\nPorrino was born in Teaneck and raised in Fort Lee and Englewood Cliffs. He resides in , with his wife, Christina, and their two children., , January 31, 2012. Accessed June 18, 2016.\n\n\nPorrino graduated from  and received his  degree from . He is admitted to the bars of the State of New Jersey and the State of New York, and is admitted to practice in the , the , and the .\n\n\nPorrino began his legal career as a law clerk (1992-1993) for then-Magistrate Judge , U.S. District Judge for the District of New Jersey. He then worked as an associate attorney at Greenbaum, Rowe, Smith & Davis from 1993 to 2004. Porrino joined  as a partner in 2004, and served as vice chair of the firm's litigation department, focusing his practice on criminal and civil trials.\n\nIn 2012, Porrino left private practice for public service. He held a variety of positions at the State of New Jersey, including Director of the Division of Law from 2012 to 2014, Chief Counsel to  from 2014 to 2015, and as the state's Attorney General from 2016 to 2018.\n\nAfter serving as the 60th Attorney General of New Jersey, Porrino returned to  in 2018 as a partner and chair of the firm's litigation department. He is a crisis manager, having represented numerous private and public companies and individuals in alleged scandals, including Governor Christie during the , and currently represents individuals and businesses of all sizes in civil, criminal, and regulatory matters involving securities, consumer fraud, banking, insurance, tax, antitrust, real estate, and the environment. He also regularly conducts internal investigations for clients faced with allegations of wrongdoing by insiders.\n\nApproximately ten months after completing his term as Attorney General in a Republican administration, Porrino was hired by New Jersey Governor  (D) in October 2018 to represent his office in connection with an anticipated legislative inquiry  of Murphy and his administration. The state legislative panel was to be tasked with looking into certain hiring practices and an alleged sexual assault that occurred during the governor's campaign. The announcement of Porrino's hiring by the Murphy administration was applauded by legislative leaders who were driving the inquiry (\"Sweeney, Coughlin have no problems with Porrino,\" New Jersey Globe, October 22, 2018).\n\n\nPorrino served as Director of the  in the Attorney General's Office from February 2012 to January 2014, overseeing a team of 800 state employees, 500 of whom were lawyers.\n\nPorrino argued the landmark Harvey Cedars “dunes” case, before the . The decision in 2013 paved the way for the state's shore protection and the dune construction projects that followed.\n\nFrom January 2014 through July 2015, Porrino served as Chief Counsel to the . On his first day as Chief Counsel, the , known as \"Bridgegate\", broke in the news media. As Chief Counsel, Porrino navigated the Governor's Office through that crisis and the myriad legal issues that followed.  In that role, he also had broad responsibility overseeing appointments, legislative matters, and all state authorities.\n\nPorrino worked closely with Governor Christie and members of the  to secure the passage of numerous pieces of critical legislation, including the Criminal Justice Reform Act (i.e., bail reform).\n\nHe was involved in the state's controversial .\n\n\n\nIn June 2016, Porrino was nominated by the ,  to be the , and served as Acting Attorney General until unanimously confirmed by the  on August 1, 2016.\n\nUnder his leadership, the Attorney General's Office created and enacted what was then the strictest prescribing rules in the country aimed at curtailing the over-dispensing of highly addictive pain medication, and proposed regulations to prevent prescribing physicians from being influenced by gifts and other rewards from pharmaceutical companies. He targeted “pill mills” and professionals engaged in indiscriminate prescribing, resulting in more civil and criminal charges filed against medical professionals during his term than during any comparable period in the history of the department. He oversaw the expansion of the state's  (PMP), including the implementation of mandatory PMP look-ups by prescribers and interconnectivity with PMPs from a number of other states.\n\nPorrino oversaw the implementation of bail reform in New Jersey. Using a validated risk assessment tool, dangerous and high-risk defendants are now held in custody and can no longer “buy” their way out of jail pending trial.\n\nPorrino targeted violent , including gun violence, taking almost 5,000 guns out of circulation over a single weekend. He also led a multi-department cooperative effort to address critical public safety issues in .\n\nTo help identify potential cases of corruption, Porrino's office launched an Anti-Corruption Whistleblower Program. Among other examples, the office indicted and convicted Mayor Jose “Joey” Torres of the City of Paterson and three city employees on corruption charges.\n\nTo combat elder abuse, Porrino's office became the country's first to loan hidden cameras to citizens who suspected that their elders were being abused. The “Safe Care Cam Program” gives participants the opportunity to covertly observe the care being given to their loved ones.\n\nIn 2016, on the child protection front, Porrino drafted legislation that strengthened child protection statutes and increased penalties for those engaged in child pornography in New Jersey. The department investigated and prosecuted persons who violated the child protection laws, including “Operation Statewide,” a statewide sweep that resulted in the arrest of forty men on charges of child pornography, and “Operation Safety Net” that resulted in the arrest of another seventy-nine men on child exploitation charges.\n\nTo combat distracted driving, Porrino spearheaded a campaign to encourage the public to report distracted driving violations through the state's #77 hotline in response to the burgeoning numbers of distracted drivers. The New Jersey State Police sent warning letters to those reported to inform motorists that their vehicles have been spotted being driven dangerously or by a distracted driver and warning them of the penalties if caught by the police.\n\nIn the civil rights area, the department prosecuted numerous acts of discrimination.  In a case that received national attention, Porrino led a civil rights action against the Township of Mahwah wherein it was alleged that local officials engaged in a pattern of discrimination to exclude Orthodox Jews. \n \nIn the area of juvenile justice, he led the planned closure of a Civil War-era youth prison as part of other important reforms of the state's juvenile justice system.\n\nIn the area of community policing, Porrino and the department implemented the first statewide community policing grant program, named in honor of fallen police officer Matthew Tarentino. The department designed and mandated the first-ever statewide continuing education curriculum to train police on de-escalation, cultural awareness, and implicit bias.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
