    "pages": }\n\n'''James Vincent Forrestal''' (February 15, 1892&nbsp;– May 22, 1949) was the last -level  and the first .\n\nForrestal came from a very strict middle-class Irish Catholic family. He was a successful financier on Wall Street before becoming Undersecretary of the Navy in 1940, shortly before the United States entered the . He became Secretary of the Navy in May 1944 upon the death of his superior,  . President  requested that Forrestal take the lead in building up the Navy. In 1947, after the end of the war, President  appointed him the first secretary of the newly created Department of Defense. Forrestal was intensely hostile to the Soviet Union, fearing Communist expansion in Europe and the Middle East. Along with Secretary of State , he strongly opposed the United States' support for the establishment of the , fearing that this would alienate Arab nations which were needed as allies, and whose petroleum reserves were vital for both military and civilian industrial expansion.\n\nForrestal was a supporter of naval  centered on s. He tried to weaken the proposed Department of Defense for the Navy's benefit, but was hard-pressed to run it from 1947 to 1949 after Truman named him Secretary of Defense. The two men were often at odds, and Truman forced Forrestal's resignation.\n\nThereafter, Forrestal's mental health rapidly deteriorated, declining to the point in which he underwent medical care for depression. While a patient at , Forrestal died by suicide from fatal injuries sustained after falling out of a sixteenth-floor window.\n\nIn 1954, the USN's new  was named  in his honor, as is the , which houses the headquarters of the . He is the namesake of the Forrestal Lecture Series at the  and of the  of his alma mater .\n\n\n\n\nForrestal was born in ,  (now part of ), the youngest son of James Forrestal, an  immigrant who dabbled in politics. His mother, the former Mary Anne Toohey (herself the daughter of another Irish immigrant) raised him as a devout . During his youth, Forrestal was an amateur boxer.\"James Vincent Forrestal\". '''', Supplement 4: 1946–50. , 1974. Reproduced in Biography Resource Center. : , 2009.  After graduating from high school in 1908, at the age of 16, he spent the next three years working for a trio of newspapers: the ''Matteawan Evening Journal'', the ''Mount Vernon Argus'' and the '' News Press''.\n\nForrestal entered  in 1911, but transferred to  in his sophomore year, where he served as an editor for ''''. His senior class voted him \"Most Likely to Succeed\", but he left just prior to completing work on a degree. Forrestal was a member of  while he was a student at Princeton. Forrestal married the former Josephine Stovall (née Ogden), a '''' writer, in 1926. She eventually developed a dependence on alcohol and suffered various mental health issues.\n\n\nForrestal went to work as a bond salesman for William A. Read and Company (later renamed ) in 1916. When the US entered , he enlisted in the Navy and ultimately became a , training with the  at  and  in Canada. During the final year of the war Forrestal spent much of his time in Washington, at the Office of Naval Operations, while completing his flight training and reaching the rank of lieutenant. After the war, Forrestal resumed his career in finance and made his fortune on Wall Street. He became a partner in 1923, was appointed vice president in 1926, and by 1937 was president of the company. He also acted as a publicist for the  committee in , helping politicians from the area win elections at both the local and state level. One of the individuals aided by his work was a neighbor, .\n\nForrestal was a compulsive  and skilled administrator. He was described as pugnacious, introspective, shy, philosophic, solitary, and . He took no part in national politics, though he usually voted for Democrats, but did not support  liberalism.\n\n\n\n\n,  on May 19, 1944. , , stands to the right.]]\nPresident Franklin D. Roosevelt appointed Forrestal a  on June 22, 1940. Six weeks later, he nominated him for the newly established position, Undersecretary of the Navy. In his nearly four years as undersecretary, Forrestal proved highly effective at mobilizing domestic  for the war effort. The ,  , wanted to control logistics and procurement, but Forrestal prevailed.\n\nIn September 1942, to get a grasp on the reports for materiel his office was receiving, he made a tour of naval operations in the  and a stop at . Returning to Washington, D.C., he made his report to Roosevelt,  , and the cabinet. In response to Forrestal's elevated request that materiel be sent immediately to the Southwest Pacific area, Stimson (who was more concerned with supplying  in North Africa), told Forrestal, \"Jim, you've got a bad case of .\" Forrestal shot back in a heated manner, \"Mr. Secretary, if the Marines on  were wiped out, the reaction of the country will give you a bad case of localitis in the seat of your pants.\"\n\nHe became  on May 19, 1944, after his immediate superior, Secretary , died from a heart attack. Knox had been a figurehead as secretary and Forrestal was highly energetic. Forrestal led the Navy through the closing year of the war and the early years of  that followed. Forrestal ordered that a  be convened to investigate the facts surrounding the Japanese  and to assess any culpability borne by members of the Navy. The Court consisted of Admiral Adolphus Andrews; Admiral , who served as President of the Court and Admiral .\n\n for a Cabinet meeting, ]]\n\nThe court convened on July 24, 1944, and held daily sessions in Washington, D.C., San Francisco and Pearl Harbor. After interviewing numerous witnesses, it completed its work on October 19, 1944. Its report to the Navy Department largely exonerated Rear Admiral , commander in chief of the  at the time of the attack. The court found that Kimmel's decisions had been correct given the limited information available to him, but criticized then-Chief of Naval Operations  for failing to warn Kimmel that war was imminent. The court concluded that \"based upon the facts established, the Court is of the opinion that no offenses have been committed nor serious blame incurred on the part of any person or persons in the naval service.\" Because the court's findings implicitly revealed that  had broken the Japanese codes, a critical wartime secret, the court's report was not made public until after the end of the war.\n\nUpon reviewing the report, Forrestal felt that the court had been too lenient in assigning blame for the disaster. The court had found that the Army and Navy had adequately cooperated in the defense of Pearl Harbor; that there had been no information indicating that Japanese carriers were on their way to attack Pearl Harbor; and that the attack had succeeded principally because of the , a secret weapon whose use could not have been predicted. Forrestal disapproved all of these findings, judging that Kimmel could have done more with the information he had had to prevent or mitigate the attack. Forrestal concluded that both Kimmel and Stark had \"failed to demonstrate the superior judgment necessary for exercising command commensurate with their rank and their assigned duties.\"\n\n with a Gold Star in lieu of a third  on May 21, 1946]]\n\nAs Secretary, Forrestal introduced a policy of  in the Navy. Forrestal traveled to combat zones to see naval forces in action. He was in the South Pacific in 1942, present at the  in 1944, and (as Secretary) witnessed the  in 1945. After five days of pitched battle, a detachment of Marines was sent to hoist the American flag on the 545-foot summit of Mount Suribachi on Iwo Jima. This was the first time in the war that the U.S. flag had flown on Japanese soil. Forrestal, who had just landed on the beach, claimed the historic flag as a souvenir. When Forrestal witnessed the sight of the  atop Mount Suribachi, he turned to Major General  and said, \"the raising of that flag on Suribachi means a Marine Corps for the next 500 years.\" A second, larger flag was run up in its place, and this second flag-raising was the moment captured by Associated Press photographer  in his .\n\nIn the early months of 1945, Forrestal, along with Stimson and Under Secretary of State , strongly advocated a softer policy toward Japan that would permit a negotiated armistice, a face-saving surrender. Forrestal's primary concern was not the resurgence of a militarized Japan, but rather \"the menace of Russian  and its attraction for decimated, destabilized societies in Europe and Asia,\" and, therefore, keeping the  out of the war with Japan.Hoopes and Brinkley, pp. 205–214. The quoted line is from p. 208 So strongly did he feel about this matter that he cultivated negotiation efforts that some regarded as approaching insubordination.\n\n\n\nHis counsel on ending the war was finally followed, but not until the atomic bombs had been dropped on . On 10 August 1945, the day after the Nagasaki attack, the Japanese sent out a radio transmission saying that it was ready to accept the terms of the ' , \"with the understanding that said declaration does not comprise any demand which prejudices the prerogatives of  as a sovereign ruler.\" That position still fell short of the U.S. \"unconditional surrender\" demand, retaining the sticking point that had held up the war's conclusion for months. Strong voices within the administration, including  , counseled fighting on. At that point, \"Forrestal came up with a shrewd and simple solution: Accept the offer and declare that it accomplishes what the Potsdam Declaration demanded. Say that the Emperor and the Japanese government will rule subject to the orders of the Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers. This would imply recognition of the Emperor while tending to neutralize American public passions against the Emperor. President  liked this. It would be close enough to 'unconditional'.\"\n\nAfter the war, Forrestal urged Truman to take a hard line with the Soviets over Poland and other issues. In furtherance of the anti-Soviet position, he was the primary promoter of the famous \"\" by State Department official . \"[Averell] Harriman thought Forrestal's reaction [to the Kennan document] was a 'decisive' catalyst in shaping American opinion on the issue.\" He also strongly influenced the new Wisconsin Senator, , concerning infiltration of the government by Communists. Upon McCarthy's arrival in Washington in December 1946, Forrestal invited him to lunch. In McCarthy's words, \"Before meeting Jim Forrestal I thought we were losing to international Communism because of incompetence and stupidity on the part of our planners. I mentioned that to Forrestal. I shall forever remember his answer. He said, 'McCarthy, consistency has never been a mark of stupidity. If they were merely stupid, they would occasionally make a mistake in our favor.' This phrase struck me so forcefully that I have often used it since.\"\n\n\n\n in Washington, D.C.]]\nIn 1947, Truman appointed him the first . Forrestal continued to advocate for complete racial integration of the , a policy eventually implemented in 1949.\n\nDuring private cabinet meetings with Truman in 1946 and 1947, Forrestal had argued against  on the grounds it would infuriate  who supplied oil needed for the  and national defense. Instead, Forrestal favored a federalization plan for Palestine. Outside the White House, response to Truman's continued silence on the issue was immediate. Truman received threats to cut off  from wealthy donors, as well as , including a letter accusing him of \"preferring  and Arab elements to the democracy-loving  of Palestine.\" Appalled by the intensity and implied threats over the partition question, Forrestal appealed to Truman in two separate cabinet meetings not to base his decision on partition, whatever the outcome, on the basis of political pressure. In his only known public comment on the issue, Forrestal stated to ,  from :\n\n...no group in this country should be permitted to influence our policy to the point it could endanger our national security.\n\nForrestal's statement soon earned him the active enmity of some congressmen and supporters of . He was also an early target of the  columnist and broadcaster , an opponent of  hostile to the Soviet Union, who began to regularly call for Forrestal's removal after Truman named him Secretary of Defense., ''Washington Head-Hunters'', New York: Time Publications, 24 January 1949 Pearson told his own , , that he believed Forrestal was \"the most dangerous man in America\" and claimed that if he was not removed from office, he would \"cause another world war\".\n\nUpon taking office as Secretary of Defense, Forrestal was surprised to learn that the administration did not  needs based on military threats posed by enemies of the United States and its interests. According to historian , Truman was known to approach defense budgetary requests in the abstract, without regard to defense response requirements in the event of conflicts with potential enemies. The president would begin by subtracting from total receipts the amount needed for domestic needs and recurrent operating costs, with any surplus going to the defense budget for that year. The Truman administration's willingness to slash conventional readiness needs for the Navy and Marine Corps soon caused fierce controversies within the upper ranks of their respective branches.Blair, Clay, ''The Forgotten War: America in Korea, 1950–1953'', Naval Institute Press (2003)\n\nDuring the Reagan years,  reflected upon the qualities which made a Secretary of Defense great: the ability to work with Congress, the ability for \"big-time management,\" and an ability at war planning. Nitze felt that Forrestal was the only one who possessed all three qualities together.\n\n\nAt the close of World War II, millions of dollars of serviceable equipment had been scrapped or abandoned rather than having funds appropriated for its storage costs. New military equipment ''en route'' to operations in the Pacific theater was scrapped or simply tossed overboard. Facing the wholesale demobilization of most of the US defense force structure, Forrestal resisted Truman's efforts to substantially reduce defense appropriations, but was unable to prevent a steady reduction in defense spending, resulting in major cuts not only in defense equipment stockpiles, but also in military readiness.\n\nBy 1948, Truman had approved military budgets billions of dollars below what the services were requesting, putting Forrestal in the middle of a fierce tug-of-war between the President and the . Forrestal was also becoming increasingly worried about the Soviet threat.See  to confirm that his concerns on the domestic front were quite legitimate His 18 months at Defense came at an exceptionally difficult time for the U.S. military establishment: Communist governments came to power in  and China; the Soviets imposed a  on  prompting the U.S.  to supply the city; the  followed the establishment of Israel; and negotiations were going on for the formation of .\n\n recorded he was in agreement with Forrestal's theories on the dangers of Soviet and International communist expansion. Eisenhower recalled that Forrestal had been \"the one man who, in the very midst of the war, always counseled caution and alertness in dealing with the Soviets.\" Eisenhower remembered on several occasions, while he was , he had been visited by Forrestal, who carefully explained his thesis that the Communists would never cease trying to destroy all . Eisenhower commented in his personal diary on 11 June 1949, \"I never had cause to doubt the accuracy of his judgments on this point.\"\n\nForrestal also opposed the unification of the military services proposed by the Truman officials. Even so, he helped develop the  that created the  (the  was not created as such until August 1949). With the former Secretary of War  retiring to private life, Forrestal was the next choice.\n\n downplays Forrestal's achievements:\n:Forrestal was not in FDR's inner circle, was not apprised of the Manhattan Project, and did not attend the major wartime conferences....Forrestal also ended up on the wrong side of the struggle to unify the armed forces....He slowed but did not stop the unification process as secretary of the navy and then had to live with legislation that prevented him from managing the military establishment efficiently as the country's first secretary of defense. In that capacity, however, Forrestal was unable to devise an integrated defense budget, work out a joint war plan, or compel the Joint Chiefs of Staff to accept presidential directives they did not like.\n\n\n  was expected to win the . Forrestal met with Dewey privately, and it was agreed he would continue as Secretary of Defense under a Dewey administration. Unwittingly, Forrestal would trigger a series of events that would not only undermine his already precarious position with Truman but also contribute to the loss of his job, his failing health and eventual demise. Weeks before the election, Pearson published an exposé of the meetings between Dewey and Forrestal.\nIn 1949, angered over Forrestal's continued opposition to his defense economization policies, and concerned about reports in the press over his mental condition, Truman abruptly asked Forrestal to resign. By March 31, 1949, Forrestal was out of a job. He was replaced by , an ardent supporter of Truman's defense retrenchment policy.\n\n\nIn 1949, exhausted from overwork, Forrestal entered psychiatric treatment. The attending psychiatrist,  George N. Raines, was handpicked by the . The  was as follows:\n# 1st week:  with .\n# 2nd – 5th weeks: a regimen of  combined with psycho-therapeutic interviews. According to Raines, the patient overreacted to the insulin much as he had to the amytal and this would occasionally throw him into a confused state with a great deal of agitation and confusion.\n# 4th week: insulin administered only in stimulating doses; 10 units of insulin four times a day, morning, noon, afternoon and evening.\n\nAccording to Raines, \"We considered  but thought it better to postpone it for another 90 days. In reactive depression if electro-shock is used early and the patient is returned to the same situation from which he came there is grave danger of suicide in the immediate period after they return... so strangely enough we left out electro-shock to avoid what actually happened anyhow.\"\n\n\nAlthough Forrestal told associates he had decided to resign, he was reportedly shattered when Truman abruptly asked for his resignation. His letter of resignation was tendered on March 28, 1949, and his condition steadily deteriorated.Hoopes and Brinkley, pp. 446–468. On the day of Forrestal's resignation from office, he was reported to have gone into a daze and was flown on a Navy airplane to the estate of Under Secretary of State  in , where Forrestal's wife, Josephine, was vacationing.  of the  in Kansas was consulted and he diagnosed \"severe depression\" of the type \"seen in  during the war\". The Menninger Clinic had successfully treated similar cases during the war, but Forrestal's wife, his friend and associate , Menninger, and Navy psychiatrist Captain George N. Raines decided to send the patient to the  (NNMC) in . He was checked into NNMC five days later. The decision to house him on the 16th floor instead of the first floor was justified in the same way. Forrestal's condition was officially announced as \"nervous and physical exhaustion\"; his lead doctor, Captain Raines, diagnosed his condition as \"depression\" or \"reactive depression\". As a person who prized anonymity and once stated that his hobby was \"obscurity\", Forrestal, with his policies, had been the constant target of vicious personal attacks from columnists, including  and . Pearson's protégé, , later asserted that Pearson \"hectored Forrestal with innuendos and false accusations\".\n\n]]\n\nForrestal seemed to be on the road to recovery, having regained  since his admission into the hospital. However, in the early morning hours of May 22, his body, clad only in the bottom half of a pair of pajamas, was found on a third-floor roof below the sixteenth-floor kitchen across the hall from his room. Forrestal's alleged last written statement, touted in the contemporary press and later biographers as an implied suicide note, was part of a poem from  translation of ' tragedy '''':\n\nFair , the billows' roar,\nWander around thee yet,\nAnd sailors gaze upon thy shore\nFirm in the Ocean set.\nThy son is in a foreign clime\nWhere  feeds her countless flocks,\nFar from thy dear, remembered rocks,\nWorn by the waste of time–\nComfortless, nameless, hopeless save\nIn the dark prospect of the yawning grave....\nWoe to the mother in her close of day,\nWoe to her desolate heart and temples gray,\nWhen she shall hear\nHer loved one's story whispered in her ear!\n\"Woe, woe!\" will be the cry–\nNo quiet murmur like the tremulous wail\nOf the lone bird, the querulous –\n\n\n\nThe official Navy review board, which completed hearings on May 31, waited until October 11, 1949, to release only a brief summary of its findings. The announcement, as reported on page 15 of the October 12 '''', stated only that Forrestal had died from his fall from the window. It did not say what might have caused the fall, nor did it make any mention of a bathrobe sash cord that had first been reported as tied around his neck. The full report was released by the Department of the Navy in April 2004.\n\n\nHe was buried at , in .\n\n\nForrestal's diaries from 1944 to March 1949 were serialised in the '''' in 1951, and published as a 581-page book ''The Forrestal Diaries'', edited by  in October 1951. They were censored prior to publication.  published a  of the complete and unexpurgated diaries in 2001, from the originals preserved in the , ; a digital edition was released in January 2020. An example of censorship is the removal of the following account of a conversation with Truman: \"He [the President] referred to Hitler as an egomaniac. The result is we shall have a  Europe for a long time to come. I don't think it is so bad.\"\n\n\nBiographer Arnold Rogow explores the pathos and tragedy of Forrestal's tormented life. He was brought up in a rigidly Catholic environment where harsh discipline gave the boy doubts about himself that were never overcome by his many achievements. He compensated by emphasizing toughness in terms of physicality and morality – he had no use for slackers or cowards. He felt war was a necessity and that negotiation was possible only alongside military parity or superiority. This intensity alienated his colleagues, as he focused his fears on Communists and Zionists. He abandoned his religion and his Irish community, but was never at ease on Wall Street, where he suspected and envied its rich and well-born . Although his brilliance and energy made him a favorite of President Roosevelt, he profoundly distrusted liberalism and never championed the New Deal.\n\n\nForrestal was awarded both the  and the  by President Truman.\n\n\n\nThe  in Washington, D.C., completed in 1969, is named for him.\n\nThe J.&nbsp;V. Forrestal Elementary School at 125 Liberty Street in , his hometown, is named for him. Forrestal Elementary School in the Great Lakes military housing area is named for him.\n\nThe aircraft carrier , in commission 1955–1993, was named for him\n\n\nIn the 2002  TV movie '''', Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara (portrayed by Alec Baldwin) hauntingly recounts the story of James Forrestal's dismissal and suicide to speechwriter Richard Goodwin (portrayed by James Frain).\n\nIn the 2006 film '','' Forrestal was played by .\n\nThe story of James Forrestal is prominently featured in Chapter 4 of the  popular documentary series '','' which aired on Showtime in 2012–13.\n\nThe later part of Forrestal's life, including his marriage and his death, is a large part of ''Majic Man'' by .\n\nIn the anime OVA series '''', a secret document is briefly viewable in the eighth episode that mentions the death of a Secretary Forrestal. It goes on to say that a \"vacancy\" was left due to his death until he was replaced by an unnamed general.\n\n\nA number of works (shown below) have implied or indicated that Forrestal's death was suspicious or nefarious.\n\nIn December 1950,  published an article titled \"Untold Facts about the Death of James Forrestal\" in '''', which he co-owned. That article, later entered into the Congressional Record and republished, suggested Forrestal has been forced to resign amid pressure from \"disgruntled politicians, Communists, Zionists, and gossip columnists\".https://www.govinfo.gov/content/pkg/GPO-CRECB-1950-pt12/pdf/GPO-CRECB-1950-pt12-8-1.pdf , pg. 16179 Huie opined that \"Much of the truth has thus far been suppressed, but the ghost of Jim Forrestal is not going to be laid until there are reasonable answers to such questions as these: Why was the attack on Forrestal so reckless and sadistically savage? Why have his papers been held secret? Where is the report of those who investigated his death? Why was the deposed Defense Secretary held a virtual prisoner at Bethesda Naval Hospital – a prisoner who could not be visited by his own priest.\"\n\nIn 1954, journalist  published a piece listing Forrestal's death as part of a pattern of suspicious deaths of federal officials. In 1955, anti-Communist investigative journalist  claimed, without evidence, that the former Secretary had been murdered by Communists. In 1966, a book-length treatment of the conspiracy theory was published in the fringe press.Hoopes & Brinkley, p.544\n\nIn a statement posted to the Paranet BBS in December 1987,  claimed that Forrestal's suicide was connected to the \"horrible truth\" about aliens and their interactions with humanity, and implies that his medical records remain sealed as part of the coverup initiated by President Truman.\n\nIn 2017, on the final episode of the  miniseries '''', journalist  implies that Forrestal's death may have been one of a series of deaths labeled as suicides that were actually covert assassinations by the CIA.\n''The Assassination of James Forrestal'', a 2019 nonfiction book by David Martin, argues that Forrestal was killed.\n\n\nForrestal conspiracy theories have been featured in numerous works of fiction. In the 1994 television movie '''', Forrestal is portrayed by . He is depicted as sitting on a commission concerning the  and advocating the eventual release of information to the public. The film treats his death and classified diary as highly suspicious.\n\nAn opera concerning the conspiracy theories behind Forrestal's death, ''Nightingale: The Last Days of James Forrestal'' composed by  with a libretto by , premiered in New York City at the Present Company Theatorium on May 19, 2002.\n\nIn '''', a  '''' \"imaginary story\" four-issue prestige format  by  (writer) and  (artist), Forrestal's death is shown to have been a murder. Forrestal is pushed from the window of his Bethesda Naval Hospital room by the Golden Age .\n\nIn the PC game '''' one of the secret documents the player can collect talks about the  initiative being threatened with \"receiving the same punishment as his last secretary, Forrestal\", implying the murder of Forrestal was to cover his operation from the public. (Forrestal was allegedly a member of Majestic 12.)\n\nThe 2020 film '''' suggests that in 1949, Forrestal was preparing to make public proof of alien visitations and technology, and was forced by two  to choose between committing suicide or seeing his entire family killed. A title slide over the last shot of the movie says \"Dedicated to the Memory of James V. Forrestal (1892–1949), who understood the significance of the events and sought to act honorably amid treachery.\"\n\n\n* \n* , a CIA scientist who plummeted from a high building to his death in 1953\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* Akashah, Mary, and Donald Tennant. (1980). \" \" (PDF). ''Proceedings of the Oklahoma Academy of Science'' 60: 89–92. Retrieved on 2007-09-09.     "pages": }\n\n'''James W. Holley III''' (November 24, 1926 – October 5, 2012) was an American  and .  Holley became the first Black  of , and ultimately the city's longest serving mayor, although both his mayoral terms (separated by a decade) ended with his being  from office. Thus he became the only known politician in American history to be twice recalled until  Councilman Don Bankhead was recalled in June 2012.\n\n\nHolley was born in 1926. After graduating from Portsmouth's  in 1944, Holley served in the  during , stationed in  in . Following the war, he attended  (now West Virginia State University), and graduated with a  in 1949. From there he went to  where he attended dental school at the , graduating in 1955. He has also received an honorary law degree from West Virginia State. He attended college on the . During a reception in the late 1950s, Holley met  student Mary Walker; the couple would marry in 1960.\n\nHolley was active during the  in the 1950s and 1960s, and played an integral role in the desegregation of Portsmouth, winning court battles which allowed for the equal use of the city's libraries, hospitals, restaurants and golf courses. In 1961, he and fellow dentist Dr. Hugo Owens, then the president of the local NAACP, requested service at the public library but were turned down because of their race, which ultimately led to the combination of that library with the segregated black library. During the course of his involvement in the civil rights movement, Holley entertained  at his home on multiple occasions.\n\n\nHolley first served as a member of the Portsmouth  from 1968 to 1984, and was vice-mayor from 1978 to 1980. Upon his election in 1968, he became the first  to serve on Portsmouth's City Council. He has twice held the office of mayor, first from July 1, 1984, to December 15, 1987, and again from July 1996 to July 13, 2010. Holley was also the first African American mayor in the city's history, and its longest serving mayor.\n\nHis first term came to an end following an expense account scandal, becoming the first  politician in modern times to be recalled.  sent to community leaders became another factor in his removal. His successor, Gloria O. Webb, former chairperson of the School Board, not only became Portsmouth's first female mayor, but also served uncontested for a decade.\nIn May 2008 Holley narrowly defeated Martha Ann Creecy in the first contested mayoral election in Portsmouth since his 1996 victory. Holley was recalled for a second time on July 13, 2010. This second recall effort began in 2009 after an assistant made a confidential complaint of verbal abuse and of being required by Holley to perform his personal errands while working on city time. The accusations (leaked to the press) prompted the Portsmouth City Council to fine Holley $2,500 and ask him to retire, citing a pattern of mistreating subordinates. After Holley refused to retire, his opponents circulated a recall petition citing the allegations against him, which gathered 8000 signatures, which a judge deemed sufficient to place Holley's recall on the ballot for July 13, 2010.\nThough an , Holley backed both  and  running for office, including 's  and former  's . He also made a  to .\n\nHolley also drew criticism in 2008 for suggesting that Portsmouth needed a \"black\" hotel to act as a counterbalance to the \"white\" . Holley was an early supporter of the Renaissance; his portrait hangs in the lobby, and the hotel named its ballroom the \"Holley Ballroom.\" He later apologized for the remark, saying that his words were \"misconstrued\" and \"misinterpreted.\"\n\nHolley died in 2012, aged 85, after suffering a stroke.\n\n\nHolley was known for his stylish dress. He appeared in the September 2007 issue of '''' along with former  mayor  in a feature chronicling U.S. mayors.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n'''Janelle K. Sarauw''' is a Virgin Islander politician and former educator who served as senator in the  from the St. Thomas-St. John District, from 2017 to 2023. Sarauw ran for Lieutenant Governor in the .\n\n\nJanelle K. Sarauw was born on St. Thomas to Levron Sarauw Sr. of  and Carla Buchanan of . The youngest of two children, Sarauw graduated from the  in 2003. Sarauw attended , where she earned a bachelor’s degree in . She also received her master’s degree in  at . She is a granddaughter of , former .\n\n\nSarauw taught  at  from 2007 to 2010. She joined the Department of Sports, Parks and Recreation to be a Sports coordinator. Prior to becoming a senator, Sarauw was an Assistant chief researcher for the Lieutenant Governor office and worked as a part-time professor on political science at the .\n\n\nSarauw was sworn in as the 15th member of the 32nd Legislature on July 14, 2017.\n\n\nSarauw ran for the Senate ending up in 8th place. On December 9, 2016, Sarauw and campaign volunteer, Brigitte Berry filed a complaint in the  against Kevin Rodríquez, St. Thomas & St. John Board of Elections, Virgin Islands Board of Elections and Supervisor of Elections Caroline F. Fawkes. They alleged that Rodríquez was not qualified to serve in the legislature because he hadn’t been \"a bona fide resident of the Virgin Islands for at least three years next preceding the date of his election.\"\n\n\nSarauw won a special election receiving 1,292 votes over former Senator Justin Harrigan Sr. who came in second place with 900 votes.\n\n\nSarauw won re-election with 5,339 votes.\n\n\nSarauw won re-election coming in second place with 4,827 votes.\n\n\n;32nd Legislature \n* Committee on Rules and Judiciary\n* Committee on Education and Workforce Development \n* Committee on Consumer Affairs and Culture\n* Committee on Youth, Sports, Parks and Recreation\n\n;33rd Legislature\n* Committee on Rules and Judiciary (Chair)\n\n;34th Legislature\n* Committee on Housing, Transportation, and Telecommunications\n*  Committee on Health, Hospitals and Human Services\n* Committee on Education and Workforce Development (Vice Chair)\n* Committee on Disaster Recovery and Infrastructure (Chair)\n* Committee on Finance\n* Committee on the Whole \n** Subcommittee on Energy and Infrastructure Development (Chair)\n\n\nIn May 2022, Sarauw was chosen by fellow senator  to be his running mate in the .\n\n\nSarauw was crowned St. Thomas Carnival Queen in 2003.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jeffrey Mead Kurzon''' (born 1976) is a  attorney and politician.\n\n\nKurzon graduated from  with a BCL/LLB in 2003, after studying abroad at the  in France.\n\n\nHe began his career as a lawyer at , which he later left to create his own law firm.\n\nKurzon's firm represented law school graduates who sued in a class action their law schools, including  and , for misrepresenting their post-graduate employment statistics to lure students to take on hundreds of thousands dollars in debt.\n\nKurzon was the lead attorney who filed a lawsuit representing a class of about 9,000 unpaid '''' bloggers, claiming that the ''Huffington Post'' and its acquirer  unjustly made profits by using the unpaid writers' work.\n\n\nKurzon became involved in New York City politics in 2007 as one of the top fundraisers for , raising over $150,000 for the candidate and organizing one of the earliest and largest grassroots groups in New York City in support of the candidate.\n\n\nIn February 2013, Kurzon announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for  against 22-year incumbent . Kurzon pledged to not accept any PAC or lobbyist money, challenging Velázquez (who sits on the ) to do the same. After the  issued guidance on , Kurzon announced he would be the first candidate in New York to accept bitcoin donations from individuals.\n\nIn the June 24, 2014 primary, Kurzon lost to Velázquez by a large margin. , .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n, .}}\n\n\n\n\n\nIn October 2021, Kurzon joined 's  PAC team.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jenna Netherton''' (born Jenna J. Haggar on December 11, 1985) is an American politician and a  member of the  representing District 5 since January 11, 2013. Netherton served consecutively from January 11, 2011 until January 11, 2013 in the District 15 seat. She is the daughter of , another former District 10 representative.\n\n\n*2012 Redistricted to District 10, and with incumbent Republican Representative  running to return to the  and  ed and leaving both District 10 seats open, Netherton ran alongside her father in the three-way June 5, 2012 Republican Primary, where she placed first with 623 votes (42.67%) and he placed second ahead of former state Senator ; in the four-way November 6, 2012 General election, she took the first seat with 5,316 votes (31,50%) and her father took the second seat ahead of  nominees Jo Hausman and Brian Parsons.\n*2010 Running as an  to challenge District 15 incumbent Democratic Representatives  and  in the three-way November 2, 2010 General election, Netherton took the first seat with 2,264 votes (38.50%) and incumbent Representative Kirschman took the second seat ahead of incumbent Representative Vanderlinde.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  at the \n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
