    "pages": }\n| partners          = Brian Rhyne (1986–2001; his death)JC Hartpence (2002–2003) (2003–2014)Seth Posey (2021–2023)\n| website           = \n}}\n\n'''Joseph Allen Maldonado''' (''né'' '''Schreibvogel'''; born March 5, 1963), known professionally as '''Joe Exotic''' and nicknamed \"'''The Tiger King'''\", is an American media personality and businessman who operated the  (also known as the G.W. Zoo, Tiger King Park and formerly the Garold Wayne Exotic Animal Memorial Park) in , from 1999 to 2018.\n\nBorn in Kansas, Exotic and his family moved to Texas, where he enrolled at . After graduation, Exotic briefly served as the chief of police in . He then opened a pet store with his brother, but after his brother's death in 1997, Exotic sold the store and founded the G.W. Zoo. During his tenure as director there, he also held  shows and cub-petting events at venues across the U.S., hosted an online talk show, and worked with producer  to create a reality television series about himself, but this latter effort ended when most footage was destroyed in a fire in 2015. In 2016, Exotic ran as an independent in the .\n\nExotic left the G.W. Zoo in June 2018 and was arrested three months later on suspicion of hiring two men to murder  founder , with whom he had a complicated rivalry. In 2019, Exotic was convicted and sentenced to 22 years in prison on 17&nbsp;federal charges of animal abuse and two counts of attempted  for the plot to kill Baskin. In 2021, he worked with attorney  to file a motion for a new trial, and on July 15, 2021, a U.S. appeals court ruled that the convictions for the two murder attempts were wrongly treated as separate. The  reduced his sentence by 1 year, resentencing him to 21 years in late January 2022. In 2023, Exotic announced his candidacy in the  as a Democrat.\n\nExotic has been subject to substantial criticism, especially for the controversies surrounding his feud with Baskin and the treatment of animals at the G.W. Zoo. Exotic has been featured in several documentaries, including the  series '''' (2020–2021), a documentary about Exotic's career as a zookeeper and his feud with Baskin. The success of the first season of ''Tiger King'' amid the worldwide  led to Exotic receiving attention on social media and inspiring several internet memes. Exotic also appeared in two  documentaries, '''' (2011) and '''' (2021). A drama TV show based mainly on the relationship between Carole Baskin and Joe Exotic called '''' aired on  on March 3, 2022.\n\n\nJoe Exotic was born Joseph Allen Schreibvogel in , on March 5, 1963, to parents Francis and Shirley Schreibvogel. The Schreibvogels had four other children: Tamara, Pamela, Yarri, and Garold \"G.W.\" Wayne.\n\nThe Schreibvogel family moved to , where Exotic was enrolled at . After graduating from high school, he joined the  police department and was promoted to chief of the small department in 1982. He was outed to his parents as being homosexual by his estranged older brother Yarri, and in response their father made Exotic shake his hand and promise not to come to his funeral.\nExotic has said that he was badly injured in 1985 when he crashed his police cruiser into a bridge, although his claims about the wreck have changed over time: In 2019, he told '''' that the incident was a spontaneous suicide attempt, but he told '''' in 1997 that he was forced off the road by an unidentified vehicle during a drug investigation. A 2019 investigation by '''', which included interviews of family members and local residents who knew him at the time, failed to find anyone who could recall such an event taking place, although he presented a photograph showing a wrecked car as evidence.\n\n\n\nSoon after the auto accident, Exotic moved to , and managed a pet store. A friend who worked at a drive-through  brought baby lions to his neighbor's home and let Exotic handle them. Exotic credits these experiences with inspiring him to work with animals.\n\nExotic returned to Texas and worked at various jobs before opening a pet shop with his brother \"G.W.\", who shared Exotic's love of animals, in , in 1986. In 1997, after closing the first pet shop and opening a new one nearby, Exotic came into conflict with Arlington officials over repeated code violations for decorations and signs: He had been hanging gay pride symbols such as a United States flag with rainbow stripes in the shop windows, and he accused city inspectors of homophobia and of targeting the business because of his sexual orientation. In 1997 his brother was killed in an auto accident, and Exotic sold the pet shop and purchased a  Oklahoma farm with his parents. Two years after his brother's death, the farm opened as Garold Wayne Exotic Animal Memorial Park in dedication to his brother. Two of Wayne's pets were the zoo's first inhabitants.\n\nIn 2000, Exotic acquired his first two tigers, which had been abandoned. He said that the first animal rescue in his career as a zookeeper was an eleven-foot alligator with a severe eye infection. According to Exotic, he spoke by phone to  of , whose vets provided advice on appropriate antibiotics for alligators and on treating an injured kangaroo. In 2006, after , Exotic dedicated a large indoor alligator complex inside the G.W. Zoo in his memory, naming it the Steve Irwin Memorial. Some of the alligators in the complex came from 's .\n\nIn 2002, seeking to earn money to feed his growing menagerie, Exotic partnered with a traveling  to provide and handle tigers during . The experience taught Exotic that traveling magic shows could be lucrative, and after parting with the magician, he began staging shows himself and adopted \"Joe Exotic\" as his stage name. He soon found that attendees would pay to pet and have their picture taken with tiger cubs, and these activities were often more profitable than the magic show itself. His magic shows evolved into dedicated cub-petting events and he began breeding his cats to ensure that cubs were consistently available. The money he earned allowed him to increase the number of adult cats at his park and feed them. To benefit his stage persona, Exotic began behaving more flamboyantly, wearing flashy clothing and jewelry and adopting his trademark bleached  hairstyle.\n\nExotic worked as the owner and operator of the G.W. Zoo for over 20 years. He left the zoo on June 18, 2018, three months before his arrest. In 2021, Exotic stated that his whole outlook on animals in captivity has changed while he's been in jail, and he now believes that \"no animal belongs in a cage\". He also said that he never would have had a zoo if he had known what life inside a cage was like 20 years ago.\n\n\n\nDuring his career as a zoo owner, Exotic was also an aspiring  singer, although music credited to him was recorded by others. Under the pretense of obtaining music for a planned reality television series, Exotic commissioned country songs from other artists, with his creative contributions reportedly being limited to suggesting song topics and singing some backing vocals. He produced music videos for the songs and posted them on his YouTube channel, depicting himself as the main performer and taking full credit for the music, allegedly without having notified the actual artists. One of Exotic's best-known songs is \"I Saw a Tiger\", which was featured in ''Tiger King'' and has been covered by numerous bands and artists.\n\nExotic's two studio albums, ''I Saw a Tiger'' (2014) and ''Star Struck'' (2015), are featured in the ''Tiger King'' episode \"Not Your Average Joe\"''.'' In April 2023, Joe Exotic was signed to Kingmaker Music to manage his music catalog. \"My Best Friends\" is the first single from ''Jungle Rhapsody: A Tiger King Experience'', Exotic's third studio album. The 2023 album was partially recorded in  and is produced by William Moseley, JT Barnett and Jonathan Hay.\n\n\n\nExotic first appeared in 's 2011 documentary ''''. Five years later, he appeared in J.D. Thompson's documentary ''The Life Exotic: Or the Incredible True Story of Joe Schreibvogel.'' Theroux stated that Exotic initially struck him as likeable and friendly, and that, owing to Exotic's emotional volatility, Theroux was inclined to be protective of him.\n\nThe Netflix documentary series '''' is centered on Exotic and his rivalry with . The first season of the series was released in March 2020, coinciding with the worldwide  following the  being classified as a pandemic by the . A week after the release of ''Tiger King,'' both the series and Exotic himself went viral, with numerous internet memes about both Exotic and Baskin being made. In a Netflix interview in prison, Exotic stated that he was thankful for the fame and that he was \"done with the Baskin saga\".\n\nIn July 2020,  released the documentary ''Surviving Joe Exotic,'' which is focused on the animals at the G.W. Zoo. The documentary features interviews with Exotic and former G.W. Zoo employees, with the Exotic interview scenes having been filmed four months before his arrest.\n\nIn April 2021, Louis Theroux released a new documentary on Exotic, titled '''', on  in the United Kingdom. The documentary contained unseen footage of Exotic from a previous documentary by Theroux as well as new interviews of other people associated with Exotic, including Exotic's legal team and Howard and Carole Baskin, his estranged niece and brother, as well as a tour around the abandoned and extensively vandalized former G.W. Zoo property.\n\n\nFrom 2014 to 2018, Exotic occasionally worked as a  commentator and hosted two wrestling programs at the G.W. Zoo. Exotic's involvement with wrestling began when he met Texas businessman and pro wrestling promoter Robert Langdon at the G.W. Zoo's \"Monkey Ball\" charity event in 2010. They bonded over their ownership of exotic animals, and Exotic began to provide  at NWA Texoma events, which would be streamed on the JoeExoticTV YouTube channel. Langdon walked Exotic down the aisle for his marriage to former husband Dillon Passage.\n\nIn May 2021, Exotic launched a cryptocurrency to raise revenue for his defense fund as well as charity incentives personal to him. In June 2021, Exotic launched an  auction as part of a collaboration with a cryptocurrency organization. Exotic also intended to send real-life collectibles, including one of his revolvers.\n\n\n\nExotic ran as an  in the , attaining ballot access in  and receiving 962 votes (including recorded write-ins) nationwide. During his campaign, Exotic uploaded several video messages to then-Republican nominee , in which he called out several politicians he said were crooked, Baskin and other animal rights people who he alleged were scamming the public, and various laws he disagreed with.\n\nWhile running for president, Exotic was featured in an episode of '''', which covered Exotic's  campaign as part of the show's coverage of the 2016 U.S. presidential election.  complimented the production quality of Exotic's music videos, and came up with a campaign slogan for Exotic: , which later inspired the title of the ''Tiger King'' episode covering Exotic's political runs. Before the episode aired, Oliver was warned about the controversies at Exotic's zoo and his rants toward Baskin.\n\nDuring the , Exotic supported Trump over .\n\n\nAfter losing in the 2016 election, Exotic ran in the 2018   of Oklahoma. He received 664 votes in the primary, finishing last among the three Libertarian candidates. During his primary campaign, he was officially censured by the Oklahoma Libertarian Party. In 2019, following his arrest, the state convention voted unanimously to revoke his party membership.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn January 13, 2017, Exotic filed with the  to run for president as a Libertarian in the . On June 1, 2017, he filed paperwork to run in the 2018 Oklahoma gubernatorial election and ended his presidential campaign to shift his focus to the Oklahoma gubernatorial race.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2022, Joe Exotic expressed interest in running for president with  as his running mate.\n\nOn  March 13, 2023, Exotic announced a bid for the  in the , which he will run from prison. His candidacy was criticized by party chair  shortly after he announced it.\n\nOn April 11, 2023, he announced he would run as a .\n\nIn August 2024, Exotic suspended his presidential campaign and endorsed .\n\n\n\nExotic has been strongly criticized for his treatment of animals that he owns, including by , which eventually led to an investigation by the USDA and convictions for animal abuse.\n\nIn February 1999, animal welfare investigators discovered a large number of neglected emus in , Texas, and Exotic volunteered to capture the animals and take them to his animal park. However, Exotic, local volunteers, and Red Oak police were quickly overwhelmed by the task of corralling the large and fast-running birds, several of which died. Exotic and another man resorted to killing emus with shotguns and were accused of  by police. However, since the emus were considered livestock, they could lawfully be killed humanely in Texas, and a grand jury declined to indict Exotic. Most of the surviving birds ultimately wound up at Texas ranches.\ns at Exotic's zoo, including a . To feed his large number of big cats, Exotic shot horses and fed their remains to the tigers. He also fed them expired Walmart meat.]]\nIn 2000, to feed his growing zoo of big cats, he took in horses that were donated to him. He would shoot the horses and feed them whole to the tigers, lions, and other big cats.\n\nDue to the number of exotic animals at his zoo, Exotic found feeding them all to be expensive. To help offset the cost, Exotic fed them expired meat from . Employees at the zoo also ate this expired Walmart meat, and also used the expired meat to make pizzas.\n\nIn 2006, the G.W. Zoo was cited multiple times by the  (USDA) for violations of  standards. In 2020, Exotic was convicted of falsifying wildlife records in violation of the .\n\n\nThe feud between Exotic and  began in 2009 when Baskin, who sought to end commercial cub petting in the United States, targeted Exotic's lucrative traveling shows. While Exotic and the Wynnewood park had been subject to protests and investigations by animal rights organizations such as , these efforts had been sporadic and poorly organized and did not seriously hamper his business. Baskin's  organizationwhich had a very popular Facebook page and many informal volunteers recruited on social mediaproved more daunting. Big Cat Rescue volunteers began to track Exotic's movements and  managers of shopping malls that hosted his shows, prompting many of them to cancel, which jeopardized his income.\n\nExotic saw Baskin's actions as hypocritical because she also operated an animal sanctuary that charged admission, albeit for nonprofit purposes. Exotic responded to Baskin's social media efforts by setting up his own TV studio and YouTube channel at the G.W. Zoo, hosting a nightly talk show that aired vitriolic attacks against Big Cat Rescue and Baskin personally. He covertly visited Big Cat Rescue in September 2010 and chartered a helicopter to survey the property. He obtained a copy of Baskin's diary stolen from her computer by a former employee and posted excerpts online.\n\nBaskin's second husband, Don Lewis,  and was declared legally dead in 2002. Evidence of foul play is lacking and Baskin was never named as a suspect; however, Lewis's daughter says that Baskin killed Lewis and fed his body to her tigers, and Exotic used his YouTube show to promote this theory and others relating to Lewis's disappearance, offering a $10,000 reward for information leading to Baskin's arrest.\n\nIn 2011, Exotic copied the Big Cat Rescue name and various identifying aspects of the sanctuary's branding in his marketing, rebranding his traveling show as \"Big Cat Rescue Entertainment\" with a Florida phone number. Baskin said that she was quickly inundated with emails and phone calls from distraught supporters who assumed that she was operating the traveling show. Baskin sued Exotic for trademark infringement and was eventually awarded a $1&nbsp;million settlement from him although she was unable to collect most of it. Two years later, Exotic filed for bankruptcy.\n\nIn 2015, Exotic's mother Shirley was sued by Big Cat Rescue over assets that belonged to Exotic or the G.W. Zoo being transferred into and out of her name. In May 2020, the  ruled that Exotic fraudulently transferred ownership of the park to his mother to avoid paying debts resulting from the earlier settlement, awarding ownership to Baskin and giving Exotic's former business partner Jeff Lowe until October 1 to vacate the premises. Baskin decided to sell the park with s prohibiting the keeping of exotic animals. Lowe relocated the animals to , intending to open a new park there, but the  filed a lawsuit citing Lowe's history of poor animal care; the new park never opened and federal authorities seized all remaining cats in May 2021.\n\n\nOn March 26, 2015, a fire broke out at the G.W. Zoo, destroying the Steve Irwin Memorial and Exotic's TV studio, where he shot his YouTube videos and stored footage for a planned reality series. All but one of the Neverland Ranch alligators were killed. The blaze was thought to have been started by an arsonist, possibly a vindictive employee, but no one was ever arrested. Exotic blamed animal rights activists for the incident, while ''Tiger King'' speculated that the perpetrator may have been Exotic himself or , the reality TV producer who worked with him.\n\nKirkham asserts that Exotic and zoo employees sought to destroy incriminating footage he had stored in the TV studio. Kirkham says that Exotic killed some of his own tigers, and that he had video of Exotic killing animals, but it was lost in the fire. During an interview, Kirkham remarked, \"There was footage in there of Exotic actually killing animals for fun. In the course of my year, he walked up to a tiger he didn't like and just shot it in the head.\"\n\n\nWith the exception of his brother Garold, Exotic did not have a good relationship with his family; in particular his estranged brother Yarri has been very critical of him, believing that he manipulated the Schreibvogel family to take the money from Garold's death for himself. Exotic's niece Chealsi Putman, who worked at the G.W. Zoo periodically from 1999 to 2017, also criticized him. In April 2021, Putman was interviewed by  for '''' and claimed that the tigers Exotic shot were not sick.\n\nSeveral of Exotic's former employees at the G.W. Zoo have called out his actions in interviews after the release of ''Tiger King''. He has most frequently been criticised by Rick Kirkham, who claimed that things were \"a hell of a lot worse\" than what's depicted in ''Tiger King;'' \"[Watching Tiger King], you kinda had a little bit of a heart for the guy, but you really didn't realize or get to see how evil he really could be, not only to animals, but to people.\" In the ''Tiger King'' aftershow, Kirkham stated that Exotic was terrified of lions and tigers, and remarked, \"It's idiotic to think how Exotic's become famous as the Tiger King when he's so terrified of big cats.\"\n\n\nIn September 2023, Joe Exotic threatened legal action against  quarterback  for allegedly infringing on Exotic's trademark of 'Tiger King'.\n\nExotic released the following statement on his social media:\n\n}}\n\n\nAs a result of an investigation by the , the , the , and the  Exotic was arrested and arraigned on charges of attempting to hire two hitmen to kill Baskin and of violating the  and the . In April 2019, a federal jury found him guilty on two counts of hiring someone to murder Baskin in Florida, eight counts of violating the Lacey Act by falsifying wildlife records, and nine counts of violating the Endangered Species Act by killing five tigers and selling tigers across state lines. He was sentenced to 22 years in prison on January 22, 2020, and was incarcerated at  (FMC Fort Worth). In March 2020, Exotic filed a lawsuit against those he blamed for his arrest and conviction, including the , the lead prosecutor, a federal agent, and former business partner Jeff Lowe; he sought $94&nbsp;million, he dropped the lawsuit five months later.\n\nIn April 2020, Exotic was a topic of conversation during a White House COVID-19 press conference. A few days later,  joked about the prospect of Exotic getting a pardon.\n, January 2021 (evoking the album cover of the Beatles' )]]\nIn May 2020, a private investigator, attorneys representing Exotic, and a group of volunteers calling themselves \"Team Tiger\" delivered a 257-page document to the  disputing elements of his conviction and requesting a  from President . The following month, Trump described Exotic and his supporters as \"strange\" but did not say whether he would consider pardoning him. On January 19, 2021, the day before the , Team Tiger chartered a limousine in  to prepare for Exotic's anticipated last-minute pardon and release. However, he ultimately was not pardoned and remained incarcerated at FMC Fort Worth. It was reported in March 2021 that Exotic intended to seek a pardon from President . Later that month, Exotic hired  and Amy Hanna as his attorneys. They planned to file a motion for a new trial within a few months.\n\nIn July 2021, a three-judge panel for the  ruled Exotic should serve a shorter sentence, saying the separate convictions for each man he tried to hire to kill Baskin should have been treated as one by the trial court. A new sentencing hearing was held on January 28, 2022, and was attended by a group of Exotic supporters, some wearing animal-print masks. Baskin testified at the hearing that she was fearful that Exotic would threaten her if released. A federal judge sentenced Exotic to 21 years, a reduction of only one year.\n\nWhile incarcerated, Exotic wrote his autobiography, ''Tiger King: The Official Tell-All Memoir'', which was released on November 9, 2021. In prison, Exotic has been allowed to use a computer for 30 minutes at a time, so he worked on his book every day.\n\nAfter the success of the first season of ''Tiger King'', Exotic began to receive a large amount of fan mail.  attempted to start a GoFundMe to help get Exotic out of prison. Exotic also inspired several s, most of which were based on his quotes in ''Tiger King.'' He also inspired the ongoing \"Free Joe Exotic\" campaign, started by fans who believed he was wrongly convicted. On March 31, 2020, Donald Trump Jr. posted two Exotic memes to Instagram, the first featuring a face merge of his father and Exotic, and the second featuring 's head photoshopped over an image of Exotic with a tiger.\n\nExotic was transferred from FMC Fort Worth to  in  in November 2021. He was later moved back to FMC Fort Worth and is scheduled for release in 2036.\n\n\n\nExotic is an ordained minister in the state of  and is able to officiate marriages. He obtained his ministerial ordination from the .\n\n\nExotic (Jon) is gay and has referred to numerous partners as his husband despite them not being legally married.\n\nHis first known male partner was Brian Rhyne, who died of complications from HIV in 2001. The following year, he started a relationship with Jeffrey Charles 'JC' Hartpence, an event manager who aided him with his traveling animal show. In mid 2003, John Finlay was hired as an employee of the G.W. Zoo and within a month began a relationship with Exotic. By this point, the relationship between Exotic and Hartpence had deteriorated owing to drug and alcohol addiction. It finally ended after Exotic threatened to kill Hartpence and feed his remains to the zoo's largest tiger. Hartpence later woke Exotic up by putting a gun to his head, an action that led to Hartpence's arrest by the local authorities. Hartpence was later convicted of child molestation and first-degree murder.\n\nTravis Maldonado arrived at the zoo in December 2013 and, like Finlay, rapidly began a relationship with Exotic. Exotic, Maldonado, and Finlay were unofficially married to each other less than a month later in a three-partner wedding ceremony. Exotic and Finlay eventually fell out, and following an incident in the zoo's car park Finlay was arrested and charged with assault and battery. In 2015, Exotic legally wed Maldonado and his legal name became Joseph Maldonado.\n\nOn October&nbsp;6, 2017, Travis Maldonado fatally shot himself at the zoo in front of Joshua Dial, who was Exotic's campaign manager at the time. In his memory, Exotic set up a charity called the Travis Maldonado Foundation, which claimed it would provide \"no-cost resources for those struggling with meth addiction and gun-safety education.\" At Travis's memorial service at the G.W. Zoo, Exotic stated that God put him on Earth to make him smile and stated that his testicles \"were like golden nuggets.\"\n\nExotic married Dillon Passage on December 11 of the same year; one of the witnesses was Travis Maldonado's mother. Upon his marriage to Passage, Exotic's legal surname became Maldonado-Passage. According to Passage, Exotic prevented him from making friends at the G.W. Zoo, and also prevented him from spending time with his mother and cousin.\n\nOn March 26, Passage revealed on Instagram that he and Exotic were seeking a divorce, but on good terms and that he would continue to have Exotic in his life. Passage announced in July 2021 that he was now in a relationship with a man closer to his age named John. Exotic initially wished the couple well, but stated that he would have liked to have been told by Passage himself rather than TMZ. He later referred to Passage as \"a dumbass\", and blocked him on Instagram and Twitter following Passage releasing a video exposing Exotic's abusive and controlling behavior during their relationship, where he stated he felt like \"another animal in a cage.\" That same month, Exotic announced a contest called \"The Bachelor King\", where men over 18 years of age could fill out an application online to possibly be the next husband in Exotic's life. Exotic and Passage's divorce was finalized in January 2023.\n\n\nExotic claims that after wrecking his police cruiser in 1985, he was confined to a hospital for over a month, and then spent several years in rehabilitation. He also stated to have had four heart attacks during his career as a zookeeper.\n\nIn April 2020, there were multiple cases of  at Exotic's prison. For safety precautions, Exotic was moved from Grady County Jail in Oklahoma to Federal Medical Center and began a 14-day quarantine. ''Tiger King'' fans speculated that Exotic had COVID-19, but Dillon Passage confirmed to fans that he did not.\n\nIn January 2021, he was reportedly suffering from an unverified medical condition. In March 2021, it was reported that he was suffering from a blood-immune disorder and was being denied treatment.\n\nOn May 14, 2021, it was reported that Exotic had been diagnosed with prostate cancer, and had approved testing to establish what stage it was in. In August 2021, he said that his prostate cancer might have spread to his . In November, he said that he had an aggressive form of cancer, and has since been moved to  in North Carolina for treatment.\n\nIn October 2024, it was reported that Exotic had been quarantined at FMC Fort Worth due to an outbreak of  in a housing unit there.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''I Saw a Tiger'' (2014)\n* ''Star Struck'' (2015)\n* ''Jungle Rhapsody: A Tiger King Experience'' (2023)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n* \n*  – Podcast history of Joe Exotic on \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| children            = 4\n | blank1          = Television\n | data1           = \n| education           =  () ()\n}}\n'''Charles Joseph Scarborough''' (; born April 9, 1963) is an American television host and former politician who is the co-host of '''' on  with his wife  and . He previously hosted '''' on the same network. A former member of the , Scarborough was in the  for  from 1995 to 2001. He was appointed to the President's Council on the 21st Century Workforce in 2002 and was a visiting  at the  at the . He was named in the 2011  as one of the most influential people in the world.\n\n\nScarborough was born in  in 1963, the son of Mary Joanna (''née'' Clark) and George Francis Scarborough, a businessman. He has two siblings. In 1969, his family moved to , in 1973 to , and in 1978 to . Scarborough attended  in Pensacola. He earned a  degree in history from the  in 1985 and a  from the  in 1990. During this time, he wrote music and produced  with his band, Dixon Mills, including the album ''Calling on Robert E. Lee'', and he also coached football and taught high school. During his first year of law school, Scarborough wrote a musical about televangelists called \"The Gospel According to Esther\" which premiered at the University of Alabama to positive reviews. Later, the musical was showcased at the Alabama Shakespeare Festival.\n\n\nScarborough was admitted to the  in 1991 and practiced law in ., Richard E. Cohen, '''',  Press, 2002, pages 374–76.\n\nScarborough's most high-profile case was briefly representing , who murdered Dr.  in 1993. Griffin's father was a friend of Scarborough's in-laws, and Joe agreed to represent Griffin until the murder suspect found adequate representation. Before removing himself from the case, Scarborough made several court appearances representing Griffin, later saying: \"There was no way in hell I could sit in at a civil trial, let alone a capital trial,\" referring to the prospect of prosecutors seeking the  against Griffin. Scarborough assisted Griffin in choosing other counsel from the many who offered their services, however, and helped shield the family from the media exposure, ''''.\n\nScarborough's political profile was also raised when he assisted with a  in late-1993, leading a tax revolt that defeated a proposed sixty-five percent increase in Pensacola's property taxes.\n\n\n\n\nIn , Scarborough was elected to the  for , becoming the first Republican to represent the  since . The seat had become open when eight-term  incumbent  retired. In the general election, Scarborough defeated the Democratic candidate, Pensacola attorney Vince \"Vinnie\" Whibbs, Jr., with 61 percent of the vote. Whibbs was the son of former Pensacola mayor . This district had not supported a Democratic candidate for U.S. president since ; however, Democratic candidates had continued to hold most local offices well into the 1990s. Scarborough's win coincided with a large Republican wave that allowed the Republicans to take the majority in the House for the first time in 40 years.\n\nScarborough was reelected with 72 percent of the vote in 1996. In 1998 and 2000, he faced only write-in candidates as opposition.\n\n\nIn June 2000, during his congressional career, he received a 95 percent lifetime rating from the . He signed the . Scarborough was a member of the , , , and  committees. In 1998 he was named chairman of the Civil Service Committee.\n\nScarborough was one of a group of about 40 freshmen Republican legislators who dubbed themselves the  after ''''. Scarborough was elected political director of the incoming legislators. The New Federalists called for sweeping cuts in the U.S. government, including plans to \", localize, consolidate, [or] eliminate\" the Departments of , ,  and . House Speaker  tapped Scarborough to head a Republican task force on education, and Scarborough declared, \"Our goal is to get as much money, power, and authority out of Washington and get as much money, power, and authority into the classroom as possible.\" Rep.  (R-Ohio), then chairman of the , adopted Scarborough's language eliminating the federal Department of Education in the 1996 House Budget Resolution. The budget passed the House by a vote of 238–193. Scarborough and the group played a pivotal role in pressing Gingrich to keep the GOP's promise to balance the federal budget.\n\nScarborough supported a number of  positions while in Congress including banning family planning funding in US aid abroad; banning ; and making it illegal to transport minors to get an abortion. He voted in favor of the , that made it a crime to harm a  during the commission of other crimes.\n\nScarborough sponsored a bill to force the U.S. to withdraw from the  after a four-year transition and replace it with an international organization of democratic nations. He voted to make the  self-sufficient by eliminating federal funding. He also voted for the \" Preservation act of 1995,\" which cut the projected growth of Medicare by $270 billion over ten years. Scarborough was one of few house Republicans to vote against efforts by Gingrich to cut Medicaid funding and the only Republican in the Florida delegation to vote against oil drilling royalty relief, which Scarborough blasted as \"corporate welfare\".  He voted against the \",\" which raised the  to $5.15 an hour. Scarborough had a conservative voting record on , , and  issues but was seen as  on  and  causes, including supporting the closure of the  and defending accused terrorist . Scarborough also teamed up with civil rights leaders in a controversial effort to rename a historic Pensacola street after  The Pensacola News Journal praised Scarborough’s leadership despite these efforts not being of political benefit to him.\n\nWhile in Congress, Scarborough received several awards, including the \"Friend of the Taxpayer Award\" from ; the \"Guardian of Small Business Award\" from the ; the \"Spirit of Enterprise Award\" from the ; the \"Taxpayer's Hero Award\" from the ; and the \"Guardian of Seniors' Rights Award\" from the . In 1996, Scarborough spoke at the ’s Council Dinner in .\n\nScarborough was one of the 228 members of the House who voted to  in December 1998.\n\n\n* 104th Congress –  –  (formerly Committee on Armed Services)\n* 105th Congress&nbsp;– Committee on National Security&nbsp;– Committee on Government Reform and Oversight – \n* 106th Congress – &nbsp;– Committee on Government Reform – \n* 107th Congress&nbsp;– Committee on Government Reform – \n\n\n\n\n\nIn May 2001, five months into his fourth term in Congress, Scarborough stated his intention to resign to spend more time with his children. Of his resignation, Scarborough said, \"The realization has come home to me that they're at a critical stage of their lives and I would rather be judged at the end of my life as a father than as a congressman.\"  A  was held in October 2001 to replace Scarborough. Since then, Scarborough has contemplated returning to politics several times. In 2017, Scarborough left the Republican Party to become an .\n\n\nIn 1999, while still serving in Congress, Scarborough founded the free weekly Pensacola-area newspaper ''The Florida Sun''. The paper merged in 2001 and is now known as the ''Independent News''.\n\nAfter leaving Congress, Scarborough worked as an environmental lawyer in Florida.\n\n\nIn April 2003, '''' debuted as a nightly primetime show on MSNBC.\n\nIn 2005 the program covered politics and popular culture. Scarborough broadcast the show from , MS, during the immediate aftermath of . After three days of reporting on the scenes, Scarborough called the situation in the  region \"nothing short of a national disgrace\". '''' wrote that Scarborough’s experiences “put him on the shortlist of network anchors and correspondents for whom Gulf Coast assignments during and immediately after Katrina proved life-changing.” The |date=2009-11-19 |title=MSNBC's 'Morning Joe' comes to New Orleans to promote volunteerism |url=https://www.nola.com/entertainment_life/movies_tv/msnbcs-morning-joe-comes-to-new-orleans-to-promote-volunteerism/article_f020e403-62e0-5da7-b206-799ebe54bd08.html |access-date=2023-11-20 |website=NOLA.com |language=en}} Because of Scarborough's criticism of , the ''San Francisco Chronicle'' said his Katrina coverage had \"become essential viewing.\"  Presidential historian  wrote in his book on Katrina, ''The Great Deluge'', that “Joe Scarborough was keenly attuned to the devastation along the Gulf Coast...and his diagnosis of the failures was right on the mark.\"\n\n\nOn December 8, 2008, Scarborough and ''Morning Joe'' co-host Mika Brzezinski began hosting a two-hour late-morning  on  (770 AM) in , replacing 12-year veteran host . On April 26, 2010, the radio show was placed on \"hiatus\", which Scarborough said was to redevelop its format into a new three-hour show. The show never returned.\n\n\n\nIn May 2007, Scarborough became one of the rotating hosts auditioning for the slot vacated by '''' on MSNBC. With his morning show, Scarborough won the slot permanently in July 2007.\n\n''Morning Joe'' is a weekday  news and talk show from 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. . It features Joe Scarborough providing both enterprise reporting and discussion on the news of the day in a panel format with co-hosts  and . The show features in-depth discussions that help drive the day's political conversation. The initial reviews were positive. The ''New York Times'' said it was \"unlike anything else on morning television\" and '''' said the show \"set the agenda for the day's news\".\n\nIn 2007, New York City mayor  joined Geist, Brzezinski, MSNBC president , and Scarborough to cut the ribbon on the new set of '''' at .\n\nThe program became a Washington \"breakfast staple\", showing up on screens at the congressional gym and on government jets. Scarborough has covered presidential elections and conventions. In 2015, he interviewed Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and abruptly ended the interview, but resumed it after the commercial break. Having known Scarborough for years, Trump would often call into the show during his first presidential campaign. It has also been reported that President  calls Scarborough often to get the host’s take on issues. ''Morning Joe'' is Biden’s favorite program, and it influences who he listens to and how the White House is run. 2017 marked the program's 10th year on air.\n\nThe Monday after the , ''MSNBC'' preempted ''Morning Joe'' for the day, prompting threats from Scarborough to quit if the network took similar action again. ''The Daily Beast'' reported that the message of the show was “We're backand the place to go for powerful Democrats to make their case” because in the days following Biden’s endorsement of   for President, Scarborough and others on the show interviewed VP nominee hopefuls  ,  and . ''The Hollywood Reporter'' wrote that “at a time when TV news feels like it is fading into irrelevance with the broader public, with a certain group of extremely important and influential viewers (or even one viewer in particular), it appears to be more essential than ever.”\n\nAccording to  in 2016, ''Morning Joe'' delivered MSNBC's biggest ever total viewer and demo audiences for that time period and beat third-place CNN in both categories. This marked ''Morning Joe''s seventh straight year topping CNN in total viewers. Scarborough also hosts ''Joe Scarborough Presents'' a primetime special dedicated to a single topic. The 2023 premiere featured Joe Biden,  and , and . He has appeared on '', '', and ''''.” He is a regular guest on NBC and MSNBC news programs such as '''' and ''''. Joe also appeared as himself on two episodes ''of '' in 2024.\n\nIn 2023, Morning Joe was the #1 cable morning show in New York and Washington, DC. Nationally, Morning Joe ranked #2 in all of cable television in its time slot for the 7th straight year. Morning Joe beat CNN in the ratings for the 14th straight year in total audience and in the  A25-54 demographic group for the 8th straight year. Compared to the previous year, Morning Joe had double-digit viewership growth among total viewers and adults ages 25–54, while  and  had double-digit declines. In August 2023,  reported Morning Joe was the most-watched morning cable news program.\n\n\nIn an  for '''' in August 2016, Scarborough argued that the Republican Party must \"dump \" as their . Drawing attention to Trump's remarks about  and the , Scarborough wrote: \"A bloody line has been crossed that cannot be ignored. At long last, Donald Trump has left the Republican Party few options but to act decisively and get this political train wreck off the tracks before something terrible happens.\"\n\nIn June 2017, Scarborough and Brzezinski were the targets of  by President Trump that, in response to their coverage of , referred to Scarborough as \"Psycho Joe\" and called Brzezinski \"low I.Q. Crazy Mika,\" while asserting that she was \"bleeding badly from a face-lift\" when he previously encountered her at . The hosts responded with an op-ed in ''The Washington Post'', in which they described White House officials telling them that the president would kill a pending ''''&nbsp;article if they apologized to Trump for their coverage of him.&nbsp; The president's tweets received criticism from many Republican lawmakers, including&nbsp;&nbsp;,&nbsp;Senators , , , , and .\n\nTrump has also aired \"wild allegations and fact-free innuendo\" stemming from an . On July 20, 2001, while Scarborough was in , one of his aides, 28 years old, Lori Bolterstein Klausutis, was found dead on the floor of his congressional office in . An  determined that an undiagnosed heart-valve irregularity had caused the 28-year-old to lose consciousness, fall, and hit her head on the edge of a desk the day before. Media trafficked in speculation about the death, often connecting it with Scarborough's resignation from Congress, announced in May. The claim that Scarborough was involved in the death was promoted by publisher  and by filmmaker , who registered the domain name JoeScarboroughKilledHisIntern.com. Since 2017, Trump has resurrected the debunked rumor and has called for another investigation. The '', , and '' have condemned Trump's remarks. \"It's remarkable that we have a president who is trying to have someone prosecute the person he considers to be his chief critic in the media,\" Scarborough responded in 2020. \"That's what  does. That's what  does. That's what autocrats have been doing for centuries.\" In May 2020, the aide's widower wrote a letter to Twitter's chief executive  begging him to delete Trump's tweets saying \"President Trump on Tuesday tweeted to his nearly 80 million followers alluding to the repeatedly debunked falsehood that my wife was murdered by her boss, former U.S. Rep. Joe Scarborough. The son of the president followed and more directly attacked my wife by tweeting to his followers as the means of spreading this vicious lie.\"  followed up with an op-ed in ''The New York Times'' on May 26, 2020, calling on Twitter to hold Trump to the company's rules. That same day, Twitter began fact-checking Trump's posts and applying warnings to his tweets when they made misleading claims about mail-in voting.\n\n\nIn August 2019, Scarborough drew criticism after posting -driven tweets about the , an American financier multimillionaire and convicted sex offender. Scarborough tweeted: \"A guy who had information that would have destroyed rich and powerful men's lives ends up dead in his jail cell. How predictably... Russian.\"\n\nIn January 2021, Scarborough excoriated the  for having enabled the . He claimed a  that had the perpetrators been either black or Muslim, they likely would have been dealt with more harshly.\n\n\nScarborough released his first book, ''Rome Wasn't Burnt in a Day: the Real Deal on how Politicians, Bureaucrats, and other Washington Barbarians are Bankrupting America,'' on October 4, 2005.\n\nIn his second book, ''The Last Best Hope'', released on June 9, 2009, Scarborough outlined a plan to help guide conservatives back to a political majority after their defeats in the  and the .\n\nOn November 12, 2013, Scarborough released his third book, ''The Right Path: From Ike to Reagan, How Republicans Once Mastered Politicsand Can Again''.\n\nOn November 24, 2020, Scarborough released his fourth book, ''''.\n\n\nScarborough released his debut , '''', on June 23, 2017. A video for the title track of the -inspired EP was also released on the same day. Scarborough said he planned to release a new EP every month for the following four years.\n\n\n* Scarborough was named on the 2011  list of the world’s most influential people.\n* Alongside Mika Brzezinski, in 2012 Scarborough was named on  “Top Media Power Players” list.\n* In 2016, Scarborough was inducted into the Cable Hall of Fame with Mika Brzezinski.\n* In 2017, Harvard awarded Scarborough and Brzezinski a Visiting  at .\n* Scarborough was honored with Brzezinski in 2018 with the Radio Television Digital News Foundation's Leonard Zeidenberg First Amendment Award for a major contribution to the protection of  freedoms.\n* In 2022, Scarborough, Brzezinski, and Willie Geist were named ''Mediaite’s'' Most Influential in News Media, with ''Mediaite'' praising Morning Joe’s “remarkable broadcasting prowess and chemistry.” Again in 2023, Mediaite listed the Morning Joe team as being the \"far and away favorite for liberal viewers and inside the Beltway folks.\"\n\n\nScarborough has been married three times. In 1986, Scarborough married Melanie Hinton. The couple had two sons and divorced in 1999. While interviewing  in June 2005, Scarborough expressed concerns about the possibility that one of his sons may have suffered  damage (see ). Scarborough said, \"My son, born in 1991, has a slight form of  called . When I was practicing law and also when I was in Congress, parents would constantly come to me, and they would bring me videotapes of their children, and they were all around the age of my son or younger. So, something happened in 1989.\"\n\nIn October 2001, Scarborough married his second wife, Susan Waren, a former aide to Florida governor  and a former congressional committee staffer. Their daughter was born in August 2003; their son was born in May 2008. Scarborough and Waren were divorced in January 2013.\n\n, Scarborough has residences in both , an affluent  of New York City, and . In early 2017, during a trip to , France, Scarborough became engaged to his co-host . The couple married on November 24, 2018, in Washington, D.C., in a ceremony officiated by U.S. Representative .\n\nScarborough is not related to  anchor .\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* &nbsp;– MSNBC\n* \n\n* \n* \n*  \n* \n* \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph Charles Schriner''' (born March 3, 1955) is an   and journalist. Schriner has run for  in  spanning from 2000 to 2020. Advocating  policies, he has primarily run as an , until the  when he sought the  nomination instead. Schriner's political views largely revolve around . He also ran as a  during the early portions of the 2000 and 2016 presidential election cycles. He also vied unsuccessfully for the  presidential nomination during the 2008 election cycle.\n\nSchriner has been referred to as \"average Joe\" in the media. He is also sometimes referred to as \"Joe the Painter.\" He is currently self-employed as a .\n\n\nJoe Schriner was born on March 3, 1955, in . In 1973, he graduated from , where he was the starting quarterback on the .\n\nSchriner spent his freshman year at  in . After taking a year off from school to work, he transferred to . He majored in journalism, wrote for '''', and completed an  as a  on Ohio's ''''. Schriner earned a  in  from Bowling Green State University in 1978.\n\n\nSchriner began his career as a  after college for the ''''. Schriner left the ''Register'' after two years.\n\nIn 1983, Schriner began working at a halfway house in  as a . The halfway house was a 90-day treatment program run operated by the Lorain County Council on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse (LCCADA). During the next two years, Schriner pursued seminar studies to become a drug and alcoholism counselor.\n\n\n\n\nSchriner declared his first run for  with a speech at the  in , on April 30, 1999. He initially declared as a  candidate, but then switched to  after  won the . Schriner ran again in 2004, 2008, and 2012.\n\nSchriner declared his 2016 candidacy in a  on the home page of his official campaign . 2016 marked his fifth consecutive run for president.\n\n\n\n\nSchriner announced he would run in the  as an  candidate.     "pages": }\n\n'''John Joseph Henry Schwarz''' (born November 15, 1937), is an American physician and independent politician from , who was elected to the  in 2004 as a moderate . He represented  from January 2005 to January 2007.\n\n\nDr. Schwarz was born and raised in , after his family moved there in 1935 so his father could work as a physician in the  Hospital. He has two older siblings, Frank and Janet. He attended Fremont Elementary School, W.K. Kellogg Junior High School, and graduated from Battle Creek Central High School. He played on the baseball, swimming and football teams at B.C. Central. In 1959, he received a  in  from the , , where he played on the 1956 reserve football team as a center.\n\nDr. Schwarz graduated from Wayne State University Medical School in 1964 and interned at Los Angeles County Hospital before enlisting in the Navy. Next, Dr. Schwarz served in Southeast Asia for five years, first with the U.S. Navy in Vietnam and as an assistant naval attaché in Indonesia. He was then a member of the Defense Intelligence Agency, before serving with the Central Intelligence Agency for three years in Indonesia, Laos, and Vietnam. During his time in Indonesia, Dr. Schwarz met  on several occasions and, at then-U.S. Ambassador to Indonesia ’s direction, even taught Suharto basic English phrases for about six weeks. Schwarz left the CIA in 1970 to attend Harvard University, finishing his residency in otolaryngology in 1973.\n\nHe returned, with his new family, to Battle Creek in 1974, and has been a practicing  in Battle Creek since that time. He currently sees patients at the Family Health Center in Battle Creek, a federally qualified health center. He is a . His first wife, Anne, died in 1990, and he is divorced from his second wife. He has one daughter from his first marriage.\n\n\nIn 1984, Schwarz was elected Mayor of Battle Creek.  In 1986, he was elected to the .  In 2002, he ran for , but was defeated in the primary by a wide margin.\n\nIn 2006, Schwarz voted against the , which would have banned every state from legally recognizing . Schwarz is considered to be a moderate Republican who supports abortion rights and favors embryonic .\n\n\nOn the state level, Schwarz was appointed to Gov. 's Emergency Financial Advisory Panel, led by former Michigan governors  (R) and  (D). On the national level, Schwarz was appointed by Secretary of Defense  to serve on the independent panel to investigate the conditions at  in suburban Washington, DC. Schwarz was reappointed to the Altarum Institute Board of Trustees, a position he held prior to his congressional service, in February 2007. Altarum Institute is a nonprofit health policy research institute based in Ann Arbor, Michigan. He also accepted a teaching position at the University of Michigan's , which began in fall 2007.\n\nIn 2010, Schwarz considered running for governor of Michigan as an independent in . However, on June 2, 2010, he announced he would not run due to fundraising issues.\n\n, Schwarz is a member of the 's board of directors.\n\nOn June 16, 2014, Schwarz signed a brief in support of same-sex marriage.\n\nFrom 1991 to 2005 Schwarz served as a trustee for . Schwarz also served as campaign chair for the college's previous capital campaign during 2007-2009 academic years for Olivet College.\n\n\n* '''2006 Race for the U.S. House of Representatives, 7th District'''\n**  (R), 50%\n**  (D), 46%\n** David Horn (UST), 1%\n** Robert Hutchinson (L), 2%\n** Joe Schwarz, 1% (Write-in candidate)\n* '''2006 Race for the U.S. House of Representatives, 7th District – Republican Primary'''\n**  (R), 53%\n** Joe Schwarz (R) (inc.), 47%\n* '''2004 Race for the U.S. House of Representatives, 7th District'''\n** Joe Schwarz (R), 58%\n** Sharon Renier (D), 36%\n* '''2004 Race for the U.S. House of Representatives, 7th District – Republican Primary'''\n** Joe Schwarz (R), 28%\n** Brad Smith (R), 22%\n**  (R), 18%\n**  (R), 14%\n** Gene DeRossett (R), 11%\n** Paul DeWeese (R), 7%\n* '''2002 Race for Governor – Republican Primary'''\n**  (R), 81%\n** Joe Schwarz (R), 19%\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John J. Farmer Jr.''' (born June 24, 1957) is an American author, lawyer, politician, and jurist.  He is the director of the , where he also leads the Miller Center for Community Protection and Resilience (CPR)., ''Rutgers.edu  '', August 19, 2019.  Retrieved August 22, 2019. He served as acting  for 90 minutes on January 8, 2002, by virtue of his status as .\n\n\nFarmer was born in , in 1957. He attended , where he received a  degree in 1979 and a  degree in 1986.\n\n\nAfter law school, he worked as a clerk for  Justice . From 1988 to 1990, he was an associate in the law firm of  in . From 1990 to 1994, he was an  for the District of New Jersey.\n\n\nIn 1997, Governor  appointed Farmer as chief counsel, after having served as deputy chief counsel and assistant counsel to the governor.\n\nFarmer was nominated to be  on March 15, 1999, and was sworn in the following June after being confirmed unanimously by the . He continued to serve under  after Whitman's resignation.\n\n\nFarmer served as Acting Governor for 90 minutes on January 8, 2002. Following Governor 's resignation the previous year to become head of the , Farmer was one of four people to serve as acting governor for the one-year period between Whitman's resignation and 's inauguration, along with three different senate presidents, , , and . DiFrancesco served as acting governor for all but the last week of this period, when his term as senate president ended with the mandate of the outgoing senate on January 8, 2002, while newly elected governor Jim McGreevey would not be inaugurated before January 15, 2002.\n\nThe state did not have the position of  until 2010, and succession rules specified that the next in line for governor after the Senate President and the Speaker of the , which both became vacant on January 8, would be the Attorney General until the next Senate President could be sworn in or until an Acting Senate President could be elected. This automatically made Farmer Acting Governor. Farmer served as Acting Governor for 90 minutes until Republican Senator  and Democratic Senator  were duly elected and sworn in as co-presidents of the senate, as the Senate had been evenly split between the two parties. They agreed to evenly divide the remaining week in the gubernatorial term, with Bennett serving from January 8, 2002 to January 12, 2002; and Codey serving from January 12, 2002, to January 15, 2002.\n\nAs a result, the state had five different people serving as governor during a period of eight days: DiFrancesco, Farmer, Bennett, Codey, and McGreevey. In 2018, political journalist David Wildstein speculated that, as  served as acting president of the senate until Bennett and Codey assumed the role, it's possible that \"maybe\" Littell assumed the governorship for \"a few minutes\" as well. However, Littell is not included on a list of governors of the state published by the .\n\n\nFarmer subsequently acted as senior counsel to the , chaired by former New Jersey Governor .\n\nFarmer's book, ''The Ground Truth: The Untold Story of America Under Attack On 9/11'', was released days before the eighth anniversary of the 9/11 attacks. In \"The Ground Truth,\" Farmer made the following controversial statement: \"At some level of government,\" says Dean Farmer, \"at some point in time, a decision was made not to tell the truth about the national response to the attacks on the morning of 9/11. We owe the truth to the families of the victims of 9/11. We owe it to the American public as well, because only by understanding what has gone wrong in the past can we assure our nation's safety in the future.\"\n\nOn January 21, 2010, he appeared on ''''.\n\nIn July 2011, he was appointed the 13th (and tie-breaking) member of  by both its Democratic and Republican members. New Jersey lost one Congressional seat in redistricting and the panel redrew the congressional districts, determining which seat was lost.\n\n\nFarmer has served as dean of . In his tenure, In conjunction with '''', Farmer planned a multi-day symposium to address the many legal uncertainties in national security policies and practices following the . The symposium featured , , , and others. Two  justices,  and , also have spoken at the law school. Prior to his deanship, Farmer practiced law as a partner in a  firm he founded, and was an adjunct professor of law at the . He also regularly contributes to '''', '''', and other publications.\n\nOn April 11, 2013, he was appointed as the senior vice president and general counsel at  in .\n\nOn August 19, 2019, Farmer was appointed by Chancellor  to succeed Ruth B. Mandel as the director of the  at .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John Jenkins''' (May 29, 1952September 30, 2020) was an American martial artist, motivational speaker, , and politician who served as the first  Mayor of ,  from 1994 to 1998, a  from 1996 to 1998 and the Mayor of , Maine from 2007 to 2009.\n\nBorn in , New Jersey, Jenkins graduated from  in 1974. While at college, he excelled in martial arts and upon graduating toured Japan competing in the . He won the 1977 Championships in , and won three other mixed martial arts championships in karate and .\n\nHe returned to Maine to work at his ''alma mater'' as director of housing in 1980 before formally entering politics in November 1993. His first political contestation was for the Mayor of Lewiston which he won with a 3 to 1 margin. Two years into his mayoral tenure, he ran and eventually unseated an incumbent legislator to become a member of the Maine Senate representing the 21st district. After a brief hiatus to become a business consultant and a , he entered the 2007 mayoral race for Auburn eventually winning it as a . He returned to business consulting after his term end in 2009.\n\nOn November 17, 2017, according to the Maine Ethics Commission, Jenkins announced his candidacy for the  as a political .\n\n\nJohn Jenkins was born ,  on May 29, 1952 becoming the youngest of three children. The Black Past: Remembered and Reclaimed|website=www.blackpast.org|date=13 April 2009 |language=en|access-date=2017-11-19}} His youth was marked with an \"abusive\" and \"violent\" atmosphere. He has claimed that \"stellar educational opportunities and a firm religious faith\" helped him through difficult early years. His mother, a , sent him to attend the  after high school which exposed him to a social program ran by  where he gained exposure to the benefits of a university education.\n\nIn 1970, he enrolled in , and despite the college's reputation for educating students from \"upper middle or affluent backgrounds\" who \"distanced themselves [from the middle class]\" he founded the Afro-American Society. He graduated from the college with a B.A. in  in 1974.\n\nWhile at college, he excelled in martial arts and upon graduating toured Japan competing in the . He won the 1977 Championships in , and won three other mixed martial arts championships in karate and .\n\nJenkins died from an undisclosed illness on September 30, 2020.\n\n\n\n\nAfter serving as the director of housing for Bates College, he announced that he was running for the Mayoralty of Lewiston, Maine in November 1993. He won the election with a margin of 3 to 1. He expanded the city's economy by encouraging  by international businesses. Jenkins was also instrumental in establishing trade and urban partnerships with neighboring towns in Maine. By 1995, the city's economy saw  decrease yielding \"one of the healthiest economies in [the state].\"\n\n\nTwo years into his mayoral tenure in 1995, he ran and eventually unseated an incumbent legislator to become a member of the Maine Senate representing the 21st district. He was the first African American to hold the position. The campaign for the Maine Senate was \"filled with personal attacks and racial overtones\" departing from his previous campaign strategies and reception. After finishing his terms as mayor of Lewiston and state senator he took a hiatus from politics to become a business consultant and .\n\n\nAfter returning from his hiatus, Jenkins ran, as a , and won the Auburn mayoralty.\n\n\nIn August 2010, Jenkins announced his write-in candidacy for the  after the current incumbent governor, , was term-limited. As an unregistered contender he competed directly with the Independent candidate Eliot R. Cutler, Democrat , and Republican . Through a , Paul LePage was elected governor over the other candidates.\n\nOn September 1, 2017, it was announced that Jenkins was interested in launching an exploratory campaign for the . He announced he would be running as a political  given that everything \"falls in place.\" He would be Maine's first African-American governor, if elected. In November 2017, he filed papers with the Maine Ethics Commission formally announcing his candidacy.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John T. Yudichak''' (born May 1, 1970) is an American politician who served as a member of the  for  from 2011 to 2022. He previously served in the  for the  from 1999 to 2010. In 2024, Yudichak became the eighth president of .\n\n\nJohn Yudichak was born on May 1, 1970, in , , to Joseph and Sarah Yudichak. Both Yudichak's father and grandfather were coal miners. His father was also a longtime supervisor in . Yudichak graduated from  in 1988, and attended  for one year before transferring to the .  He earned a  degree in English in 1993 and a  degree in American Studies from Pennsylvania State University in 2004.\n\n\nYudichak worked as an intern for   before serving as director of development at the  in Wilkes-Barre. In 1996, he unsuccessfully challenged incumbent  for the  nomination for the  in the , losing by 600 votes. However, he ran for the nomination again in 1998, and defeated Jarolin by more than 800 votes. In the general election, he defeated  Jean Sepling.\n\nYudichak was elected to the State Senate in . He easily won the Democratic nomination for the  (being vacated by Democratic incumbent ) when he defeated  mayor  by a 2 to 1 margin in the May 18, 2010, primary. Yudichak won the general election on November 2, 2010, defeating Luzerne County Commissioner .\n\nOn November 19, 2019, Yudichak changed his voter registration from Democrat to Independent and ceased to caucus with the Democrats, caucusing instead with the Republican majority. He blamed his party switch on \"purist\" partisan politicians \"who demand that you choose a battle camp. You must pass their litmus test, and declare if you support ‘us,’ or ‘them.’\" Yudichak would later say the friction between him and the Democratic Party was because of   Democrats who opposed the expansion of Pennsylvania's energy industry and \"demonize[d]\" .\n\nOn March 17, 2022, Yudichak announced he would not seek re-election after the redistricting process shifted his district to the  and placed his home in the . After leaving office, Yudichak joined GSL Public Strategies Group, a government consulting firm.\n\nOn October 17, 2023, Yudichak was chosen by the board of trustees of  to be the college's next president. He was one of three applicants interviewed for the job and was elected by a 13–2 vote of the board. He succeeded President Thomas P. Leary on July 1, 2024.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  '''official PA Senate website'''\n*  '''official Party website'''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Juan Arambula''' (born January 29, 1952, in ) is a former man. He represented the 31st district. Arambula was elected to the assembly in 2004. While Arambula had announced that he would retire in 2008, he ran again that year and won his final term. He was a  until June 2009, when he became an . He was ed in 2010.\n\n\nHe graduated with high honors from , and went on to earn a Master's degree in Educational Administration and Policy Analysis from the  and a  (J.D.) from the .\n\nArambula is the son of immigrant farm workers. In his youth, he harvested crops with his family throughout California. He lives in Fresno with Amy, his wife of 30 years. He has four adult children: , Carmen, Diego and Miguel. His religion is \"decline to state.\"\n\n\nPrior to his election to the assembly, Arambula served on the Fresno  from 1997 to 2004. He earned the  Award for Ethics in Leadership in 2002 for his public service.\n\nEarly in his career, Assembly Member Arambula served as an attorney for the Agricultural Labor Relations Board. He also performed legal services for California Rural Legal Assistance (CRLA) in its Delano office.\n\nFrom 1987 to 1996, Arambula served on the  Board, where he worked to meet the needs of a diverse student population while maintaining financial stability during lean budget years. Arambula also served on the Board of Directors for the California School Boards Association and the California State Association of Counties.\n\n\nJuan Arambula has stated that his top legislative priorities include efforts to improve California's business climate, to encourage job creation and retention, as well as efforts to improve the health care system, student academic achievement and school accountability. He is also working to tackle air pollution in the , the shortage of health care professionals, and California's infrastructure challenges.\n\n\nJuan Arambula was named \"Legislator of the Year\" by the California Small Business Association.\n\n\nDemocratic Speaker  stripped Arambula of his chairmanship of the Public Safety Committee in retribution for Arambula leaving the Democratic Party to become an independent.\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Judith Kennedy''' (October 25, 1944 &ndash; April 15, 2018) was an American politician and businesswoman. She was an , but was a member of the  until 2015. In 2011, Kennedy was elected Mayor of , serving in the office until her death in 2018.\n\nIn the 1990s, Kennedy worked for  in , before ultimately moving to Newburgh.\n\nDuring her tenure as mayor, Kennedy focused on Newburgh's reputation as one of the most dangerous places to live in the United States, through focus on reducing crime, bringing in business and revitalizing neighborhoods. She won a second term running as an independent after losing the Democratic nomination in 2015.\n\n\nKennedy was born in , on October 25, 1944, to alcoholic parents. At the age of ten, Kennedy was responsible for her family when necessity forced her mother to take on a full-time job as a store clerk, while her father worked two jobs day and night. Three years later, Kennedy and her family moved to .\n\nAfter graduating from high school, Kennedy married James Kennedy in 1964 and worked as a dental assistant. She filed for divorce in 1981 and took custody of her four children.\n\n\nKennedy taught homemaking crafts at her local church's women's organization in Baker City. She served as president of the church's youth group and co-chaired many of the church's fundraising efforts. Subsequently, Kennedy went on to become president of the Working Women's Conference.\n\nAfter her divorce, she studied at  and later transferred to , where she earned a  degree, majoring in business administration in 1982.\n\nIn the 1990s, Kennedy moved to , and worked for , including as a consultant for  and . In September 2006, she moved to  to help remodel her son's residence and to live closer with him.\n\n\nKennedy ran for Mayor of Newburgh in 2011 after she was outraged by a 71% tax rate increase. She started a grassroots group whose members collected signatures for a petition to be delivered to state legislators in . She replaced Nicholas J. Valentine, a . Kennedy was sworn in on January 1, 2012. Her platform included expanding the tax base to reduce everyone's taxes, increasing living-wage jobs and reforming government to make it more data-driven and focused on measurable outcomes.\n\nKennedy worked to change Newburgh's reputation as one of the most dangerous places to live in the United States, with focusing on reducing crime, bringing in business and revitalizing neighborhoods. She began her first term by announcing the formation of Community Action Teams with the goal of tackling issues ranging from beautification and job creation to public safety and a citywide arts and heritage festival. Three months into her first term, Kennedy oversaw the police shooting of Michael Lembhard which resulted in protests that included clashes between protesters and police. One of her main critics at that time, activist Omari Shakur, supported Kennedy's 2015 re-election campaign.\n\nKennedy won a second term in 2015 as the nominee of the Independence Party after beating Councilman  (who had defeated her in a Democratic primary) in the general election.\n\nIn May 2016, Kennedy was diagnosed with , but continued her council work. In April 2017, a celebration of her life was held in Newburgh with dozens of residents attending to honor her. Kennedy went to  that month for treatment.\n\nIn a March 2018 interview, Kennedy reflected on her future aspirations for Newburgh remarking that her greatest hope is that \"people lay down their sharp tongues and their weapons and decide to work together\". She also criticized New York state for not providing money to Newburgh and remarking that \"it is a slow progress. We don't have any money. We've been a cash-strapped city forever\", however, she remained optimistic in the city's crime improvement.\n\nIn the aftermath of her death, a special election was originally discussed which would have been held in November 2018 to determine her successor to the mayoral office. However, in May 2018, the city council appointed councilman Torrance Harvey as Kennedy's successor.\n\n\nKennedy died of ovarian cancer while under hospice care in Newburgh on April 15, 2018, at age 73.\n\nIn response to her death,   issued a statement on : \"Judy Kennedy and I shared a love for the City of Newburgh, and I saw her in action working every day to make Newburgh the City that its wonderful people deserve\".\n\nA memorial service was held on April 19 at the Newburgh Armory Unity Center with family and local politicians in attendance, including U.S. Representative Maloney.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Keith English''' (November 4, 1967 &ndash; February 28, 2018) was an American politician, union electrician, and business owner from the state of . English served as a member of the  from . He was elected to his first two-year term in November 2012.\n\n\nEnglish was born in , . He graduated from  in 1986 and attended . He graduated from the IBEW Joint Apprenticeship Training Center in 1989. He grew up in Florissant and previously served as a Florissant city councilman for more than five years.\n\nEnglish was a former Mixed Martial Arts (MMA) trainer and enthusiast, who took up fighting professionally after the death of his mother in 2008. English fought as an MMA fighter from 2008 to the fall of 2012, when he retired, with a record of 10 wins and 0 losses. He routinely gave his winnings to charity.\n\n\n\nEnglish made national news in 2014 when he was the only Democrat to vote to reduce Missouri's state income tax for the first time in nearly a century by voting to override the veto of Democratic Governor . The vote was 109–46 with English providing the pivotal vote. English contended that the governor had spread \"misinformation\" about the bill. Immediately following the vote, English was removed from four House committees by House Minority Leader and fellow union electrician .\n\nEnglish was re-elected to a second term in November 2014, and subsequently appealed to have his committee assignments restored. When that proved unsuccessful, English resigned his Democratic Party membership and announced that he would serve as an Independent.\n\n\nAt the start of the 2015 legislative session, English introduced a bill that would, if enacted, legalize medical marijuana in the state.\n\n\nEnglish died of an apparent  on February 28, 2018, in a parking lot, in . The police recovered a firearm from the scene.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She graduated from the  and  with a  in women's studies. Pajala served as the assistant  in  and town clerk in .\n\n\n\nIn 2017, , an  member of the , resigned to focus on his business career. Governor  appointed Pajala as she was also an independent. She won in the 2018 and 2020 elections without opposition. She serves on the Human Services committee.\n\nPajala resigned in July 2024 in order to take a position with .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
