    "pages": }\n'''Kenneth Ezra Mapp''' (born November 2, 1955) is an American politician who served as the eighth elected , from 2015 to 2019. He was registered Republican, . 2002 but ran as an independent.\n\nA former three-term Virgin Islands , Mapp served as the  from 1995 until 1999. Mapp was an independent candidate for Governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands in 2006 and , but was defeated both times by Democrat . He ran in the  for , defeating , the longtime Delegate to Congress, in a . Mapp ran for a second term in , but was defeated in the runoff election by Democrat .\n\n\nKenneth Ezra Mapp was born on November 2, 1955, in , to Al Mapp and Vashti Hewitt Mapp of St. Croix. He was one of four siblings. Mapp moved to  in the  in 1961, where he was raised by his maternal grandmother, Almina N. Hewitt, in . He graduated from  in 1973.\n\nMapp has attended  of  and the , but has not earned a bachelor's degree. After leaving office as lieutenant governor in 1999, however, he completed the six-week Advanced Management Program at  (which has no formal educational requirements) and received a  in  from the  at . Mapp also completed other fellowships at Harvard University and  in .\n\n\nMapp has worked as a  in  and a police officer in the . He joined the  soon after graduating from high school in 1973 and was based in the 83rd Police Precinct in Brooklyn. He later became a police officer in the Virgin Islands and was elected president of the Virgin Islands .\n\nMapp was elected as a  in the  in three separate elections. Mapp was elected to the 15th Legislature of the Virgin Islands in 1982, his first elected office. He would later be elected as a senator in the 18th and 20th Legislatures as well. He chaired the Committee on Public Safety and Judicial Affairs and was a standing member on the Committee on Finance.\nAdditionally, Mapp held other positions within the Virgin Islands government. He served as the assistant director of the Industrial Development Commission, which later became the Economic Development Authority. Mapp also became the director of the Consumer Services Administration, which is now the Department of Licensing and Consumer Affairs.\n\nIn 1994, gubernatorial candidate  chose Mapp as his  for lieutenant governor in the election. Schneider and Mapp jointly campaigned as independent candidates. Schneider and Mapp were elected Governor and Lt. Governor in a special gubernatorial  held on November 22, 1994. They defeated the Democratic gubernatorial ticket, which consisted of then-Lt. Gov.  and his running mate, .\n\nGovernor Roy Schneider and Lt. Governor Kenneth Mapp were  to a four-year term on January 2, 1995. However, Schneider and Mapp had a publicly strained relationship while in office and the two often did not speak to one another during their four-year tenure. Schneider and Mapp did not seek re-election in 1999. Instead, Schneider ran with Finance Commissioner Juan Centeno as his running mate and they were defeated in the election by Democratic candidate  and his running mate, , who were sworn in on January 4, 1999.\n\nAfter leaving office as lieutenant governor, Mapp earned a master's degree in  from Harvard University's  and completed the Advanced Management Program (AMP 159) at Harvard Business School. Though he ran for lieutenant governor as , Mapp had changed his party affiliation from  by 2001. Mapp did not run for governor in 2002. He campaigned for Governor Turnbull who was re-elected to a second term.\n\nIn 2002, Governor Charles Turnbull appointed Mapp as the Virgin Island's Public Finance Authority's Director of  and . Mapp raised millions of dollars for the government and , the territory's largest private sector employer. The Public Finance Authority acquired its first ever investment grade ratings on VI government-backed securities during Mapp's tenure. Mapp also managed several major capital projects and served on the Governor's financial and budget team. Mapp participated in budget hearings and prepared a variety of detailed analysis and reports. The Governor's financial team worked closely with department heads and legislators to develop and gain legislative approval of the annual territorial budgets.\n\nIn 2006, Mapp announced his candidacy for governor as an independent candidate with former Senator at Large  as his running mate. His two main opponents were businessman  and Senator . In the general election, de Jongh won 15,914 votes which equalled 49.33% of the total vote, Mapp won 9,100 of the total votes (equalling 26.78 percent) and Donatorg earned 7,871 votes, or 23.16 percent of the votes cast. De Jongh and Mapp, the two top candidates in terms of votes, were forced into a second runoff election on November 21, 2006, since no candidate earned more than 50% of the total votes cast. In the 2006 gubernatorial runoff, De Jongh was elected Governor with 16,644 votes (57.30%), while Mapp came in second, garnering 12,402 votes (42.70%).\n\n\nMapp formally announced his candidacy for Governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands in the  on August 20, 2010, at his headquarters on Saint Thomas. Mapp, who is running as an Independent rather than a Republican, picked , a  and department chair at the , as his running mate for lieutenant governor.\n\nMapp's main campaign platform included reducing crime and improving education in the Virgin Islands. Mapp promised to construct a technical school, promote economic growth while protecting the environment and pursue cleaner forms of energy if elected. The general election took  place on November 2, 2010. Incumbent governor  defeated Mapp in the election to win a second term in office. De Jongh earned 17,535 votes, or 56.27% of the vote, while Mapp came in second with 13,580 votes, or 43.58% of the vote. Mapp initially refused to concede, citing possible voting irregularities and the advice from his campaign advisor.\n\n\n* Campaign slogan: ''It’s Time To Build''\n\nMapp ran for Governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands in the , choosing Osbert Potter, a former Virgin Islands senator as his running mate. The general election was held on November 4, 2014. He received 47.47% of the vote, but since no candidate received the required 50%+1 as required by the , a runoff was held between him and , the two top vote receivers. The runoff was held on November 18, 2014, two weeks after the general election. Mapp went on to win the run-off election, receiving almost 64% of the vote.\n\n\n* Campaign slogan: ''Building Stronger and Smarter''\nMapp ran for reelection but lost with 44.67 percent of the vote to 's 55.04 percent in a run-off election.\n\n\nMapp was sworn in as the 8th elected Governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands on January 5, 2015. Upon taking office, Mapp requested $1 million to file a lawsuit against . He later signed legislation appropriating $1 million to further take legal action towards  and . To combat rising crime in the territory, Mapp formed alliance between the  and the . In addition, VIPD officers were sent to New York for training and mentorship. Mapp signed an executive order allowing  in the U.S. Virgin Islands following a  decision. In July 2015, Mapp became a member of the . His administration moved to sue HESS Corporation for $1.5 billion given the refinery immediate closure. Mapp created the Virgin Islands Climate Change Council through executive order. In December 2015, Mapp began a agreement with ArcLight Partners, LLC, to operate the oil storage terminal of  refinery.\n\nMapp implemented salary increases for government employees while his administration focused on raising the minimum wage from $7.25 to $10.50 over a three-year period. Worked with  on St. Croix oil refinery and met with  officials to attract Chinese tourists to the territory. In February 2017, Mapp faced a government fiscal crisis with over $2 billion in debt and a structural deficit of $110 million. Mapp provided the federal Medicaid program to all eligible Virgin Islands residents, giving vital health care access to many families who lacked health insurance and access to basic health care services. On September 5, 2017, Mapp declared a state of emergency in preparations for  which was followed by  thirteen days later. He met  on a ship off . Within ten months of the storms, over 130 members of Congress led by then House Minority Leader  were in the USVI seeing firsthand of the devastation. Mapp was successful in persuading  and received bipartisan support for several unprecedented amendments to the  as well as an estimated $9 billion of federal funds for the recovery and rebuilding of the territory. Mapp recruited local and national nonprofit organizations to join the recovery effort, including the , , the Clinton Global Initiative, and the Kenny Chesney Foundation. He also appealed help for the territory and received personnel and resources from his fellow governors , , and .\n\nMajor capital projects funded by the federal government started under Mapp tenure, such as the Veterans Drive Improvement Project and the Bridge To NowHere. Mapp offered free tuition to all local high school graduates attending the University of the Virgin Islands.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| education     = \n|spouse         = \n| website       = \n| signature     = Kyrsten Sinema Signature.svg\n| footnotes     = \n| module        = \n}}\n'''Kyrsten Lea Sinema''' ( ; born July 12, 1976) is an American politician and former social worker serving as the   from , a seat she has held since 2019. A former member of the , Sinema became an  in December 2022.\n\nSinema served three terms as a  for the  from 2005 to 2011, one term as the  for the 15th legislative district from 2011 to 2012, and three terms as the  for the  from 2013 to 2019. She began her political career in the  and rose to prominence for her  advocacy, supporting causes such as  and opposing the . She left the Green Party to join the  in 2004 and was elected to a seat in the  in . After her election, she joined the , the  and the  , amassing one of the most conservative voting records in the Democratic caucus. \n\nSinema won the  to replace the retiring , defeating  nominee . She is the  and the second openly  woman (after ) to be elected to the Senate. Sinema is also the first woman elected to the Senate from Arizona and the only religiously unaffiliated member of the Senate. She is one of four independents in the Senate, alongside , , and , all of whom caucus with the Democrats. \n\nSinema was considered a key swing vote in the Senate during the , when it was split 50–50 between Democrats and Republicans. On March 5, 2024, she announced she would not .\n\n\nSinema was born in , on July 12, 1976, to Marilyn (Wiley) and Dan Sinema. Sinema has an older brother and younger sister. Her father was an attorney. Her parents divorced when she was a child, and her mother, who had custody of the children, remarried. With her siblings, mother, and stepfather, Sinema moved to , a small town on the .\n\nSinema has said that when her stepfather lost his job and the bank foreclosed on their home, the family lived for three years in an abandoned  and that for two years they had no toilet or electricity while living there. She later recalled: \"My stepdad built a bunkbed for me and my sister. We separated our bunkbed from the kitchen with one of those big chalkboards on rollers. I knew that was weird. A chalkboard shouldn't be a wall. A kitchen should have running water.\"\n\nAccording to journalist  in '''', Sinema has given \"contradictory answers about her early life\", and her mother and stepfather have filed court documents saying they had made monthly payments for gas, electricity, and phone bills, even though Sinema had said they had been \"without running water or electricity\". Asked whether she had embellished details from her childhood, Sinema said, \"I've shared what I remember from my childhood. I know what I lived through.\"\n\nSinema was raised as a member of  (LDS Church). She graduated as valedictorian from  in DeFuniak Springs at age 16 and earned her  from  (BYU) in 1995 at age 18.Sanders, Rebekah L. \"\". ''The Arizona Republic''. Retrieved 7 July 2018. She left the LDS Church after graduating from BYU. Sinema returned to Arizona in 1995.\n\nWhile employed as a social worker, Sinema completed a  degree at  in 1999. In 2004, she earned a  degree from  and started working as a . In 2012, she earned a Ph.D. in justice studies from Arizona State and in 2018, she completed an online M.B.A. from the .\n\n\nIn 2003, Sinema became an adjunct professor teaching master's-level policy and grant-writing classes at Arizona State University School of Social Work and an adjunct business law professor at , formerly known as Phoenix School of Law. Sinema began her political career in the  before joining the  in 2004, and called herself a \" socialist\".\n\nIn 2000, Sinema worked on 's . In 2001 and 2002, she ran for local elected offices as an  and lost. In 2002, '''' published a letter from Sinema criticizing . She wrote: \"Until the average American realizes that capitalism damages her livelihood while augmenting the livelihoods of the wealthy, the Almighty Dollar will continue to rule.\" In 2003, she protested 's unsuccessful , telling the '''': \"He's a shame to . I don't even know why he's running. He seems to want to get  voting for him – what kind of strategy is that?\"\n\nWhile in the , Sinema was its local spokesperson, working to repeal the  and organizing . She had organized 15 antiwar rallies by the time the  began. She also opposed the . During a February 15, 2003, protest in  in Phoenix, a group led by Sinema distributed flyers portraying a U.S. service member as a skeleton \"inflicting 'U.S. terror' in Iraq and the Middle East\".\n\nIn a 2003 opinion piece, Sinema wrote that Presidents  and  were \"the real Saddam and Osama lovers\". When asked on a local radio show whether she would oppose someone joining the  and fighting on its behalf, Sinema responded: \"Fine ... I don't care if you want to do that, go ahead.\"\n\nIn a 2011 address to , Sinema called Arizona the \"meth lab of democracy\", in contrast to the \"laboratories of democracy\" in other states.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2002, Sinema first ran for the  as an  affiliated with the . She finished in last place in a five-candidate field, receiving 8 percent of the vote.\n\nSinema joined the  in 2004. That year, Sinema and  won the two seats for Arizona's 15th district, with 37 percent of the vote for Sinema and 34 percent for Lujan over incumbent representative . Sinema was reelected three times with over 30 percent of the vote. In 2008, Sinema completed the Harvard University  program for senior executives in state and local government as a David Bohnett LGBTQ Victory Institute Leadership Fellow. In 2009 and 2010, Sinema was an assistant Minority Leader for the Democratic Caucus of the Arizona House of Representatives.\n\n\nIn 2010, Sinema was elected to the , defeating  Bob Thomas, 63 to 37 percent.\n\n\nAccording to '''', \"her first public comment as an elected official came in 2005, after a Republican colleague's speech insulted LGBT people. 'We're simply people like everyone else who want and deserve respect', she passionately declared. Later, when reporters asked about her use of the first person, Sinema replied, 'Duh, I'm bisexual. In 2012, when running for U.S. House, Sinema said she did not remember disclosing her sexual orientation in 2005 and declined to discuss the significance of being the first openly bisexual member of the House.\n\nIn 2006, Sinema told a radio host that she was \"the most liberal member of the Arizona State Legislature\". Also in 2006, she sponsored a bill urging the adoption of the , and co-chaired Arizona Together, the statewide campaign that defeated , which would have banned the recognition of  and s in Arizona. In 2008, a similar referendum, , passed.\n\nIn 2006, Sinema was asked about \"new feminism\", and responded: \"These women who act like staying at home, leeching off their husbands or boyfriends, and just cashing the checks is some sort of feminism because they're choosing to live that life. That's bullshit. I mean, what the fuck are we really talking about here?\" After facing criticism, Sinema apologized and said the interview format was intended to be a \"lighthearted spoof\", adding: \"I was raised by a stay-at-home mom. So she did a pretty good job with me.\"\n\nSinema campaigned against Proposition , a referendum to ban the recognition of same-sex marriage and civil unions in Arizona. In 2008, she led the campaign against , another referendum that would have banned the recognition of same-sex marriage in Arizona. Proposition 102 was approved with 56% of the vote in the general election on November 4, 2008. Sinema chaired a coalition called Protect Arizona's Freedom, which defeated 's goal to place an initiative on the state ballot that would eliminate racial-preference programs.\n\nIn June 2009, Sinema was one of 32 state legislators appointed by President  to the White House Health Reform Task Force, which helped shape the . \"Thanks in part to her hard work in improving the bill\", she was invited to attend the Obamacare bill signing at the White House in March 2010.\n\nIn 2010, Sinema sponsored a bill to give in-state tuition to veterans; it was held in committee and did not receive a vote. Also in 2010, Sinema was named one of '''' magazine's \"40 Under 40\". The  gave Sinema its Award for the Advancement of Science and Reason in Public Policy in 2011.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn June 2011, Sinema said she was considering running for the  in . She lived in the same  neighborhood as incumbent Democratic congressman , but was adamant that she would not challenge another Democrat in a primary. On January 3, 2012, Sinema announced her bid for Congress, in the 9th congressional district. The district had previously been the 5th, represented by freshman Republican ; it contained 60 percent of the old 5th's territory. Schweikert had been drawn into the 6th districtthe old 3rd districtand sought reelection there.\n\nAlthough Sinema was not required to resign her State Senate seat under Arizona's s (since she was in the final year of her term), she did so on the same day that she announced her candidacy. On August 28, 2012, Sinema won the three-way Democratic primary with nearly 42 percent of the vote. Her opponents, state Senator  and former  chairman , a former speechwriter in the , each finished with less than 30 percent of the vote.\n\nIn the general election, Sinema ran against Republican nominee Vernon Parker, the former mayor of . She was endorsed by ''''. The campaign was described as a \"nasty\", \"bitterly fought race that featured millions of dollars in s\". Parker ran s that accused Sinema of being an \"anti-American \" who practiced \" rituals\". The Republican-aligned outside group  spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on attack ads against Sinema. When her religious views were raised as an issue, her campaign said that she simply believes in a  approach to government.\n\nThe November 6 election was initially too close to call, because Arizona election authorities failed to count more than 25 percent of the votes on election day. Sinema held a narrow lead over Parker, while provisional and absentee ballots were still being counted. On November 12, when it was apparent that Sinema's lead was too large for Parker to overcome, the  called the race for Sinema.\n\nOnce all ballots were counted, Sinema won by 4 percentage points, over 10,000 votes.  Powell Gammill finished third with 7 percent of the votes.\n\nSinema is the  and  (after Senator  of ) elected to the United States Congress.\n\n\n\nSinema ran for reelection in 2014 and was unopposed in the Democratic primary, which took place on August 26, 2014. She faced Republican  in the general election.\n\nAccording to '''', Sinema considered herself bipartisan. It was drawn as a \"fair-fight\" district, and President  won the district by four points in 2012. In September 2014, she was endorsed for reelection by the , becoming one of five Democrats to be endorsed by the Chamber in the 2014 congressional election cycle. She was reelected with approximately 55 percent of the vote, beating Rogers by 13 points.\n\n\n\nUnopposed in her primary, Sinema won the general election with 61 percent of the vote. Her opponent, Republican nominee Dave Giles, received 39 percent.\n\n\nFollowing her election to Congress, Sinema shifted toward the political center, joining the conservative Democratic  and the bipartisan  and amassing a \"reliably moderate-Democratic\" voting record. Sinema worked for the adoption of the , hiring DREAM Act advocate  as a district outreach staffer.\n\nOn the House Financial Services Committee, Sinema supported the  of 2013, which sought to exempt certain financial instruments from some Dodd-Frank restrictions. Bank lobbyists drafted key amendments, which appeared word-for-word in the bill she supported in the committee and on the House floor. It passed the House, with only 119 Democrats and three Republicans opposing it, but failed to advance in the Senate banking committee., '''', Michael Daly, March 13, 2023. Retrieved March 15, 2023.\n\nSinema co-sponsored other anti-regulation bills, including the Systemic Risk Designation Improvement Act of 2015, which includes provisions that Silicon Valley Bank President  called for in testimony before Congress that year. That measure also failed to pass.\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn September 28, 2017, Sinema officially announced her  for the Class I United States Senate seat held by  incumbent , who declined to seek reelection the next month.\n\nIn March 2018, Sinema donated to charity $33,800 in campaign contributions she had received from , a prominent Democratic donor who came under scrutiny after a homeless escort died of a drug overdose at his California home in 2017. She had previously donated to charity $53,400 in campaign contributions from people with ties to , a website that was seized by the  after it was accused of knowingly accepting ads for sex with underage girls.\n\n filings released in April 2018 showed Sinema had raised over $8.2 million, more than the three leading Republican primary contenders combined.\n\nDuring the 2018 campaign, Sinema refused to debate her competitor in the Democratic primary, Deedra Abboud, an attorney and community activist. Sinema won the August Democratic primary for the Senate seat. Her Republican opponent in the general election was fellow Arizona U.S. Representative and eventual Senate colleague . Sinema received the endorsement of the .\n\nWhile Abboud said she would vote against the nomination of  to the , Sinema \"said she wanted to delve deeper into Kavanaugh's writings and interview him personally before deciding\". She said she was \"running on the issues people care about most, including offering quality, affordable health care and promoting economic opportunity\".\n\nIn the summer of 2018, Sinema said she would vote against  for  if elected to the U.S. Senate. \"The Democratic leadership has failed Democrats across the country,\" she said. \"I am unafraid to say what I believe about what I think our party needs to do and I think our party needs to grow and change.\"\n\nJournalist Jonathan Martin wrote in ''The New York Times'' in September 2018 that Sinema was running \"one of the most moderate-sounding and cautious Senate campaigns this year, keeping the media at arms-length and avoiding controversial issues\", and said her campaign was generally reluctant to bring up President . According to Martin, both Republicans and Democrats said that Sinema had \"few major legislative accomplishments to her record\" and was running \"on a political image that she has shaped and reshaped over the years. And nothing is more central to it now than her childhood homelessness.\"\n\nOn November 12, many news sources called the U.S. Senate race for Sinema, and the Republican nominee, , conceded. Sinema was sworn in with the  on January 3, 2019.\n\nSinema is the first woman to represent Arizona in the United States Senate. She is also the first Democrat elected to represent Arizona in the chamber since , who held her current seat from 1977 to 1995.\n\n\nSinema was sworn in as a member of the U.S. Senate on January 3, 2019. During the  ceremony, led by Vice President , she decided to be sworn in not on the traditional Bible, but on copies of the  and the . She is the senior U.S. senator from Arizona; the junior U.S. senator for Arizona is Democrat . Kelly defeated Sinema's 2018 general election opponent, Martha McSally, who was appointed to fill the Senate seat vacated upon the resignation of , who had been appointed to fill the Senate seat vacated upon the death of .\n\nOn February 14, 2019, Sinema voted to confirm  as .\n\nDuring the , Sinema was noted for her use of colorful wigs. Her spokeswoman explained that Sinema wore them to emphasize the importance of : by wearing wigs, she did not need to go to a hair salon.\n\nSinema voted to convict Donald Trump in both his  and  impeachment trials.\n\nSinema urged Senate colleagues to vote in favor of the proposed  to further investigate the  on January 6, 2021. In a joint statement with Senator , she said, \"we implore our Senate Republican colleagues to work with us to find a path forward on a commission to examine the events of January 6th.\" Sinema was one of two Senate Democrats who did not vote on it, the other being Senator  of . Murray and Sinema both cited a \"personal family matter\" for their absence.\n\nIn October 2021, five of the veterans Sinema had selected for her advisory council as liaisons to the Arizona service member community resigned. Their resignation letter accused her of \"answering to big donors rather than your own people\" and criticized her opposition to key Democratic Party issues, such as abolishing the filibuster and aspects of Biden's .\n\nSinema's stance on the filibuster was sharply criticized by others in her party and her consituents. On January 22, 2022, the   voted to censure Sinema for voting with Senate Republicans to maintain the filibuster, preventing passage of a . The same year, the Arizona Youth Climate Coalition and the Tucson Climate Coalition worked on a pressure campaign to persuade Sinema to abolish the modern filibuster. The campaign included an open letter and petition signed by over 150 Arizona legislators, constituents, and climate action leaders, including her personal friend, Arizona Sierra Club director Sandy Bahr. The letter and an accompanying op-ed published in the ''Arizona Daily Star'' persuaded her office to meet her critics on February 24, 2022. The meeting was ultimately unsuccessful.\n\nSinema was the only U.S. elected official to attend the , an annual private gathering of the European and North American . About 120 high-level politicians, CEOs, national security experts, academics and journalists from 21 countries attended the closed-door meeting.\n\nIn December 2022, Sinema announced that she had left the Democratic Party and registered as an independent. She continued to caucus with the Democratic Party for committee assignments.\n\nLate in 2023, Sinema was brought in as the medium between liberal Democrat  of Connecticut and conservative Republican  of Oklahoma to negotiate a bill to handle the . Days before the vote, pressure from Trump reduced Republican support from 20 senators to the four that voted in favor. Before the voting, Sinema admonished the defectors for playing \"political theater\" and said \"the Senate has failed Arizona\". On March 5, 2024, Sinema announced that she would retire from Congress at the end of her term and not seek reelection, saying that her approach to fostering compromise seemed to be \"a model of the past\".\n\n\n'''Source:'''\n* \n** \n** \n** \n** \n** \n* \n**  (Chair)\n** \n** \n** \n* \n** \n**  (Chair)\n* \n*  (116th Congress)\n*  (116th-118th Congress)\n** \n** \n** \n\n\nSinema has been described as a  and a , being generally socially liberal but fiscally moderate-to-conservative. She has cited U.S. Senator , a Democrat from West Virginia, as a role model.\n\nIn the House of Representatives, Sinema was a member of the  and the . According to the Bipartisan Index created by the Lugar Center and the , Sinema was the sixth most bipartisan member of the U.S. House of Representatives during the first session of the . The ''''s 2013 vote ratings placed Sinema near the center of their – scale. In 2015, she voted with the majority of her party 73% of the time. In 2015 and 2016, Sinema did not vote for  for . In 2016, the ''National Journal'' gave her a composite ideology score of 57% liberal and 43% conservative. She was one of the most conservative House Democrats during her House tenure.\n\nAccording to '''', Sinema has a  to  voting record in the Senate, to the right of Republican Senators  and . According to '''', as of January 2021, Sinema had voted in line with Donald Trump's position on legislation about 50% of the time. As a result, the Arizona Democratic Party suggested censuring her. But after delaying the vote and watering down the resolution from a censure to an advisement, the Party ultimately  the resolution.\n\nAccording to ''FiveThirtyEight'', as of July 2022, Sinema had voted with President Biden's position on legislative issues 94% of the time.\n\nIn December 2022, Sinema changed her party registration to .\n\n\nWhen asked about '''' in 2018, Sinema said the ruling should not be overturned and that she supports a woman's . In 2020, she had a 100% rating from the abortion-rights organization , and a 0% rating from the  organization Campaign for Working Families. She was endorsed by , an abortion-rights-focused political action committee, until 2022, when she voted with Republicans against changing the filibuster to allow passage of the Freedom to Vote and . That vote also cost her the support of the abortion-rights advocacy group . After  in June 2022, Sinema said the decision \"endangers the health and well-being of women in Arizona and across America.\"\n\n\nWhile working as a spokesperson for the , Sinema worked to repeal the death penalty. In her 2009 book, ''Unite and Conquer'', she explained her stance on capital punishment, writing that she opposed it \"because I think no civilized society should use it as a punishment\", though \"since we have the death penalty in Arizona, I want to ensure that it's being implemented as fairly and judiciously as possible\".\n\nAccording to '''', while serving in the Arizona State Legislature, she introduced more bills regarding the death penalty than bills regarding military or veterans' families. In 2007, she introduced HB 2278, which would require the  to \"strike\" any prior death sentence and \"enter in its place a sentence of natural life\", as in .\n\nSinema has served as an Advisory Board Member of the . She was also a presenter at their 2010 Spring Conference, which was co-sponsored by  and the  of Arizona.\n\nIn 2017, Sinema and 47 other House Democrats voted with the majority of House Republicans on H.R. 115,  of 2017, which was opposed by the . The bill would \"expand the list of statutory aggravating factors in death penalty determinations\" to include the killing or targeting of a , , or .\n\n\nOn February 5, 2019, Sinema voted for a bill that would make improvements to certain defense and security assistance provisions, authorize the appropriation of funds to Israel, and reauthorize the United States-Jordan Defense Cooperation Act of 2015. On March 13, 2019, she voted to remove the United States Armed Forces from hostilities in the Republic of Yemen that have not been authorized by Congress.\n\n\nSinema has voted for federal stimulus spending. She has said: \"Raising taxes is more economically sound than cutting vital social services.\"\n\nIn 2015, Sinema was one of just seven House Democrats to vote in favor of a Republican-backed bill to repeal the , which affects about 0.2% of Americans in the U.S. each year (estates of $5.43 million or more for individuals, or $10.86 million or more for couples). That same year, she voted to change the 's leadership from a single director to a bipartisan commission.\n\nIn 2016, with Republican representative  of New York, Sinema cosponsored the Working Parents Flexibility Act (H.R. 4699). This legislation would establish a tax-free \"parental savings account\" in which employers and parents could invest savings tax-free, with unused funds eligible to be \"rolled into qualifying retirement, college savings or ABLE accounts for people with disabilities without tax penalties\". In September 2018, she voted \"to make  passed by the GOP [in 2017] permanent\". She was one of three Democrats to break with her party and vote for the tax cuts being made permanent.\n\nOn July 30, 2019, Sinema and Senator  released a proposal under which new parents would be authorized to advance their child tax credit benefits in order to receive a $5,000 cash benefit upon either birth or adoption of a child. The parents' child tax credit would then be reduced by $500 for each year of the following decade.\n\nIn 2022, several provisions of the  were changed after negotiations with Sinema: a provision narrowing the  loophole was dropped, a 1% excise tax on stock buybacks was added, and manufacturing exceptions were added to the corporate minimum tax.\n\n\nOn February 12, 2021, Sinema became the second Democratic senator after  to announce her opposition to including a $15/hour minimum wage as part of a  relief bill. On March 5, 2021, Sinema voted against an increase of the federal  to $15 an hour, proposed by Senator  as part of the . She did so by flashing a thumbs-down, and some commentators compared her demeanor to that of former Arizona senator , who had voted with a dramatic thumbs-down gesture in 2017; others compared her to former French queen , to whom the phrase \"\" is attributed. Sinema's office responded that any commentary on her clothes and demeanor was sexist. Her vote was at odds with that of fellow Democrat , the  , who supports a $15/hour minimum wage.\n\n\nIn February 2019, Sinema was one of 20 senators to sponsor the Employer Participation in Repayment Act, enabling employers to contribute up to $5,250 to their employees' student loans.\n\n\nIn 2019, Sinema was one of four Democratic-caucusing senators to join all Republicans in voting against the , a  program that aims to address  and economic inequality, while most other Democrats voted \"\". In April 2019, Sinema was one of three Democrats who voted with Republicans to confirm , a former oil executive, as Secretary of the Interior Department.\n\nOn February 12, 2019, Sinema voted along with the whole Senate for the Natural Resources Management Act, which provides for the management of the natural resources of the United States.\n\nIn 2022, Sinema voted for the , a major piece of climate and energy legislation designed to invest in renewable energy, which includes billions of dollars for drought relief.\n\n\nSinema supports the use of military force to stop , such as in ,  and . She wrote a doctoral dissertation on the 1994  that Lexington Books published in 2015 under the title ''''.\n\nSinema was opposed to the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq and helped organize anti-war protests while a law student at Arizona State University. Sinema was involved in organizing a Phoenix-area group called the Arizona Alliance for Peaceful Justice (AAPJ). According to Josh Lederman of '''', \"The group's mission statement at the time called military action 'an inappropriate response to terrorism' and advocated for using the legal systemnot violenceto bring  and others to justice.\"\n\nAs an antiwar activist in the years after , Sinema \"led a group that distributed flyers depicting an American soldier as a skeleton inflicting 'U.S. terror' in Iraq and the Middle East.\" The flyers \"promoted a February 2003 rally organized by Local to Global Justice, an anti-war group Sinema co-founded\". Sinema was described in news reports as an organizer and sponsor of the rally and was listed as the point of contact for the event. One flyer referred to \" and his ,  war\", saying, \"Government is slavery\", and describing laws as \"cobwebs for the rich and chains of steel for the poor\". CNN said that such positions were \"a contrast from the more moderate profile she has developed since her 2012 election to Congress\".\n\nIn 2005 and 2006, she co-hosted an  radio show with  . In 2006, Sinema said she opposed \"war in all its forms\", and wrote: \"As one of the core organizers against the war from day one (September 12, 2001), I have always and will always continue to oppose war in all its forms.\"\n\nAfter joining Congress in 2012, she said her views on military force had \"evolved\", and that \"you should never take military intervention off the table. When you do so, you give an out to a rogue nation or rogue actors.\" Lederman reported that \"she said she favors aggressive diplomacy, crippling sanctions to combat proliferation, and swift, multilateral intervention as a last resort\". Since joining Congress, she has voted against the  and supported Trump's missile attack on Syria.\n\n\nSinema favors  measures such as requiring background checks on gun sales between private citizens at gun shows, and requiring a license for gun possession. In 2014 and 2018 the  (NRA-PVF), which opposes gun regulations, gave Sinema a \"D\" rating.  gave her a 17% rating.\n\n\n\nSinema voted against repealing the , but has called for reforms to the law. In a 2012 congressional campaign debate, she said the health care law was not perfect, and that in Congress she would work to amend it to make it work effectively. Sinema voted to delay the imposition of fines on those who did not purchase insurance in 2014. She also voted to repeal the Medical Device Tax and for the Keep Your Health Plan Act of 2013.\n\nSpeaking about healthcare policy, Sinema said, \"I used to say that I wanted universal health-care coverage in Arizona, which went over like a ton of bricks. Turns out, Arizonans hear the word 'universal' and think 'socialism'or 'pinko commie'. But when I say that I want all Arizonans to have access to affordable, quality health care, Arizonans agree wholeheartedly. Same basic idea, different language.\"\n\nIn 2021, Sinema opposed prescription drug pricing reform proposals in House and Senate versions of a Democrat-crafted spending bill. On October 8, 2021, '''' reported:\n\n}}\n\nSinema and Senator  met with President Biden the same day to discuss their concerns with the bills. Observers have noted that Sinema is one of the largest beneficiaries of pharmaceutical political action committee money in Congress, and has been described as a \"Pharma Favorite\". KHN reported: \"For the 2019–20 election cycle through March, political action committees run by employees of drug companies and their trade groups gave her $98,500 in campaign funds, Kaiser Health News' Pharma Cash to Congress database shows. That stands out in a Congress in which a third of the members got no pharma cash for the period and half of those who did got $10,000 or less.\" Sinema's haul was \"twice that of Sen. Susan Collins of Maine, considered one of the most vulnerable Republicans in November, and approached that of fellow Democrat Steny Hoyer, the powerful House majority leader from Maryland.\" Senator  indirectly called her out, saying: \"Take a hard look at those people who are opposed to strong legislation to lower the cost of prescription drugs, and take a look at their campaign-finance reports. See where they get their money, how many of them get their money from the pharmaceutical industry, and the executives there. And I think there will be a direct correlation.\" On October 18, 2021, ''Politico'' reported:\n\n}}\n\n\nAccording to a profile in '''', \"Sinema has her sights set on advancing  rights.\" She has a history of policy advocacy regarding LGBT rights and issues. In 2006, Sinema was among the leading opponents of a proposed amendment to the Arizona state constitution which would have banned s and s. The proposal failed in Arizona, the first time that a state rejected a ban on same-sex marriage, but a second proposed amendment banning only same-sex marriage passed in 2008 with Sinema in opposition again. She supports same-sex marriage,  recognition, and adding  to anti-discrimination laws.\n\nIn 2013, Sinema co-sponsored Rep. 's letter, which opposed  for \"the use of \".\n\nIn December 2022, Sinema was a lead cosponsor and negotiator on the , which passed the Senate, 61–36.\n\n\n on the day of the SB 1070's signing|alt=A woman in her thirties with fairly short blond hair, wearing sunglasses and a beige and pink top, is surrounded by a crowd.]]\n\nSinema co-sponsored the Southwest Border Security Threat Assessment Act (H.R. 4482), a bill that calls for border threat analysis of terrorism, smuggling, and human trafficking every five years.\n\nSinema was one of 24 House Democrats to vote in favor of , a bill that would expand maximum sentences for foreigners who attempt to reenter the country, legally or illegally, after having been deported, denied entry or removed, and for foreign felons who attempt to reenter the country.\n\nSinema voted for the , which expanded the  screening process to require signatures from the , the , and the  for each refugee entering the country.\n\nSinema opposed . She has argued that mass deportation of undocumented immigrants is not an option and supported the . Her 2012 campaign website stated that \"we need to create a tough but fair path to citizenship for undocumented workers that requires them to get right with the law by paying back taxes, paying a fine and learning English as a condition of gaining citizenship.\" In July 2018, she broke with her party by voting with Republicans against abolishing .\n\nThe , a PAC that seeks to limit both legal and illegal immigration, gave Sinema a 33% rating in 2018, and , which supports a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, gave Sinema a score of 88% in 2014.\n\nOn March 14, 2019, Sinema voted against Trump's National Emergency declaration on border security.\n\nOn February 4, 2021, Sinema voted against providing COVID-19 pandemic financial support to undocumented immigrants.\n\n\nIn June 2013, Sinema became one of 29 original cosponsors of the bipartisan LIBERT-E (Limiting Internet and Blanket Electronic Review of Telecommunications and Email) Act, along with Representative . The legislation would limit the  (NSA) to only collecting electronic information from subjects of an investigation.\n\nIn July 2013, Sinema joined a bipartisan majority and voted against an amendment to a defense appropriations bill (offered by Amash) to prohibit the NSA from monitoring and recording details of U.S. citizens' telecommunications without a warrant.\n\n\nEarly in her career, Sinema expressed enthusiasm about evading the  through the .\n\nOn January 25, 2021, a spokesperson for Sinema told '''' that she is \"against eliminating the filibuster\" and \"not open to changing her mind\" on the issue. Additionally, Sinema has spoken out on the elimination of the judicial filibuster as a key reason for increased politicization of the .\n\nIn January 2022, Sinema and Democratic Senate colleague Joe Manchin voted against changing the Senate filibuster rule. The proposed rule change, which would have allowed certain voting rights bills to advance to the Senate floor without meeting the Senate's 60-vote threshold, was voted down by a 52-48 margin. Days later, the Arizona Democratic Party executive committee censured Sinema for voting to retain the filibuster rule.\n\n\nIn 2016, Sinema was one of five House Democrats to vote for a Republican-backed bill barring the  (FCC) from regulating broadband rates. Her vote broke from her party; other Democrats were strongly opposed to the measure, and President Obama said he would veto it if it passed.\n\nIn 2019, Sinema was the sole Senate Democrat not to co-sponsor the Save the Internet Act, which would restore Obama-era regulations preventing s from throttling consumers' website traffic. She worked with Senate Republican  to develop their own  bill.\n\n\n\nSinema married, and later divorced, her BYU classmate Blake Dain. She is . She has been reported to be the only  member of , although she has rejected the label. Sinema's campaign stated that \"the terms '''', '''' or '''' are not befitting of her life's work or personal character\".\n\n\nSinema has completed numerous . In 2019, she completed a marathon in 3:28:17, which was fast enough for her (female) age group to qualify for the . Two weeks before her Boston-qualifying race, she ran a three-mile race in 20:42, setting a record for women in Congress. In 2020, she set a personal record of 3:21:45 and later in 2021, she broke her right foot while running a marathon, requiring her to use a hands-free crutch.\n\nOn November 17, 2013, Sinema completed an  in a little over 15 hours. She was the second active member of Congress, after Senator , to finish a long-distance , and the first to complete an Ironman-branded race. She completed the  in .\n\nOn December 25, 2013, Sinema climbed to the summit of .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. Senate website\n* \n* \n* \n\n*  official Arizona Senate website (archived)\n*  at * \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n ''|years=since January 3, 2019}}\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Laura Miller''' (born November 18, 1958) is an American journalist and politician who served as the 57th  of ,  from 2002 through 2007. She decided not to run for re-election in 2007. She was the third woman to serve as mayor of Dallas.\n\n\nLaura Miller was born in . She attended the , where she graduated with a degree in political science and journalism in 1980.\n\n\n\n\nMiller spent the early part of her career as a  working as a staff writer for '''' and '''' and then as a columnist for the '''' and the now-defunct ''''. In 1991, Miller became an investigative reporter for the '''' and then a columnist for ''''.\n\n\nIn 1998, Miller was elected to the Dallas City Council representing  and southwest Dallas. In 2002, Miller was elected as Mayor of Dallas, replacing  who left the post to run for the  position vacated by retiring Texas Senator .\n\nShe fought for and won approval of a strengthened , an ordinance prohibiting discrimination on the basis of , a revamped  system, a $23 million homeless assistance center, major changes to the city's  Corridor improvement plan and a taxpayer-funded  redevelopment effort.\n\nShe participated in an agreement between , the ,  and  to revise the  at , which involved: replacing geographic limitations on Love Field service with: flight caps determined by a limitation on the number of gates allowed at Love Field, restrictions on the rights of any new air carrier to service North Texas via any airport other than DFW Airport, and banning international commercial air travel at Love Field.  The unique agreement and resulting oligopoly required an exemption from federal antitrust laws, which Miller also successfully helped obtain.\n\nDavid Levey, executive vice president for , credited Miller for reviving a $250 million deal to renovate downtown's long vacant .\n\nDuring her term, the  announced plans to build  and many citizens hoped it would be built in Dallas. The city and the Dallas Cowboys, however, failed to reach a deal and the stadium was built in .\n\nShe announced parade plans for the  championship in 2006, prior to the Mavericks losing four straight games and ultimately the NBA championship to the  in six games.\n\nMiller was succeeded in office by Republican .\n\nIn May 2019. Miller made an unsuccessful run for Dallas City Council to represent District 13.\n\n\nLaura Miller serves as Director of Projects, Texas, for Summit Power Group, a Seattle-based developer of wind, solar and gas-fired power plants. Summit was recently selected by the  to receive a $350 million cost-sharing award to build the world’s first  (Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle) clean-coal power plant located near . The low-emissions project, called the Texas Clean Energy Project, is projected to capture just under 3 million tons a year of carbon dioxide, which will be used for  in the .\n\nMiller's other environmental accomplishments included the formation and co-leading (with former Houston mayor ) of the Texas Clean Air Cities Coalition, made up of 36 cities, counties and school districts in Texas that opposed the construction of 11 coal plants (which would have used older technology) by , a Dallas-based energy company. Ultimately, TXU (now called Energy Future Holdings) officially suspended its plans to build eight of the eleven plants.  As a result of these efforts, Miller won a 2008 Climate Protection Award from the  for this nationally-recognized effort, which has been memorialized in a documentary film, produced and narrated by , and entitled ''Fighting Goliath: The Texas Coal Wars''.\n\n\nMiller is married to Dallas attorney and former Texas  . They have three children.\n\nIn 1998, Miller was diagnosed with breast cancer. She underwent chemotherapy and radiation treatments which effectively eradicated the cancer.\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Leevin Taitano Camacho''' is a  lawyer who served as fourteenth (fifth elected) . He was elected on November 6, 2018, defeating former attorney general  with 67% of the vote. Inaugurated on January 7, 2019, Camacho succeeded .\n\n\nCamacho was born to Lolita San Nicolas Taitano (Familian Asan and Familian Lucas) and Vincent G. Camacho (Familian Santiago and Familian Victoriano). The Camachos were a military family. He attended  followed by the .\n\n\nAfter graduating from  in 2005, Camacho returned to Guam where he  for the .\n\n\nCamacho is a founder of , an activist movement opposed to military buildup on Guam. He also was involved with Save Southern Guam, successfully convincing the  to revoke construction permits for a hotel project in .\n\n\n\nIn a primary election on August 25, 2018, Camacho garnered the most votes (nearly 50%) despite accusations of inexperience from his opponents. He went on to win the general election against Douglas Moylan in November. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCamacho is married to Jennifer \"Jen\" Crisostomo Camacho (Familian Beyong and Familian BeckPing); they have two children, Matua and Tanom.\n\nCamacho enjoys sports and competes in s.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* at the \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Lee Jin Carter''' (born June 2, 1987) is an American former politician who represented the  in the  from 2018 to 2022. A member of the , he defeated , the Republican House Majority , to win the seat. Born in , Carter is an  and a former . The first openly  state delegate in the United States since 1929, Carter served on the Finance Committee and the Militia, Police and Public Safety Committee. In 2017, he was endorsed by the  (DSA), of which he was then a member.\n\nAs a Marine, Carter went to Kuwait and the Mediterranean. His unit, the , was also one of the first to respond to the . In 2021, Carter ran for  in the . He came in fifth of the five candidates in the Democratic primary with less than 3% of the vote, losing to , and also lost the primary for renomination for his House seat.\n\n\n in Kuwait in 2009]]\nCarter was born June 2, 1987, in , . He was a member of the  (USMC) from 2006 to 2011, having attended the . During his time in the U.S. Marine Corps, Carter completed tours in the Middle East and the Mediterranean. His unit, the , was also one of the first to respond to the .\n\nCarter earned an  from the  in 2017. He worked as an IT specialist before running for office.\n\n\n\n\nCarter was inspired to run for office after receiving a shock while repairing a lighting system in the summer of 2015 and subsequently struggling to receive worker's compensation from Virginia while unable to work. Before choosing to run, he had long identified as \"to the left of where the Democratic party [is]\" but was further inspired by  to explore .\n\nCarter ran for the  for the . He was endorsed by the  (DSA), of which he has been a member since April 2017. His campaign mostly focused on issues such as  and . , the incumbent Republican, distributed a mailer campaign that compared Carter to Communist rulers , , and , an act the  condemned as . Miller called Carter an \"anti-jobs candidate\", and said his \"ideas are so out of the mainstream, and so incredibly expensive\". During the campaign, Carter claimed he had little support from the state's Democratic Party, saying their resources were \"stretched thin\" but that the DSA had \"managed to knock on thousands of doors\" on his behalf. On November 7, 2017, Carter won the race by nine percentage points. He was one of 15 DSA members elected in 2017.\n\n\n\nCarter ran for reelection in the , defeating his primary opponent, Manassas city councilman Mark Wolfe, by 57.7% to 42.3% of the vote.\n\nIn the general election, Carter defeated Republican Ian Lovejoy, another Manassas city councilman, by 53.3% to 46.5% of the vote. Carter was endorsed by U.S. Senator , who campaigned with Carter in Manassas the day before the election.\n\n\nOn January 1, 2021, Carter announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for governor of Virginia. He also ran for renomination as delegate but had two challengers. Carter lost both the  and the Democratic primary for delegate, the latter of which was won by attorney Michelle Lopes-Maldonado. After the losses, he announced his retirement from electoral politics and endorsed the Independent candidate Princess Blanding for governor.\n\n\nDuring Carter's remarks on a tax bill during the 2018 legislative session, fellow Democratic Delegate  briefly displayed the  on a laptop behind Carter, an action for which he later apologized; Keam also apologized for violating Rule 57 in regard to the legislative body's decorum (\"No member shall in debate use any language or gesture calculated to wound, offend, or insult another member\"). Carter dismissed the affair as \"clearly ... a joke, but ... in very poor taste and rooted in a lack of knowledge about the history of the political left.\"\n\n\n\n\nCarter opposes the death penalty under all circumstances, and introduced a bill in the House of Delegates to abolish it in Virginia.\n\n\nCarter introduced legislation in the 2020 session that would prohibit Virginia prisons and jails from strip-searching minors before visitation. The bill passed unanimously in subcommittee.\n\n\nCarter supports the right to keep and bear arms, and has opposed proposed assault weapons bans in Virginia as a \"terrible idea\". He opposes , since he believes they result in right-wing extremists abusing the process to disarm their opposition, and has voted against prohibiting guns on the property of the Virginia State Capitol, the only Democrat to do so.\n\n\nCarter introduced legislation in the 2020 session that would cap the monthly copay for  at $30. The bill passed and was signed into law at a $50 monthly copay cap.\n\n\nCarter is autistic, and opposes public funding for  in the treatment of , a controversial therapy when used to attempt to treat the condition. He has likened ABA to conversion therapy. Carter said in a statement that \"There is zero difference between ABA and punishing deaf kids to make them read lips instead of signing. Which is what institutions used to do to them decades ago.\" Carter opposes , and has called the organization a .\n\n\nCarter was the only Democrat to vote against a bipartisan bill in 2021 to require schools to provide at least three specialized student support positions. The bill passed and was signed by Governor .\n\n\nSince taking office, Carter has been an outspoken advocate for workers' rights. In December 2018 he introduced House Bill 1806, which would overturn Virginia's 70-year-old . Of the bill, Carter said, \"When workers form a union, everyone in the workplace benefits from higher wages and better conditions. ...  was created specifically to allow some people to stand opposed to their coworkers' union while still reaping the rewards for free. It was intentionally designed to bankrupt unions, and I'm fighting to end it.\"\n\nIn late 2019, after Carter introduced or supported bills overturning restrictions on the ability of Virginia state employees to strike, he received a wave of death threats on social media, as critics mistook the exception of police officers from the bills for a case of their right to strike being removed. These threats were severe and credible enough that Carter spent the day at an undisclosed safe location on January 20, 2020, the day a gun rights rally was organized at the Virginia State Capitol. This coincided with the declaration of a state of emergency by Northam in response to potential violence at the rally.\n\nIn the 2020 session, Carter introduced a bill to address pay disparities for certain categories of workers. One bill would prevent employers from categorizing employees as \"tipped employees\" if state or federal regulations prohibit those employees from accepting tips. This bill targeted workers at  and , who are classified as tipped employees and are ineligible from receiving minimum wage even though they are prohibited from receiving tips.\n\n\nCarter endorsed  for president in 2020, and co-chaired his Virginia campaign.\n\n\nCarter has been married and divorced three times. He has a daughter with his second wife. In October 2018, to get ahead of any potential attempts at \"personal smears\", Carter admitted making \"homophobic, transphobic, sometimes sexist or racially insensitive\" comments online as a teenager.\n\nOn July 2, 2021, Carter's longtime partner Violet Rae announced their engagement on Twitter.\n\nWhile serving as a Virginia delegate, Carter also worked as a  driver.\n\nCarter is , and has expressed positions belonging to the .\n\nOn July 10, 2024, Carter began posting a series of introspective tweets about his gender, and his realization of being . Five days later, Carter announced he was stepping away from public life following allegations of sexual misconduct.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Manka Dhingra''' (born 1973 or 1974) is an Indian-born American attorney and politician who is a . A member of the , she was elected to represent the , on 's  in , during a . Dhingra is the first  elected to any state legislature in the United States.\n\nDhingra, an Indian immigrant, founded the woman's advocacy organization API Chaya in 1996, and later worked under several elected officials at the state level. She joined the 's office in 2000 and has led the department's expanding mental health and veterans courts.\n\n\n\nDhingra was born in , India to a  family; her father worked for  and her mother was a schoolteacher. After her father died of , Dhingra moved to California with her mother at the age of 13, joining her relatives. She graduated from the , earning a  in history and political science in 1995, before moving with her husband Harjit Singh to .\n\n\n\nDhingra founded Chaya, a non-profit organization to combat domestic violence against South Asian women, in 1996. She would later work in the offices of  justice  and the  , while earning a degree from the  in 1999. Dhingra joined the 's office in 2000 and served as a Senior Deputy Prosecuting Attorney for King County; she was last in that role in 2021. Her work in the office's mental health court and the  earned membership in various mental health and anti-hate crime advocacy organizations.\n\nDhingra identified herself as a nonpartisan prior to the . A few months after attending her first Democratic meeting, she declared her candidacy for the  created by the death of  . Dhingra defeated Jinyoung Englund, the Republican nominee, on November 7, 2017, with 55% of the votes. Dhingra's election overturned the Republican  in the , giving the  complete control over the state's government for the first time since 2012. She was sworn in on November 29 and became the first Sikh woman to enter a state legislature. Dhingra was named as the deputy majority leader in the Senate and assigned as the chair of the Behavioral Health Subcommittee. She retained the 45th district seat by being re-elected in 2018 and 2022.\n\nShe is running in the  to become . The incumbent, Democrat , is running for Washington State Governor.\n\n\n\nDhingra met her husband, Harjit Singh, while at the University of California, Berkeley. Singh works for  in Redmond. The couple have two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Charles Matthew Fariss''' (born May 11, 1968) is an American businessman and politician. An  in the 2023 election following criminal charges discussed below, he was first elected to the  in 2011, as a . He represented the 59th district, made up of  and  counties, and parts of , , and  counties between  and .\n\n\nFariss grew up on a farm. After graduating from , he went into farming himself, and expanded into other related businesses, including co-ownership of the Lynchburg Livestock Market.\n\nFariss married Crystal Dawn Brown. They have three children, Hunter, Bobby and Harrison.\n\n\nIn 2011, the 59th district incumbent,  , announced his retirement after 26 years of service. Fariss, the Republican nominee, won a three-way race against  Connie Brennan and independent Linda M. Wall, receiving 52.98% of the vote. Fariss labeled himself as a social conservative, opposing , as well as .\n\nIn October 2019, Fariss potentially violated Virginia campaign finance code by holding a fundraiser via raffle.\n\nIn 2022, Virginia's legislature reapportioned legislative districts following the U.S. Federal census, after which the 59th district covered counties substantially north and east of what had been Fariss' district, and the counties that had been in his district were now in the 51st legislative district. On June 20, 2023, Fariss filed for reelection as an Independent after missing the GOP Legislative District Committee's March 30 deadline amidst his legal troubles.\n\nOn November 7, 2023, Fariss finished a distant third in a three-way race, losing to both  nominee and winner  (who won 69% of votes cast) as well as  nominee Kimberly Moran (22%). Fariss only won approximately 8% of the votes cast.\n\n\nIn January 2016, Fariss was charged with two incidents. These included a misdemeanor breach of peace and a hit and run accident in which property was damaged but no people were hurt.\n\nIn April 2023, Fariss was charged with malicious wounding, failing to stop after an accident, and reckless driving after striking a woman with his SUV the previous month. Prior to striking the woman, Fariss had been angrily demanding that the woman get back into his vehicle after she left his vehicle on foot to get away from him. Fariss fled after a bystander who witnessed the scene shouted out. On March 5, 2024, Fariss was found not guilty on all three charges but was convicted of the lesser charge of improper driving and ordered to pay $500.\n\nFariss was arrested on March 23, 2024 on felony charges for possession of s and a firearm, and a misdemeanor charge of violating a protective order. Initially held without bail, he was released on bond on April 2 subject to drug testing. An October 1 bail review hearing revealed that Fariss had tested positive for drugs but the court gave him another chance. Fariss was arrested on October 25 following another positive drug test. Fariss will remain in jail awaiting his trial, scheduled for November 13.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n'''Matthew Edward Gonzalez''' (born June 4, 1965) is an American politician, lawyer, and activist. He served on the  from 2001 to 2005 and was president of the Board. In 2003, Gonzalez, running as a member of the , lost a  to Democrat . In the , Gonzalez ran for vice president as the running mate of candidate . , he works as the Chief Attorney at the San Francisco .\n\n\nMatthew Edward Gonzalez was born in . His father, a division chief for the international tobacco company ,Guthrie, Julian.  ''The San Francisco Chronicle'' Sunday, December 7, 2003 moved the family to , , and , before resettling in McAllen when Gonzalez was eleven years old. After graduating from , he attended , from which he graduated in 1987. In 1990, he earned a  degree from .\n\n\nGonzalez began working as a  at the  in San Francisco in 1991. Gonzalez served one term on the  from 2001 to 2005. He was elected president of the board in 2003. After losing the  in 2003, he chose not to seek re-election.\n\n\nGonzalez entered politics when he ran for San Francisco  in 1999. He campaigned to halt political corruption and marijuana prosecutions. Gonzalez lost to incumbent . In a field of five candidates, he finished third with 20,153 votes (11 percent of the total).\n\n\n\nA system of electing supervisors by district rather than citywide took effect in 2000. At the urging of Supervisor , Gonzalez moved from his home in the Mission District to run for supervisor in newly made . In early November, shortly before the , Gonzalez switched party affiliations from the  to the nascent . His opponent, Juanita Owens, tried to capitalize on many Democrats' ill feelings toward the Green Party in the wake of Ralph Nader's involvement in the acrimonious , but Gonzalez won the runoff election. He was part of a slate of candidates who wanted to change the direction of city policy, in opposition to the \" ,\" a Democratic Party political machine that had dominated local politics for over 30 years behind Mayor Willie Brown, the  family, and other Democrats.Shaw, Randy. ''Beyondchron'' (January 3, 2005),  His supporters saw his election as a turning point in local politics.Reed, Christopher.  '''', December 7, 2003. Wildermuth, John.  ''The San Francisco Chronicle'' December 16, 2003, \n\n\n\nGonzalez's critics considered him a stubborn and willful ideologue, though supporters noted his commitment to stand firm on principles over politicking. When the Board put forth a  commending  Congresswoman  for being elected  and being the first woman to hold that position, Gonzalez was the only board member who voted against it. Gonzalez said that supervisors should not issue commendations for winning partisan political positions and that he had written a personal note to Pelosi congratulating her, as she had done him for being elected board president.Wildermuth, John; Gordon, Rachel; Chronicle Political Writers; November 12, 2003)''San Francisco Chronicle''Mayoral Runoff Debate (November 11, 2003) ''Commonwealth Club Archives'' Gonzalez refused to meet with Brown during his first two years on the Board of Supervisors, saying he did so to avoid being subject to Brown's influence rather than as a matter of disrespect. Two sources reported that Gonzalez defied Brown by walking out of the mayor's State of the City address in 2002. However, Gonzalez later told '''' that he was never in attendance.\n\n\nIn January 2003, Gonzalez was elected president of the Board of Supervisors after seven rounds of voting, most of which had Gonzalez vying for a majority vote with supervisors  and . When Peskin dropped out Gonzalez emerged the winner, counting among his supporters conservative Board member , who said when asked why he voted for Gonzalez, \"Gonzalez is a man of integrity and intelligence who will carry out his responsibilities fairly and impartially.\"\n\nGonzalez hosted monthly art exhibits in his City Hall office. At the last reception,  artist  spray-painted \"Smash the State\" on the walls of the office as part of his exhibit.\"Lelchuk, I.   ''San Francisco Chronicle'' on the web, December 10, 2004. Gonzalez told the press that he knew his office would be repainted for the next occupant.\n\n\nIn August 2003, Gonzalez ran for mayor of San Francisco in a bid to replace outgoing two-term mayor . On a ballot with nine candidates, Gonzalez finished second in the primary election on November 4 behind , a Democrat and fellow member of the Board of Supervisors who had been endorsed by Brown. Gonzalez received 19.6 percent of the total vote to Newsom's 41.9 percent. Because none of the candidates received a majority, a  was held on December 9.\n\nGonzalez faced a difficult run-off election; only 3 percent of voters in San Francisco were registered to the Green Party, the party to which he belonged. Although Gonzalez was endorsed by several key local Democrats, including five members of the Board of Supervisors, national Democratic figures, concerned about Ralph Nader's role in the , campaigned on Newsom's behalf.McCarthy, Kevin.  '''', December 5, 2003.  , , , , and  all campaigned for Newsom. Gonzalez said about his candidacy, \"They're scared, not of a Green being elected mayor, but of an honest person being elected mayor.\" Newsom won the runoff race by a margin of 11,000 votes, capturing 53 percent of the vote to Gonzalez's 47 percent.\n\n\n rally in San Francisco]]\nFollowing the mayoral contest, Gonzalez announced he would not seek re-election to the Board of Supervisors. He left office when his term ended in January 2005. He was succeeded by , a  member and community activist who had also worked on Gonzalez's campaign. Gonzalez then opened law offices with fellow  alum Whitney Leigh. In May 2005 Gonzalez sought unsuccessfully to  of San Francisco school Superintendent . His law firm brought suit against a San Francisco hotel for not paying its workers the minimum wage; two  suits against Sacramento police for using s; against the city of San Jose and  for interfering with  rights of protestors; and against Clear Channel in a naming rights dispute over the locally owned San Francisco . It has also been involved in examining the  attack on the Yale  group ''The Baker's Dozen'' in .\n\n\n\n\nIn January 2008, Gonzalez, along with several other prominent  members, launched Ralph Nader's 2008 Presidential Exploratory Committee to support a possible Nader candidacy. On February 28, 2008, four days after announcing his presidential bid, Nader named Gonzalez as his running mate for the .\n\nNader announced that he and Gonzalez would not seek the Green Party nomination but would run as independents. On March 4, 2008, Gonzalez announced that he had left the Green Party and had changed his voter registration to independent. The change, he said, was to accommodate states, including ,  and , that did not allow members of political parties to run as independents.\n\nOn October 18, 2008 Gonzalez and Nader held a large protest on  following the passage of the . Their opposition to the bailout was a key issue of the Nader/Gonzalez campaign, in contrast to the Democratic and Republican Party candidates who supported the bill.\n\nGonzalez participated in the  vice-presidential debates, along with  vice-presidential candidate Darrell Castle and  , held in Las Vegas, on November 2, 2008. The event was hosted by Free and Equal.org and Free & Equal Elections (FREE), an organization of political parties, independent citizens and civic organizations formed to promote free and equal elections in the United States.\n\n\n appointed Gonzalez as Chief Attorney in the Public Defender's Office in February 2011.\n\nIn 2012, Gonzalez took a month-long unpaid leave of absence to act as co-counsel for a corporation in its $16 million lawsuit against San Francisco. This was a civil suit, and as such was not a violation of the San Francisco Public Defender's office rules of ethics, which states in part, \"No employee may provide legal advice or legal representation...to any person or entity other than in the employee's official capacity.\" The case involved Cobra Solutions, a minority-owned business, that had been wrongfully suspended from being able to bid on city information technology contracts. The article “How Business Was Done,” by Luke Thomas, published in 48 Hills, February 14, 2012, explained the key features of the litigation.\n\nGonzalez defended José Inez García Zárate in the  homicide trial. The trial received national media attention because the defendant was an undocumented immigrant who had previously been deported five times. Zarate, 45, was found not guilty of assault with a firearm but was convicted of being a felon in possession of a firearm. Zárate was sentenced to time already served.\n\nAfter the death of Jeff Adachi on 22 February 2019, Gonzalez served briefly as head of the public defender's office until an interim head, , was named. Mano was appointed Public Defender on March 11.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* Carlsson, Chris, ed.     "pages": }\n\n'''Michael P. Bell''' (born 1955) is a former Mayor of  who took office on January 4, 2010, and served until January 4, 2014. Bell previously served as Toledo Fire Chief and State Fire Marshal.\n\n\nHis career in Public Service began in 1980 when he joined the  as a firefighter and later became a certified paramedic/EMT. In 1990, he was appointed as Chief of the Toledo Fire and Rescue Department, the first African American as well as the youngest person ever to lead the department. He remained in that position for over 16 years. Under his leadership the TFD earned the prestigious honor of Accreditation by the Commission on Fire Accreditation, a certification held by only the most elite fire departments. He is a member of the International Fire Chief's Association and received the President's Award for his efforts for diversification.\n\n\nIn 2007, he was appointed as State Fire Marshal by Ohio Governor Ted Strickland. In that position he implemented the \"Everyone Goes Home\" program, stressing firefighter safety. That program earned the Seal of Excellence Award from the Firefighter Life Safety Initiatives Program.\n\n\n at Rudy's Hot Dog in 2011.]]\nIn 2009, Bell ran as an independent in Toledo's mayoral election. He ran against attorney Keith Wilkowski, a Democrat. Bell defeated Wilkowski on the November 3 election by a margin of only 2% and was sworn in on January 4, 2010. He was the second African-American mayor in the city's history.\n\nIn 2013, Bell again ran for mayor, however, his opponent, Councilman , won the mayor's race by a margin of 56.5% to 43.5%.\n\nThe unofficial vote was 28,002 for Mr. Collins and 21,535 for Mr. Bell. Turnout was 25.4 percent of registered voters in the city.\n\nBell officially ended his term as Mayor of Toledo on January 4, 2014.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael S. Katz''' (born January 1962) is an American physician and politician from the state of . Katz represented the 4th district in the  for one term, serving from 2009 to 2013. Originally a member of the , Katz later joined the . He is currently the Independent Party's nominee for U.S. Senate in the .\n\n\nKatz is an , having been trained in pediatric anesthesia at  and . He also owns a real estate company. Katz received an  from , a  from , and an  from .\n\n\nKatz ran for the 4th district of the  in 2008. The Republican incumbent, Senate Minority Leader , was not seeking re-election, instead . The 4th district is historically competitive, due in part to its high amount of third-party and independent voters. At the time, Republicans had a voter registration advantage in the district. Katz campaigned on a platform of improving public schools and increasing access to healthcare. Katz won the Democratic nomination over nonprofit executive Dee Durham with 63.0% of the vote before edging out  member John Clatworthy in the general election by just 1.3%. Katz raised $97,039 for his campaign.\n\nWhile in office, Katz supported the movement to preserve the historic Murphy House; however, the house was demolished in 2012. Katz also introduced several bills aimed at increasing transparency requirements for lobbyists, though none of them passed committee. In 2011, Katz accused Democratic state representative  of plagiarizing a bill he wrote to establish an accreditation process for s. Katz also refused to list Short as a cosponsor on his bill due to what he perceived as Short's \"poor treatment of the medical community during his private and public deliberations\" on an earlier bill. Short acknowledged his bill was very similar to Katz's bill, but argued that both bills were based on language written by the Delaware Department of Health and Social Services and the Medical Society of Delaware months earlier. Short also believed that Katz's bill contained too many protections for doctors, saying \"each piece of legislation Sen. Katz introduced has skewed in favor of his profession.\" Katz asked House Majority Leader  to open an ethics investigation into Short, but Schwartzkopf refused, pointing out that only members of the House could make such a request. Schwartzkopf also commented that Katz \"doesn’t think anyone should propose legislation involving doctors except for him.\" However, in 2012, Katz and Short collaborated on a bill to strengthen restrictions on  salesmen that successfully passed the legislature.\n\nKatz ran for re-election in 2012 and was unopposed in the Democratic primary. In the general election, he faced Republican , the Minority Leader of the . Lavelle had chosen to run for state senate after he and 4 other Republican state representatives were placed in the same district as a result of the . Lavelle defeated Katz by a margin of 3.3%. The race was one of the most expensive of the 2012 Delaware Senate elections, with Katz raising $245,128 for his campaign.\n\nKatz returned to politics in 2023 when he accepted the 's nomination for U.S. Senate at its July 1, 2023 convention in .\n\n\nKatz lives with his wife Trish. He has three children, Abigail, Emily, and Sander.\n\nIn 2011, Katz and his two daughters were riding a  at a  ski resort when their chair detached and fell 35 feet to the ground. All three were injured, with Katz suffering a broken back and a traumatic brain injury. One of his daughters was thrown from the chair on impact, while the other was dragged up the mountain because a piece of her ski equipment became stuck in the chair. The incident became a contentious issue during Katz's 2012 re-election campaign, as his opponent accused him of using his injuries as an excuse for frequently missing state meetings. In 2013, Katz filed a lawsuit against the ski resort. The resort requested a dismissal on the grounds that Katz had signed a  before attending, but a judge rejected the request and allowed the suit to continue. The suit was settled out of court in 2015 for an undisclosed sum.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
