    "pages": }\n'''Michel A. Ball''' (born September 17, 1954) is an American politician who was a member of the , representing its 10th district from 2002 to 2022.\n\n\nBall was born in  where he lived until 1963 with his sister Linda and his mother who was unable to care for the children. Because of their mother's chronic severe mental illness, he and his sister were placed in foster care until California authorities arranged for the children to live with their father Leldon Ball, who operated a sawmill in Hartselle, Alabama.  At 9 years old, Ball met his father for the first time when he and his sister arrived at the Birmingham, Alabama airport.\n\nHis father immediately began instilling into his son the value of service, faith,  respect for others, and humility; as well as the love of music and education. He was working alongside his father at the sawmill when a flying board struck them.  Because he turned to protect his 14-year-old son instead of moving out of danger, Leldon Ball was killed instantly.  \n\nBall lived with various friends and relatives in Hartselle until joining the U.S. Marine Corps in 1973 soon after graduating high school. He was honorably discharged as a sergeant in 1977.  A previous ruling by U.S. Federal Judge Frank M. Johnson, Jr that removed height and weight restrictions cleared the way for Ball at 5'4\" and 135 lbs to become an Alabama State Trooper in 1978, the smallest in its history at the time.\n\nHe served in uniform as a highway patrolman for 8 years, as well as a member of the SWAT team and the Special Operations Unit.  In 1986, Ball transferred to the Major Crimes Unit of the Alabama Bureau of Investigation conducting a wide variety of criminal inv including  His investigations included homicide, public corruption, voter fraud, child abuse, and organized crime. He was also the lead hostage negotiator in numerous hostage/barricade suspect incidents throughout the state.  Ball retired from the Alabama State Troopers in 2002 with 25 years of law enforcement service.\n\nIn 2002, Ball was elected as a Republican to represent the 10th District in the Alabama Legislature which encompasses Redstone Arsenal, the Marshall Space Flight Center, and the U.S. Space and Rocket Center.  \n\nDuring his 20-year tenure as a state representative he served as Chairman of the House Ethics and Campaign Finance Committee and the Chairman of the Madison County House Delegation, in addition multiple other committees including  Judiciary, Public Safety, Education Policy, County and Municipal Government, State Government, and Internal Affairs.\n\nAlthough, much of his legislative career was has focused the promotion of comprehensive Ethics and Transparency reforms in Alabama, he is probably best known for his advocacy for medical cannabis since the passage of Carly's Law in 2014, Leni's Law in 2016, and the Darren Wesley \"Ato\" Hall Compassion Act in 2021.       \n\nAfter several years of declining interest in partisan politics, Ball chose not to run for another legislative term in 2022, to  publish his memoir, ''Picking, Politicticking, and Pontificating: How an Ex-Cop Legalized Cannabis While Fighting Corruption'' and devote his attention to writing, storytelling, mentoring, and music.\n\nSoon after his final session in 2022, Ball left the , declaring himself an unaffiliated independent.  During the 2022 campaign between the Republican candidate David Cole and the Democratic candidate Marilyn Lands, Ball remained neutral; although Lands had been his campaign manager in 2002 when he was first elected to the state legislature.  However, following the 2023 resignation of Ball's successor in the 10th district, , following an election fraud conviction, Ball endorsed Lands when she ran in the subsequent special election as a .\n\nBall and his wife Karen live in Madison, Alabama with their two dogs Grant and Molly.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Gerald Michael Gabbard''' (born January 15, 1948) is an American politician, serving as the  for District 21 from the  party, since 2006. Gabbard rose to prominence for efforts to prevent same-sex marriage in Hawai'i by passing  to the  to give the state legislature \"the power to reserve marriage to opposite-sex couples\" under the 1996 . Gabbard, who was born in , is the first person of Samoan descent to serve in the Hawaii Senate.\n\nHis daughter, , served as a member of the  for  from 2013 to 2021 and was a candidate for .\n\n\nGabbard was born on January 15, 1948, in , one of eight children of Aknesis Agnes (Yandall) and Benjamin Harrison Gabbard, Jr, a Samoan of American ancestry. Mike Gabbard is of Samoan and European descent from both his maternal and paternal ancestry. He was a U.S. citizen from birth because of his father's U.S. citizenship.|name=Citizenship|group=}} Gabbard lived in Hawaii as a child and graduated from  in .  He studied at and obtained a degree in English from  in 1971.  He earned a  in community college administration from .\n\n\nIn the 1970s and early 1980s, Gabbard taught high school English in American Samoa and was a guidance counselor and later Assistant Dean of Instruction, and Dean of Adult and Community Education at .  He also worked as a head tennis pro at the  on the  of  in the mid 1970s.\n\nFrom 1983 to 1987, Gabbard and his wife Carol established the Ponomauloa School in , where he worked as headmaster and teacher; it closed after five years.\n\nFrom 1988 to 1992, Gabbard and his wife owned The Natural Deli, a vegetarian restaurant within  Down to Earth Natural Food Store. Gabbard closed the restaurant following picketing by activists after Gabbard said on his self-funded radio show, \"Let's Talk Straight Hawaii\", on , that \"If [two applicants] were both the same, then I would take the one that is not homosexual.\"\n\nIn the late 1980s and early 1990s, Gabbard and his wife worked for  Rick Reed.\n\nIn the early 1990s, Gabbard and his wife were listed as teachers for the .\n\nGabbard and his wife later started Hawaiian Toffee Treasures, a candy company in Honolulu.\n\n\nGabbard was elected to the  in a nonpartisan race in 2002.\n\nIn 2004, he ran unsuccessfully as a  for the  in the , losing to  .\n\nOn March 21, 2006, Gabbard announced his plans to run for the  in West Oahu's District 19, after 14-year incumbent Senator  decided not to run for reelection. On November 7, 2006, Gabbard defeated retired Honolulu police captain George Yamamoto by a 56% to 44% margin, to represent the district in the . Gabbard was sworn in on January 17, 2007. Gabbard, who was born in , became the first person of Samoan descent to serve in the Hawaii Senate.\n\nOn August 30, 2007, Gabbard switched from the  to the . His stated reason for doing so was that he believed that he could be more effective to his constituents as part of the majority party in the State Senate, where Democrats have long had a .\n\nOn November 2, 2010, Gabbard was re-elected for a second term to the Hawaii State Senate, after defeating Republican Aaron Bonar by a 74% to 26% margin. Gabbard served as the Chair of the Energy and Environment Committee from 2009 to 2015, which culminated with his leadership on the passage of a first-in-the-nation law to require Hawaii utilities to get 100% of their electricity from clean, renewable energy sources by 2045.\n\nOn November 6, 2012, Gabbard defeated Republican candidate Dean Capelouto, 72% to 28%, to represent the newly reapportioned Hawaii State Senate District 20.\n\nDuring the 2016 election cycle, Gabbard was unopposed, and was re-elected to the Hawaii State Senate for a four-year term on November 8, 2016.\n\n\n\nGabbard became an anti-homosexual activist before the same-sex marriage debate took hold in Hawaii. Between 1991 and 1996, Gabbard founded the organizations Stop Promoting Homosexuality Hawaii (renamed Stop Promoting Homosexuality International), Stop Promoting Homosexuality America, and the Alliance for Traditional Marriage and Values. Gabbard became well-known for his advocacy for . This amendment, approved by voters 69.2%–28.6%, gave the state legislature \"the power to reserve marriage to opposite-sex couples\" under the federal , signed by  in 1996.\n\nShortly after , Gabbard founded Stand Up For America (SUFA), a non-profit educational organization.\n\nIn 2007, Gabbard co-founded the non-profit Aloha Parenting Project (APP) with his wife Carol.\n\n\nGabbard opposes  and civil unions. He believes marriage should only be between a man and a woman.\n\nIn 2016, while serving as the Chair of the Water, Land, and Agriculture Committee, Gabbard authored a bill banning the sale of parts and products of .\n\nIn 2018, Gabbard authored legislation that enacted a statewide ban on sunscreens that contained the controversial chemicals  and . The bill also included a ban on the pesticide , and upon enactment, Hawaii became the first state to ban the substance.\n\nIn 2021, Gabbard reintroduced the Hawaii Cruelty Free Cosmetics Act, which passed the  and would make Hawaii the sixth state to ban cosmetic , after having previously introduced the bill in 2018. He received 's May 2021 award for Legislator of the Month. He also introduced and passed SCR44, a resolution which made Hawaii the first state to declare a \"\".\n\nHe is currently the Chair of the Agriculture and Environment Committee.\n\n\nGabbard is married to Carol (née Porter). A socially conservative , Gabbard serves as a  at St. Jude Catholic Church in . Mike's daughter Tulsi Gabbard is a politician. In the 1970s, Gabbard and his wife became devotees of Chris Butler, whom they called Jagad Guru Siddhaswarupananda Paramahamsa, who founded the ; Gabbard's sister Caroline, described it as the \" of the .\" Gabbard became vegetarian and gave his children  names.\n died in a stabbing in May 2024.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Nancy Ruth Landry''', also known as '''Nancy L. Matthews''' (born June 10, 1962), is an American politician who has served as the  since January 2024. In that capacity, she supported legislation by State Representative Barbara Norton of  to ban  in all Louisiana , but the measure was defeated by a vote of 61–34.\n\nLandry won reelection in the nonpartisan blanket primary held on October 24, 2015. Wright's 1,890 ballots (15.3 percent).\n\nLandry resigned from the House seven months prior to the expiration of her third term to become the chief of staff in the office of Secretary of State .     "pages": }\n'''Nancy Pletcher McFarlane''' is an American pharmacist and politician.  She served as the 61st mayor of , the state capital. She was elected to lead the city in the , and succeeded , who had declined to run for re-election to another term. McFarlane is a political independent (called \"Unaffiliated\" in North Carolina) but ran with the endorsement of the local . She was re-elected for three further terms, in , , and , but declined to run for re-election in 2019.\n\nBefore her election as mayor, McFarlane was a pharmacist and small business owner, served on the . She was elected in 2007 and re-elected without opposition in 2009.  She left her seat on the council when she was elected mayor.\n\n\n\nNancy Pletcher McFarlane was born in , on July 20, 1956, to Jean Pletcher and the late Ralph Pletcher. Joined by her brothers, the family lived in , where McFarlane formed an early impression that the congestion there was a detriment to living quality. \"I know what large, poorly planned growth can do to an area,\" she said during her 2011 run for mayor.\n\nMcFarlane earned a Bachelor of Science in pharmacy from 's School of Pharmacy at the Medical College of Virginia. While there, she met Ron McFarlane, who was pursuing a degree in pharmacy as well. She married him in 1980. In 2010 the McFarlanes received the Distinguished Pharmacy Alumni Award from Virginia Commonwealth University for the contributions they have made to the profession of pharmacy.\n\n\nAfter graduating from Virginia Commonwealth University, McFarlane worked as a hospital pharmacist in  until she and her husband moved to  in 1984. She later worked briefly as a retail pharmacist and then spent 15 years at Raleigh Community Hospital (now known as Duke Raleigh North) as a hospital pharmacist while raising her three children.\n\n\nIn 2002, after 22 years as a retail and hospital pharmacist, McFarlane launched MedPro Rx, Inc., an accredited specialty infusion pharmacy that provides infusion medications and services to clients with chronic illnesses. \"I wanted to provide more than medicine,\" she said. \"I wanted to offer the support and services that are often lost in bigger companies.\" She has built the company into one of Inc. Magazine's fastest-growing companies from 2009 to 2011. In 2013, McFarlane was named one of the top entrepreneurs in the Triangle region by Business Leader Magazine.\n\n\n news television crew in 2012]]\nMcFarlane won the District A City Council seat in 2007, and ran without opposition in 2009. She served on the Budget and Economic Development Committee and was chair of the Comprehensive Planning Committee.\n\nMcFarlane worked with the Coalition to Unchain Dogs which works to mitigate the negative consequences of keeping dogs chained and she initiated the tasking of the City Attorney to draw up the Dog Tethering Ordinance which was unanimously passed by the City Council on March 3, 2009, and took effect July 1 of that year.\n\n\n\nWhen her predecessor in the office, , decided to not seek re-election as mayor in 2011, he suggested to both McFarlane and fellow city councilor (and eventual successor)  that one of the two should run in his place.  She had been approached earlier with a similar suggestion, but considering herself largely apolitical, turned down the offer at that time.  Baldwin was, at the time, dealing with personal issues and declined to run, so McFarlane accepted the offer, and decided to run for mayor that year.  Running as an , she won 61% of the vote over the next candidate, a .\n\nBeing new to politics, she frequently sought advice both from her predecessor Meeker and former Raleigh mayor , as well as then New York City mayor .  She developed a leadership style described as \"dull\", with her council meetings almost always featuring unanimous votes.  This was due to her efforts holding discussions with council members outside of meetings to handle negotiations out of the public eye, and keep meetings efficient.\n\nShe presided over Raleigh during a period of unprecedented growth, as the formerly moribund downtown area was rebuilt, and as the population growth was among the highest in the United States.  Her biggest achievement during her time as mayor, and the one fraught with the most controversy, was the acquisition of the 325-acre campus of the former , which had been sought by the city for some time as a potential large public park.  At a time when North Carolina state party politics was shifting from Democratic to Republican control of the legislature and major state offices, McFarlane finalized a deal during the last months of outgoing governor 's term for the state of North Carolina (which owned the Dix property) to lease the land to the city of Raleigh.  The new governor, , backed by the legislature, made several attempts early in his term to halt or reverse the deal, but she developed a close working relationship with McCrory, himself a former mayor of a large North Carolina city () and in 2015, he reversed his former position and the lease was signed, allowing the city to build its park on the land.\n\nMcFarlane remained popular and was easily re-elected in 2013 and 2015, with her only serious opposition coming from Charles Francis during the 2017 campaign.  Following the 2017 election, her formerly smooth working relationship with the council was upended when internal political divisions led to several factions developing within the council, and unlike her prior terms, where there was little public debate, council meetings became acrimonious affairs where several council members attempted to form a \"working majority\" to steer the council in their own political direction and away from McFarlane's.\n\nFollowing surgery to correct debilitating back pain, on March 13, 2019, McFarlane announced that she would not be seeking re-election to a fifth term as mayor.  She was replaced in the 2019 election as mayor by her long-time political ally Mary-Ann Baldwin, and many of the council members who stood against her during her last term as mayor lost their seats on the city council, with the Baldwin administration re-enacting many of McFarlane's prior policies and programs.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

She was 's running mate in his  .\n\nBorn in California, Shanahan graduated from the  and the . Before law school, she worked as a paralegal and then as a patent specialist at the   She was a fellow at 's CodeX, Stanford Center for Legal Informatics.\n\nShanahan married  co-founder  in 2018; they separated in 2021 and divorced in 2023. She reportedly has a  over $1 billion, primarily as a result of her marriage to Brin. In 2019, she established a , Bia-Echo, that promotes research to .\n\nIn March 2024, Kennedy named Shanahan as his running mate in his . Shanahan has questioned the  on .\n\n\nShanahan was born to Shawn and Amy Shanahan (née Wong) in , on September 26, 1985. She grew up in . In a 2023 interview, she said she had a \"very hard\" childhood marked by  and poverty. Shanahan said her father, a computer specialist of  and  who died in 2014, had , , and , and struggled with . Shanahan's mother was born in China and immigrated to the U.S. from  in the 1980s; she worked as a maid before becoming an accountant. Shanahan has a younger brother.\n\nShanahan attended , a private  in . She then moved to , where she earned a bachelor's degree from the  in 2007. At the university, she studied , economics, and Mandarin Chinese. Shanahan worked as a paralegal and patent specialist (the latter at  ) before attending , from which she graduated with a  in 2014.\n\n\nWhile in law school, Shanahan was an  at . She became interested in  as a law student; after becoming a lawyer, she founded a -based  company, ClearAccessIP, and was its CEO. She sold the company to a competitor, IPwe, in 2020, in exchange for an estimated $20 million in IPwe stock; IPwe went bankrupt in 2024.\n\nShanahan has spoken about the impact of  (AI) on law and the legal profession. She was a fellow at 's CodeX, Stanford Center for Legal Informatics.\n\nShanahan served as  for the films '''' and ''Evolver''.\n\nShanahan is a member of the board of Carbon Royalty Corp. She invested in Linus Biotechnology, Inc. (LinusBio), a  firm, during a  in January 2023. Also in 2023, she joined the board of Extreme Tech Challenge. She is the \"Global Joy Officer\" and a member of the board at the Sloomoo Institute.\n\n\nIn 2018, Shanahan helped fund and launch the Center for Female Reproductive Longevity and Equality within the .\n\nIn 2019, she established her , Bia-Echo. It is named after , the ancient Greek goddess associated with energy. According to financial disclosure documents over a three-year period, Bia-Echo's sole donor was Shanahan's then-husband, . Before their divorce, Brin donated more than $20 million to Bia-Echo, much of it from shares of  (Google's parent company). He made another contribution to the foundation in 2021, but did not contribute in 2022. In 2022, the Bia-Echo Foundation reported owning $13.7 million in government securities and $12.2 million in stocks and bonds, and reported making $0 in grants or contributions to outside groups.\n\nIn 2019, Shanahan pledged to contribute $100 million through Bia-Echo over five years, mostly for \"reproductive longevity\" research, which aims to help . The foundation also supported a daylong conference of experts in November 2022, in Boston, sponsored by 's  and the school's Food and Nutrition Innovation Institute, \"to explore the state of the evidence and evidence gaps regarding the relationships between food, nutrition, and fertility.\"}} She has repeatedly criticized  (calling IVF \"one of the biggest lies that's being told about women's health today\") and championed unconventional research that she believes might allow women to have children into their 50s (suggesting, for example, that  might aid fertility).\n\nIn a 2023 interview, Shanahan said that finding a \"cure to \" was an additional focus of Bia-Echo, and estimated that she spent 60% of her time researching autism.\n\nIn 2022, Shanahan gave $70 million to Blue Meridian Partners, which makes grants to nonprofits that aim to help the impoverished.\n\n\nIn the 2010s and 2020s, Shanahan made various contributions to left-leaning organizations and  political candidates, including  and 's congressional campaigns. In 2020, she was a \"major donor\" to Measure J, a  referendum in . Also in 2020, she contributed $150,000 to support 's campaign for .\n\nDuring the , Shanahan contributed $2,800 each to the campaigns of  and . She co-hosted a fundraiser for Buttigieg in December 2019, along with other wealthy  figures. After  became the , she supported , contributing $25,000 to the Biden Victory Fund, and a five-figure sum to the .\n\n\n\nIn May 2023, when Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was running for the , Shanahan donated the  of $6,600 to his . After Kennedy dropped out of the Democratic primaries in October 2023, announcing that he would run in the general election as an independent candidate, Shanahan said she was \"incredibly disappointed\" and would not support his candidacy. But in early 2024, she reversed course, and resumed backing Kennedy. Through Planeta Management LLC, Shanahan donated $4 million to a  to pay for a 30-second television , aired during , supporting the campaign. In addition to funding the ad, Shanahan was also a \"creative force\" behind it, the total cost of which was variously said to be $5 million or (according to the super PAC's co-founder) $7 million. Kennedy said that his campaign was not directly involved with the ad, as coordination between  groups and campaigns is illegal.\n\nShanahan separately donated (also through Planeta Management LLC) half a million dollars to a different super PAC supporting Kennedy's campaign.\n\n\nIn March 2024, Kennedy's campaign manager and daughter-in-law, , confirmed that Shanahan was on the candidate's \"short list\" of potential running mates. The campaign also considered  and . On March 26, 2024, Kennedy formally announced Shanahan as his selection for vice president during a campaign event in Oakland, California. Shanahan left the Democratic Party when she joined the ticket. Her ability to bankroll the Kennedy campaign was seen as an advantage.\n\nShanahan was the richest candidate for vice president in at least 50 years, with a  possibly in the hundreds of millions of dollars. She gave almost $19 million on the Kennedy/Shanahan campaign, a small portion of her wealth. $8 million more to the campaign in May 2024, and a further $2.5 million in June 2024.}} Shanahan was among the top self-funded candidates of the 2024 election cycle (although she spent less than , who spent over $60 million on the Democratic ). Despite Shanahan's contributions, the campaign continued to struggle with fundraising, and its expenditures were greater than contributions.\n\nBy the time Kennedy dropped out of the race in August 2024, the Kennedy/Shanahan campaign had  in only 16 of the 50 states (representing 140 of the 538 electoral votes). The Kennedy campaign's efforts to get on the ballot in key states was supported by Republican megadonors and  organizations. In some states, the campaign pursued unconventional strategies to get on the ballot, such as forming new political parties or partnering with existing . For example, the  attempted to give its ballot line to Kennedy and Shanahan (displacing the national  ticket of  and ), but this effort was unsuccessful.\n\nDuring their campaign, Shanahan and Kennedy expressed divergent views. Shanahan expressed support for banning   \"between 15 and 18 weeks\" while a Kennedy spokesman said \"he believes the cutoff should be at fetal viability.\" In May 2024, Shanahan suggested that the campaign was intended to force a  in the House of Representatives, a suggestion Kennedy disavowed.\n\nShanahan rarely appeared at campaign events and infrequently gave interviews to mainstream outlets. Her first solo appearance on the campaign trail was a month and a half after Kennedy named her as his running mate.\n\nOn August 20, 2024, Shanahan said in an interview with podcast host Tom Bilyeu that the Kennedy campaign had discussions with the , and that she and Kennedy were considering whether to drop out of the race and \"join forces with\" Trump. She suggested that the campaign had no realistic prospect of winning the general election; that \"we draw votes from Trump\"; and that if Kennedy remained in the race, it would \"run the risk of\" aiding . Kennedy and Shanahan suspended their campaign two days later and endorsed Trump.\n\nIn October 2024, '''' reported that Shanahan attempted to bribe a journalist from the same newspaper with US$500,000 to reveal the sources of a profile story on her.\n\n\nIn interviews in 2024, Shanahan said she is \"not an anti-vaxxer\" but expressed support for Kennedy's  and questioned the  on their . After being selected as Kennedy's running mate, she referenced discredited anti-vaccine claims. and implied that , a debunked notion that Kennedy has promoted for years. On X (formerly ), she promoted , asserting that the vaccines are unsafe.\n\nShanahan believes that \"\" from mobile phones and other devices are contributing to an \"epidemic of chronic disease\" and that Kennedy was the only presidential candidate who \"takes the chronic disease epidemic seriously\".\n\nShe criticized the Biden administration for . She named the  U.S. Representative  as one of her \"favorite\" members of Congress.\n\n\nIn 2014, Shanahan married Jeremy Asher Kranz, a  investor and finance executive. They had dated since 2011. Weeks before their marriage, she began an affair with , a co-founder of Google, which Kranz discovered from texts on her phone. Kranz and Shanahan divorced in 2015. Shanahan had met Brin at a yoga festival in  in 2014; they married in 2018. They have a daughter together, born in 2018. Brin and Shanahan maintained an estate at  in , purchased in 2020.\n\nShanahan and Brin separated in December 2021, and Brin filed for divorce in January 2022. In 2022, the '''' reported that a reason for the breakup was a \"brief affair\" in 2021 between Shanahan and . Three people interviewed as part of a 2024 ''New York Times'' investigation said that Shanahan and Brin separated after Shanahan had a sexual encounter with Musk in 2021. Shanahan and Musk denied having had an affair. The ''Wall Street Journal'' said: \"We are confident in our sourcing, and we stand by our reporting.\" Shanahan and Brin had signed a . During the divorce proceedings, Shanahan's attorneys argued that she had signed it under , and in mediation sought more than $1 billion of Brin's $95 billion fortune. The divorce was finalized in 2023 in a confidential arbitration. '''' reported that Shanahan likely received around 2.6 million Alphabet s from Brin, worth $390 million in March 2024, and possibly an additional, equal amount of s. ''The New York Times'', citing three people with knowledge of Shanahan's finances, reported she has a  over $1 billion, mainly as a result of her marriage to Brin.\n\nIn 2023, Shanahan held a \"love ceremony\" of commitment with Jacob Strumwasser, an advisor at Lightning Labs, a  software company. She described the event as a  ceremony . The pair met at the  festival in 2022.\n\nFrom her marriage to Brin, Shanahan has a daughter, who was diagnosed with  in 2020. A doctor blamed Shanahan and Brin for their daughter's autism, falsely claiming that it was because Shanahan allowed her infant to receive vaccines and be exposed to  and . The doctor also accused Brin of participating in a plot by the U.S. government and \"Big Tech\" to use blue light to control the population. Shanahan took his advice and modified her home to limit non-sun light, as well as  and cellular signals. She also converted her  to .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Potter''' (born May 8, 1956 in , ) is a British Virgin Islander-American Virgin Islander politician who served as the 11th  from 2015 to 2019.\n\n\nOsbert Potter was the third of eight children born to Margaret and Cecil Potter on the island of , . At the age of 10, he moved to the island of . He would later attend the , graduating in 1974. He would continue his education at the , graduating cum laude in 1978 with a Bachelor of Arts in Business Administration, concentrating in Finance.\n\nHe was a part-time instructor at the University of the Virgin Islands from 1978–1992. He later successfully campaigned for a seat in the , being elected to the 20th and 21st Legislature in 1992 and 1994 respectively. During his tenure, he served as Chairman of the Committee of Economic Development, Agriculture and Consumer Protection. Potter joined the  in 1985 and served for 23 years.  In 2004, he was hired to head , the only PBS affiliate in the territory.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Paula Jean Swearengin''' (born June 13, 1974) is an American activist and politician who was the  nominee in the , and a candidate in the Democratic primary for the state's other Senate seat in . Her 2018 campaign was one of four campaigns featured in the 2019 documentary ''''.\n\nSwearengin lost the 2020 election to  incumbent  by more than 40 percentage points, and the 2018 primary to incumbent . She left the Democratic Party in 2021 and joined the . She left the organization in 2022.\n\n\nSwearengin was born in  to a family of coal miners historically affiliated with the . One of her grandfathers served in the , and her father in the . She lost her grandfather and several uncles to  contracted in the coal mines. Her father died of  at age 52.\n\n\nSwearengin was professionally employed as an . She has advocated for economic diversity, clean air and clean water in her community, and all of West Virginia, since 2001. She is a former board member and representative of the Keepers of the Mountain Foundation, a West Virginia organization that opposed . She has also spoken on behalf of the  and the  at public fora and events, including  hearings on the . She supported 's . On February 20, 2022, Swearengin left the People's Party.\n\n\n\nIn May 2017, Swearengin announced her candidacy against Joe Manchin in the U.S. Senate election in West Virginia. She was one of the first candidates supported by . Swearengin refused all  donations in the election and received no contributions over $200.\n\nSwearengin's campaign was highlighted in the 2019 documentary '''' alongside the  of , , and , three other  who ran for  in the , with Ocasio-Cortez winning her election. The film premiered at the . and was released on  on May 1, 2019.\n\n\nSwearengin supports a  healthcare plan. She favors legalization of both medical and recreational . She also supports raising the  to $15 and free public college tuition. She has spoken out against the influence of  in addressing the  and argues that long-term treatment centers and a  model both have roles to play in addressing the epidemic.\n\n\n\nIn June 2019, Swearengin announced her campaign for Senate against Republican incumbent . She had two opponents in the June 9 Democratic primary, Richie Robb and . Swearengin won with 38% of the vote to Ojeda's 33% and Robb's 29%. In the November 3 general election she faced Capito, who has been a Senator since 2015, and unaffiliated candidate Franklin Riley, losing to the former.\n\nSwearengin joined her three other '''' co-stars in endorsing Vermont Senator  for the Democratic nomination for president in 2020. Sanders endorsed Swearengin's campaign for Senate on July 8, 2020. In the November general election, Capito defeated Swearengin. Swearengin left the Democratic party less than one year later, writing in July 2021 of the  and the  that \"I can't support racism or them ignoring Appalachian children dying & suffering.\"\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nSwearengin is a single mother. She has four sons and one grandson. She lives in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n()|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n|birth_place  = \n|death_date   = \n|death_place  = \n|party        = \n|otherparty   =  (until change to Independent)\n|spouse       = Linda\n|children     = 2\n|residence    = \n|alma_mater   = \n|profession   = \n|religion     = \n|website      = \n}}\n\n'''Richard D. Henderson''' (born March 15, 1971) is an American retired politician who served four consecutive terms as a member of the  for the 74th district from January 2007 to January 2015. Before serving in , Henderson served one term as the  of  from January 2003 to January 2007. Henderson decided against running for mayoral re-election in order to run for the Kentucky House of Representatives seat held by the retiring . In 2015, after losing re-election to a fifth term, Henderson filed to run for . He would finish third in the statewide  primary with 32,914 votes behind Neville Blakemore's 36,663 votes and the winner 's 44,397 votes. In 2023, after an eight-year hiatus, Henderson filed to run as an  in the  for the  District 28  seat. On May 16, Henderson would finish third in the election with 3,001 votes behind Democrat Robert Sainte's 4,968 votes and the winner  ' 7,899 votes. Henderson would announce his retirement from politics in the local newspaper.\n\n\n*2023: Henderson was the Independent candidate in a Special Election for the Kentucky Senate District 28 on May 16, 2023. Henderson would finish third in the election with 3,001 votes behind Democrat Robert Sainte's 4,968 votes and the winner Republican Greg Elkins' 7,899 votes.\n*2015: Henderson filed to run for  on January 16, 2015. Henderson was part of a five-candidate Democratic primary on May 19, 2015. Henderson would finish third in the statewide primary with 32,914 votes behind Neville Blakemore's 36,663 votes and the winner 's 44,397 votes.\n*2014: Henderson was unopposed in the May 20, 2014, Democratic primary, and lost to Republican nominee  in the November 4, 2014, General Election 8,346 votes (52.8%) to 7,453 votes (47.2%).\n*2012: Henderson was unopposed for both the May 22, 2012, Democratic primary, and the November 6, 2012, general election, winning with 11,562 votes.\n*2010: Henderson was challenged in the May 18, 2010 Democratic primary, winning with 6,007 votes (54.0%) and would win the November 2, 2010, general election, with 8,223 votes (63.5%) against Republican nominee Jeff Moore.\n*2008: Henderson and returning 2006 Republican opponent Woodrow Wells both won their 2008 primaries, setting up a rematch; Henderson won the November 4, 2008, general election with 11,994 votes (73.0%) against Wells.\n*2006: When District 74 Representative  retired and left the seat open, Henderson won the seven-way 2006 Democratic primary with 2,771 votes (26.6%) and won the November 7, 2006, general election with 8,868 votes (72.7%) against Republican nominee Woodrow Wells.\n\n\n\n\n\n* at the \n*\n* at \n* at the National Institute on Money in State Politics\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
